column4: [Inglês] Spatial and temporal distribution of tadpole assemblages (AmphibiaVIRGULA Anura) in a seasonal dry tropical forest of southeastern Brazil
column5: [Inglês] We determined spatial and temporal distribution of tadpoles in 11 breeding habitats from Morro do Diabo State Park (MDSP)VIRGULA southeastern Brazil. Breeding habitats occupancy by tadpoles was tested to be different from a null model of random placement of species. We also tested whether tadpole occupancy in a given breeding habitat is organized according to different ecomorphological guildsVIRGULA and we analyzed spatial partitioning of tadpoles among breeding habitats through similarity analysis. For temporal analysis we analyzed temporal partitioning of tadpole monthly occurrence also using similarity analysisVIRGULA and assessed what climatic variable better predicts tadpole temporal occurrence in the MDSPVIRGULA through regression analysis. Among tadpoles from 19 anuran speciesVIRGULA distribution was different from a null modelVIRGULA but co-occurrence patterns among the breeding habitats did not differ among different guilds. HoweverVIRGULA breeding habitats with similar hydroperiods had similar species compositionVIRGULA which may be related to the reproduction patterns of species. Among the three climatic variables analyzed (rainfallVIRGULA temperatureVIRGULA and photoperiod)VIRGULA temporal occurrence of monthly tadpole richness and abundance was correlated with temperature and rainfall. Most species were found only during the rainy season monthsVIRGULA and overlap occurred within three groups of species. ThusVIRGULA temporal distribution does not seem to be an important mechanism in species segregation at the MDSPVIRGULA where the dry season is pronounced. In this caseVIRGULA spatial partitioning tends to be more important for species coexistence. (AU)

(HarpacticoidaVIRGULA Tachidiidae)VIRGULA um novo copépode da meiofauna do litoral norte do estado de São PauloVIRGULA BrasilVIRGULA [Inglês] Microarthridion corbisierae sp. nov. column5: [Português] Durante estudos sobre a diversidade de copépodes harpacticóides meiobentônicos marinhosVIRGULA um novo representante da família Tachidiidae foi encontrado na plataforma continental interna do estado de São PauloVIRGULA entre o canal de São Sebastião e a área costeira em frente á praia de UbatumirimVIRGULA Ubatuba (23º24'SVIRGULA 44º57VIRGULA6'W). Material complementar foi coletado próximo à praia da EnseadaVIRGULA Ubatuba (23º30'SVIRGULA 45º05'W). Embora esta nova espécie compartilhe com M. laurenticum (NichollsVIRGULA 1940) a redução das antênulasVIRGULA ela pode ser facilmente distinguida de seus congêneres pela presença de apenas 2 artículos no endópodo da perna 4 e pela redução no número de cerdas internas do endópodo-3 das pernas 1-4 e do exópodo-3 da perna 3. Os TachidiidaeVIRGULA que tipicamente habitam sedimentos finos de águas rasas salobras e marinhas do Hemisfério NorteVIRGULA são considerados bioindicadores de ambientes ricos em material orgânico. Este é o primeiro relato da família no hemisfério sul. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] During studies on the diversity of meiobenthic marine harpacticoid copepodsVIRGULA a new representative of the family Tachidiidae was found on the inner continental shelf of São Paulo StateVIRGULA between São Sebastião Channel and Ubatumirim BayVIRGULA Ubatuba (23º24'SVIRGULA 44º57VIRGULA6'W). Complementary material was collected near Enseada BeachVIRGULA Ubatuba (23º30'SVIRGULA 45º05'W). Although the new species shares with M. laurenticum (NichollsVIRGULA 1940) the reduced antennulesVIRGULA it can be easily distinguished from its congeners by leg 4 endopod with only two segments and the reduction of the number of inner setae of legs 1-4 endopod-3 and leg 3 exopod-3. TachidiidsVIRGULA typically inhabiting fine sediments of brackish and marine shallow waters in the Northern HemisphereVIRGULA are good indicators of heavy organic pollution. This is the first record of the family Tachidiidae in the southern hemisphere. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Gametogenic cycle of Ophioderma januariiVIRGULA a common Ophiodermatidae (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea) in southeastern Brazil
column5: [Inglês] This study describes the gametogenic cycle of Ophioderma januarii LütkenVIRGULA 1856VIRGULA a common species of ophiuroid in Southeastern Brazil. The specimens were collected during the project "Biodiversidade Bêntica Marinha no Estado de São Paulo-BIOTA/FAPESP-Bentos Marinho" (Marine benthic biodiversity in the State of São Paulo-BIOTA/ Fapesp-Marine Benthos) which was conducted off the northern coast of the state of São Paulo. Specimens were captured monthly between February 2001 and December 2002. Due to the low number of individuals the monthly data was grouped in seasons (spring to winter). A total of 101 specimens were obtained: 33 in springVIRGULA 10 in summerVIRGULA 23 in autumnVIRGULA and 35 in winter. The gonads of eighty-eight individuals (45 femalesVIRGULA 42 malesVIRGULA and one hermaphrodite) were analyzed histologically. The male and female gametogenic cycles were classified into five different gonadal stagesVIRGULA which were analyzed separately. The reproductive pattern could be defined through histological analyses of male and female gonadsVIRGULA together with oocyte diameter frequency. Some general conclusions could also be reached: this is a gonochoric species that reproduces year-round but increases its gonadal activity during summerPONTOCOMMA based on the size of its mature oocytesVIRGULA it has lecithotrophic development. ApparentlyVIRGULA its recruitment is enhanced in late summerVIRGULA and smaller individuals are more frequent during autumn and winter. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Can the deforestation breeze change the rainfall in Amazonia? A case study for the BR-163 highway region
column5: [Inglês] The authors simulated the effects of Amazonian mesoscale deforestation in the boundary layer and in rainfall with the Brazilian Regional Atmospheric Modeling System (BRAMS) model. They found that both the area and shape (with respect to wind incidence) of deforestation and the soil moisture status contributed to the state of the atmosphere during the time scale of several weeksVIRGULA with distinguishable patterns of temperatureVIRGULA humidityVIRGULA and rainfall. Deforestation resulted in the development of a three-dimensional thermal cellVIRGULA the so-called deforestation breezeVIRGULA slightly shifted downwind to large-scale circulation. The boundary layer was warmer and drier above 1000-m height and was slightly wetter up to 2000-m height. Soil wetness affected the circulation energetics proportionally to the soil dryness (for soil wetness below &#8764PONTOCOMMA&#8764PONTOCOMMA0.6). The shape of the deforestation controlled the impact on rainfall. The horizontal strips lined up with the prevailing wind showed a dominant increase in rainfallVIRGULA significant up to about 60 000 km<sup>2</sup>. On the other handVIRGULA in the patches aligned in the opposite direction (north--south)VIRGULA there was both increase and decrease in precipitation in two distinct regionsVIRGULA as a result of clearly separated upward and downward branchesVIRGULA which caused the precipitation to increase for patches up to 15 000 km<sup>2</sup>. The authors'' estimates for the size of deforestation impacting the rainfall contributed to fill up the low spatial resolution in other previous studies. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Elevated CO2 increases photosynthesisVIRGULA biomass and productivityVIRGULA and modifies gene expression in sugarcane
column5: [Inglês] Because of the economical relevance of sugarcane and its high potential as a source of biofuelVIRGULA it is important to understand how this crop will respond to the foreseen increase in atmospheric [CO2]. The effects of increased [CO2] on photosynthesisVIRGULA development and carbohydrate metabolism were studied in sugarcane (Saccharum ssp.). Plants were grown at ambient (&#8764PONTOCOMMA370 ppm) and elevated (&#8764PONTOCOMMA720 ppm) [CO2] during 50 weeks in open-top chambers. The plants grown under elevated CO2 showedVIRGULA at the end of such periodVIRGULA an increase of about 30% in photosynthesis and 17% in heightVIRGULA and accumulated 40% more biomass in comparison with the plants grown at ambient [CO2]. These plants also had lower stomatal conductance and transpiration rates (&#8722PONTOCOMMA37 and &#8722PONTOCOMMA32%VIRGULA respectively)VIRGULA and higher water-use efficiency (c.a. 62%). cDNA microarray analyses revealed a differential expression of 35 genes on the leaves (14 repressed and 22 induced) by elevated CO2. The latter are mainly related to photosynthesis and development. Industrial productivity analysis showed an increase of about 29% in sucrose content. These data suggest that sugarcane crops increase productivity in higher [CO2]VIRGULA and that this might be relatedVIRGULA as previously observed for maize and sorghumVIRGULA to transient drought stress. (AU)

In addition 23 new species were described and illustrated: Dissomphalus inclinatus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. divisus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. distans sp. nov.VIRGULA D. crassus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. filiformis sp. nov.VIRGULA D. inflexus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. spissus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. firmus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. setosus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. tubulatus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. differens sp. nov.VIRGULA D. lamellatus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. fimbriatus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. magnus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. trilobatus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. amplifoveatus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. personatus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. excellens sp. nov.VIRGULA D. peculiaris sp. nov.VIRGULA D. bahiensis sp. nov.VIRGULA D. amplexus sp. nov.VIRGULA D. elegans sp. nov. e D. amplus sp. nov.. column4: [Inglês] Myzomolgus sipunculensis sp. nov. (CyclopoidaVIRGULA Catiniidae)VIRGULA a new copepod associated with sipunculan worms from BrazilVIRGULA [Português] Myzomolgus sipunculensis sp. nov. (CyclopoidaVIRGULA Catiniidae)VIRGULA um novo copépode associado a sipuncúlidos do Brasil
column5: [Inglês] Catiniid copepods are characterized by the presence of a pedunculate sucker on the antenna. Four genera are currently included in the family Catiniidae: CatiniaVIRGULA CotylemyzonVIRGULA Cotylomolgus and MyzomolgusVIRGULA the most speciose. Within the framework of the Special Research Program "Conservation and Sustainable Use of the Biodiversity of the State of São Paulo &#8211PONTOCOMMA Biota/FAPESP"VIRGULA a new species of Myzomolgus was found as an external associate of Sipunculus nudus and S. phalloides phalloides. The sipunculan worms were collected during the low tide in Araçá BeachVIRGULA State of São PauloVIRGULA Brazil (23º4902"SVIRGULA 45º2419"W). The new species differs from its three congenersVIRGULA namely M. stupendus from France and M. tenuis and M. orientalis from KoreaVIRGULA by the peculiar ornamentation of the third antennal segmentVIRGULA morphology of mandible and leg 6 and presence of denticulate area between maxillipeds. The description of this new species raises to four the number of catiniid species (one of Catinia and two of Myzomolgus) associated with the widely distributed S. nudus. In BrazilVIRGULA this is the first record of Myzomolgus and the second species associated with sipunculan worms (a new species of Catinia found on S. phalloides phalloides is under description). (AU)VIRGULA [Português] Os copépodes catiniídeos se caracterizam pela presença de uma ventosa pedunculada na antena. AtualmenteVIRGULA quatro gêneros estão incluídos na família Catiniidae: CatiniaVIRGULA CotylemyzonVIRGULA Cotylemolgus e MyzomolgusVIRGULA o mais especioso. Como parte de um programa especial de pesquisa "Conservação e Uso Sustentável da Biodiversidade do Estado de São Paulo &#8211PONTOCOMMA Biota/FAPESP"VIRGULA uma nova espécie de Myzomolgus foi encontrada associada à superfície externa de Sipunculus nudus e S. phalloides phalloides. Os sipuncúlidos foram coletados na Praia do AraçáVIRGULA Estado de São PauloVIRGULA Brasil (23º4902"SVIRGULA 45º2419"W)VIRGULA durante a maré baixa. A nova espécie difere de M. stupendusVIRGULA da FrançaVIRGULA e M. tenuis e M. orientalisVIRGULA ambos da Coréia do SulVIRGULA pela ornamentação peculiar do terceiro artículo da antenaVIRGULA morfologia da mandíbula e perna 6VIRGULA e presença de área denticulada entre os maxilípedes. A descrição desta nova espécie eleva para quatro o número de catiniídeos (uma espécie de Catinia e duas de Myzomolgus) associados a S. nudusVIRGULA um táxon de larga distribuição. No BrasilVIRGULA este é o primeiro relato de MyzomolgusVIRGULA e o registro da segunda espécie associada a sipuncúlidos (uma nova espécie de Catinia associada a S. phalloides phalloides encontra-se em descrição). (AU)

column5: [Português] Os ofiuróides aqui analisados são procedentes dos programas "Biodiversidade Bêntica Marinha no Estado de São Paulo" &#8211PONTOCOMMA BIOTA/FAPESP-Bentos MarinhosVIRGULA "Avaliação do Potencial Sustentável dos Recursos Vivos da Zona Econômica Exclusiva" &#8211PONTOCOMMA REVIZEE/Score Sul-Bentos e "Utilização Racional dos Ecossistemas Costeiros da Região Tropical Brasileira: Estado de São Paulo" &#8211PONTOCOMMA INTEGRADO/Subprojeto Bentos. As amostras analisadas foram coletadas nas regiões da plataforma e talude continental do Sudeste e Sul brasileirosVIRGULA em profundidades entre 10 e 800 m. São aqui descritas e ilustradas quatro espécies de OphiuroideaVIRGULA as quais representam novos registros de ocorrência para o BrasilVIRGULA duas da família OphiuridaeVIRGULA uma de Amphiuridae e uma de Ophiochitonidae. Este é também o primeiro registro desta última família para o Brasil. Somente Amphiodia trychna (Amphiuridae) foi amostrada na região da plataforma interna (profundidade < 50 m). As demais ocorreram em maiores profundidades (de 314 a 808 m). (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The ophiuroids were collected during the Programs "Biodiversidade Bêntica Marinha no Estado de São Paulo" &#8211PONTOCOMMA BIOTA/FAPESP-Marine BenthosVIRGULA "Avaliação do Potencial Sustentável dos Recursos Vivos da Zona Econômica Exclusiva" &#8211PONTOCOMMA REVIZEE/Score South &#8211PONTOCOMMA Benthos and "Utilização Racional dos Ecossistemas Costeiros da Região Tropical Brasileira: Estado de São Paulo" &#8211PONTOCOMMA INTEGRADO/Subproject Benthos. Samples were obtained from the continental shelf and slope off southeast and south BrazilVIRGULA between 10 and 800 m. Four species of the Ophiuroidea are described and they are new records for Brazil. Two species belong to the family OphiuridaeVIRGULA and the others belong to Amphiuridae and Ophiochitonidae. The family Ophiochitonidae is recorded for the first time in Brazil. Amphiodia trychna (Amphiuridae) was sampled in the inner continental shelf (depth < 50 m). The other three species were collected deeper (between 314 and 808 m). (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Species richness and geographic distribution of the genera Chydorus and Pseudochydorus (CladoceraVIRGULA Chydoridae) in São Paulo StateVIRGULA [Português] Distribuição das espécies dos gêneros Chydorus e Pseudochydorus (CladoceraVIRGULA Chydoridae) no estado de São Paulo
column5: [Português] Os gêneros Chydorus e Pseudochydorus são de ampla distribuição geográfica. Algumas espécies de Chydorus estão entre os anomópodos mais comuns e Pseudochydorus globosusVIRGULA a única espécie do gêneroVIRGULA é considerada cosmopolita. O presente estudo está inserido no projeto " Biodiversidade zooplanctônica e o estado de degradação dos ecossistemas aquáticos continentais do estado de São Paulo" VIRGULA como parte do Programa BIOTA/FAPESP &#8211PONTOCOMMA O Instituto Virtual da Biodiversidade (www.biota.org.br) e teve como objetivo o inventário e a análise da distribuição das espécies dos gêneros Chydorus e Pseudochydorus no estado de São Paulo. Foram amostrados 223 corpos de água e 373 amostras das unidades de gerenciamento dos recursos hídricos do estado de São PauloVIRGULA entre 09/09/1999 e 28/08/2002. Os ambientes amostrados compreenderam desde pequenos córregosVIRGULA riosVIRGULA lagoasVIRGULA lagosVIRGULA até grandes reservatórios. Foram registradas seis espécies do gênero Chydorus e uma espécie do gênero Pseudochydorus. As espécies mais comuns e mais amplamente distribuídas foram Chydorus eurynotus e Chydorus pubescens. A espécie Chydorus parvireticulatus ocorreu em apenas uma unidade de gerenciamento recursos hídricos e constituiu o primeiro registro desta espécie no Estado de São Paulo. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The Chydorus and Pseudochydorus genera are widely distributed around the world. Some species of Chydorus are among the commonest anomopods and Pseudochydorus globosusVIRGULA the only species of the genusVIRGULA is believed cosmopolitan. This study was part of the project " Zooplanktonic biodiversity and state of degradation of continental water ecosystems in São Paulo State" VIRGULA itself a part of the FAPESP/BIOTA Program - The Virtual Institute of Biodiversity (www.biotasp.org.br)VIRGULA the aim being to make an inventory and analyze the distribution of species of the genera Chydorus and Pseudochydorus in São Paulo StateVIRGULA Brazil. In totalVIRGULA 373 samples were collected from 223 water bodies in the Water Resources Management Units of São Paulo StateVIRGULA between 9/9/1999 and 8/28/2002. The sampled sites varied from small streamsVIRGULA riversVIRGULA pondsVIRGULA lakes up to big reservoirs. Six species of the genus Chydorus and one of the genus Pseudochydorus were recorded. The most common and widely distributed species were Chydorus eurynotus and Chydorus pubescens. The species Chydorus parvireticulatus occurred only in one Water Resources Management Unit of the stateVIRGULA and constituted the first recorded of this species in São Paulo State. (AU)

column4: [Português] Pelagic and littoral cladocerans (CrustaceaVIRGULA Anomopoda and Ctenopoda) from reservoirs of the Northwest of São Paulo StateVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA [Inglês] Cladóceros (CrustaceaVIRGULA Anomopoda e Ctenopoda) pelágicos e litorâneos em reservatórios na região noroeste do estado de São PauloVIRGULA Brasil
column5: [Português] A região noroeste paulista é uma das regiões com menor quantidade de dados sobre o zooplânctonVIRGULA comparado a outras regiões do estado. Os Cladocera constituem um grupo bastante representativo do zooplânctonVIRGULA apresentando elevada diversidade de espécies. A maior parte desta diversidade pode ser encontrada nas regiões litorâneas de lagos e reservatóriosVIRGULA especialmente aquelas ocupadas por muitas macrófitas. Como parte de um projeto temático mais amplo (Programa Biota-Fapesp &#8211PONTOCOMMA Instituto Virtual da BiodiversidadeVIRGULA www.biotasp.org.br)VIRGULA o presente trabalho tem o objetivo de caracterizar as comunidades de cladóceros (CrustaceaVIRGULA Anomopoda e Ctenopoda) pelágicos e litorâneos presentes em pequenos reservatórios na região noroeste do estado de São PauloVIRGULA nas estações seca e chuvosa. As amostragens foram realizadas tanto na zona litorânea quanto pelágica de 10 pequenos reservatórios rasos (média de 2VIRGULA8 m)VIRGULA através de arrastos verticais com rede de plâncton de 45 µm de malha. Parâmetros físicos e químicos da água também foram avaliados utilizando-se o aparelho Horiba U10. As concentrações de oxigênio e o pH foram mais baixos na estação chuvosaVIRGULA indicando maiores taxas de decomposição. A entrada de matéria proveniente do ambiente rural pode ser o principal fator que contribui para a eutrofização dos reservatórios. No totalVIRGULA foram identificadas 58 espécies de cladócerosVIRGULA sendo que destasVIRGULA quatro constituem novas ocorrências para o estado de São Paulo. Esta elevada riqueza contrapõe-se com o fato de que a região noroeste paulista tem sido considerada uma das mais devastadas do estado. Maiores valores de riqueza e diversidade foram observados na zona litorâneaVIRGULA comparado à zona pelágicaVIRGULA durante as duas estações. Zonas litorâneas com maior diversidade de macrófitas também apresentaram maiores riqueza e diversidade de espécies de cladóceros do que zonas com menor diversidade de macrófitas. As comparações entre as zonas litorâneas e pelágicas evidenciaram a importância dos estudos nos diferentes compartimentos dos ambientes aquáticosVIRGULA confirmando a elevada riqueza na zona litorâneaVIRGULA já relatada em tantos outros trabalhosVIRGULA bem como revelando a forte influência da comunidade de macrófitas e do ambiente terrestre adjacente. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] There are few studies on the zooplankton from the northwestern region of São Paulo StateVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA compared to other regions of the State. Cladocerans are a very representative zooplankton group with high species diversity. Most of this diversity can be found at littoral zones of lakes and reservoirsVIRGULA especially those occupied by macrophytes. This study was part of a thematic project FAPESP/BIOTA Program - The Virtual Institute of Biodiversity (www.biotasp.org.br)VIRGULA and its aim is to catalogue and analyze the distribution of cladoceran species (CrustaceaVIRGULA Anomopoda and Ctenopoda) in pelagic and littoral zones from small reservoirs in the northwest of the São Paulo StateVIRGULA in dry and rainy seasons. Zooplankton samplings were carried out in littoral and pelagic zone of 10 small shallow reservoirs (mean depth: 2.8 m) using a plankton 45 µm mesh net. Water physical and chemical parameters were also monitored with a multiparameter Horiba U10. pH and dissolved oxygen concentration were lower at rainy than dry seasonsVIRGULA indicating high decomposition rates of organic matter introduced from the rural environmentVIRGULA being the main factor contributing to reservoirs' eutrophication. Fifty eight cladocerans species were recordedVIRGULA with four new occurrences for the São Paulo State. This high richness contrasts with the high devastation of the northwestern region in the State. During the two seasonsVIRGULA littoral zones presented higher cladoceran richness and diversity than pelagic zone. Littoral zones with higher macrophytes diversity also showed higher cladocerans richness and diversity than that with low macrophyte diversity. Littoral and pelagic zones comparisons emphasized the importance of studies on different regions of the aquatic environmentsVIRGULA confirming the elevated richness in the littoral zoneVIRGULA as reported in previous works. This study revealed also the strong influence of the macrophyte community and the adjacent terrestrial environmentVIRGULA which is occupied by forest or agriculture. (AU)

column4: [Português] Diferença entre dois métodos de coleta utilizados na captura de crustáceos decápodes em um rio da Estação Ecológica Juréia-ItatinsVIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA [Inglês] Differences between two methods used for sampling decapod crustaceans in a stream at Juréia-Itatins Ecological StationVIRGULA state of São PauloVIRGULA Brazil
column5: [Português] Durante os anos 2000 e 2001 foram realizadas coletas sazonais de crustáceos decápodes em dois pontos de um rio na Estação Ecológica Juréia-ItatinsVIRGULA utilizando-se duas metodologias distintas (peneira e armadilha). Comparando-se ambos os métodos de coletaVIRGULA foram constatadas diferenças quanto à composição e riqueza da carcinofauna capturadaVIRGULA grau de dominância e equitatividadeVIRGULA bem como tamanho e número de indivíduos coletados. Além dissoVIRGULA as razões sexuais de Macrobrachium acanthurus (WiegmannVIRGULA 1836) podem diferir dependendo do método de coleta utilizado. Devido à grande variedade de hábitats e hábitos dos crustáceosVIRGULA pode-se inferir queVIRGULA para um levantamento qualitativo e/ou quantitativo eficaz e apurado da comunidade de crustáceos decápodes dulcícolas de um determinado rioVIRGULA é recomendado o uso de mais de um método de coleta. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] Sampling collections were taken quarterly from Fall 2000 to Summer 2001 at Juréia-Itatins Ecological Station using two different sampling methods (hand sieve and traps). Comparing both sampling methods one can verify differences in faunal compositionVIRGULA richnessVIRGULA degree of dominanceVIRGULA evenness and size and number of individuals. MoreoverVIRGULA the sex ratio of Macrobrachium acanthurus (WiegmannVIRGULA 1836) may differ according to the sampling method. Decapod crustaceans are known to inhabit a great variety of habitats and nichesVIRGULA therefore to obtain an effective qualitative and/or quantitative samplingVIRGULA in which the majority of decapod species are collectedVIRGULA the use of more than one sampling method is recommended. (AU)

column4: [Português] Anurofauna de remanescentes de Floresta Atlântica do município de São José do BarreiroVIRGULA Estado de São PauloVIRGULA BrasilVIRGULA [Inglês] Anurans of remnants of Atlantic forest of São José do Barreiro municipalityVIRGULA São Paulo StateVIRGULA Brazil
column5: [Português] O município de São José do Barreiro (SP)VIRGULA localizado no domínio da Floresta AtlânticaVIRGULA em altitudes que oscilam entre 480 e 2088 mVIRGULA apresenta grande complexidade topográfica e climáticaVIRGULA que resulta na presença de inúmeras fitofisionomiasVIRGULA como os Campos de altitudeVIRGULA Floresta Estacional Semidecidual e Florestas Ombrófilas Densa e Mista. O objetivo deste estudo foi verificar a riqueza de espécies de anuros em duas áreas deste município: uma de Floresta Estacional Semidecidual e outra de Floresta Ombrófila Densa. Foram realizadas buscas ativas diurnas e noturnasVIRGULA entre abril de 2004 e dezembro de 2006. O inventário resultou no registro de 35 espécies de anuros de nove famílias. A riqueza de espécies observada na área de estudo é similar a de outras localidades consideradas preservadas como a Estação Ecológica Juréia-Itatins (PeruíbeVIRGULA SP) e a Serra do Japi (Jundiaí-SP). A similaridade na composição de espécies de sete localidades no Estado de São Paulo foi associada à fisionomia da vegetação das áreas amostradas. A grande variação de altitudeVIRGULA a presença de diferentes formações vegetais e o pouco conhecimento da fauna localVIRGULA torna o inventário da sua anurofauna de suma importância para estudos futuros de conservação destas espécies. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The municipality of São José do Barreiro (SP) located in the Atlantic Forest DomainVIRGULA at elevations between 480 and 2088 m above sea levelVIRGULA exhibit ample topografic and climatic complexity that result in the presence of severals phytophysionomies with High Mountain GrasslandsVIRGULA Seasonal Semideciduous ForestVIRGULA Tropical RainforestVIRGULA and Araucaria Forest. The aim of this study was to verify the anuran species richness in two different forest habitats in this areaVIRGULA one in a Seasonal Semideciduous Forest and the other in a Tropical Rainforest. Animals were collected by active search from April 2004 to December 2006. In the studied periodVIRGULA we registered 35 anuran species in nine families. The anuran richness observed in the studied region is similar to other localities considered preservedVIRGULA as the Estação Ecológica Juréia-Itatins (PeruíbeVIRGULA SP) and Serra do Japi (Jundiaí-SP). The similarity in species composition among seven localities in Atlantic Forest in São Paulo state was associated to the vegetal types of the studied areas. The ample altitude variationVIRGULA the presence of different types of vegetationVIRGULA and the little knowledge of the local fauna in this regionVIRGULA make the surveys very important to support future studies on species conservation. (AU)

column4: [Português] Avaliação de mutagenicidade e antimutagenicidade de diferentes frações de Pterogyne nitens (Leguminosae)VIRGULA utilizando ensaio de micronúcleo em Tradescantia pallidaVIRGULA [Inglês] Evaluation of mutagenicity and antimutagenicity of different fractions of Pterogyne nitens (Leguminosae)VIRGULA using Tradescantia pallida micronuclei assay
column5: [Português] Pterogyne nitens (Fabaceae-Caesalpinioideae) é uma árvore nativa da América do SulVIRGULA onde é empregada na medicina popular para o tratamento da ascaridíase. RecentementeVIRGULA descrevemos o efeito mutagênico do extrato etanólico das folhas de P. nitens. Dessa formaVIRGULA o presente estudo teve por objetivo aprofundar a avaliação do potencial mutagênico das frações isoladas das folhas de Pterogyne nitensVIRGULA acetato de etila (AcOEt)VIRGULA n-butanólica (BuOH) e hidroalcóolica (HA). Quando o efeito mutagênico foi observado somente nas maiores concentrações testadasVIRGULA o potencial antimutagênico também foi avaliado. Os ensaios mutagênicos e antimutagênicos foram realizados utilizando ensaio de micronúcleo em Trandescantia pallida. Na avaliação de mutagenicidadeVIRGULA observou-se o efeito nas frações AcOEt (0VIRGULA460 mg/mL)VIRGULA BuOH (0VIRGULA142VIRGULA 0VIRGULA285VIRGULA 0VIRGULA570 e 1VIRGULA14 mg/mL) e HA (0VIRGULA050VIRGULA 0VIRGULA100VIRGULA 0VIRGULA200 e 0VIRGULA400 mg/mL). Considerando que o efeito mutagênico da fração AcOEt foi observado somente na concentração mais elevada (0VIRGULA460 mg/mL)VIRGULA o potencial antimutagênico da mesma foi avaliado. As concentrações de 0VIRGULA115 e 0VIRGULA230 mg/mL da fração AcOEt demonstraram atividade antimutagênica. A partir dos resultados do presente estudoVIRGULA conclui-se que determinadas frações de P. nitens apresentam mutagenicidade (BuOH e HA)VIRGULA enquanto a fração AcOEt apresentou efeito antimutagênico nas maiores concentrações. Esses resultados tornam o estudo da P. nitens bastante promissorVIRGULA considerando que esta planta possui distribuição geográfica ampla e tem sido pouco estudada. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] Pterogyne nitens (Fabaceae-Caesalpinioideae) is a tree native to South AmericanVIRGULA where it is used in folk treatment of ascaridiasis. RecentlyVIRGULA we have been describing the mutagenic effect of the ethanol extract of leaves of P. nitens. ThusVIRGULA the present study aimed at evaluating the mutagenic potential of the ethyl acetate (EtOAc)VIRGULA n- butanol (BuOH) and hydroalcoholic (HA) fractions. When the mutagenic effect was observed only in the highest tested concentrationsVIRGULA the antimutagenic activity was also evaluated. Both mutagenic and antimutagenic assays were performed using T. pallida micronuclei assay. Mutagenicity was observed between different concentrations of the P nitens fractionsVIRGULA EtOAc (0.460 mg/mL)VIRGULA BuOH (0.142VIRGULA 0.285VIRGULA 0.570 and 1.14 mg/mL) and HA (0.050VIRGULA 0.100VIRGULA 0.200 and 0.400 mg/mL). Whereas the mutagenic effect of the EtOAc fraction was observed in the highest concentration (0.460 mg/mL)VIRGULA its antimutagenic potential was evaluated. The 0.115 and 0.230 mg/mL concentrations of the EtOAc fraction demonstrated antimutagenic activity. Based on the results of the present study we can conclude that some P. nitens fractions (BuOH and HA) demonstrated mutagenic effects whereas the EtOAc fraction shown low mutagenicity and amtimutagenicity in the two higher concentrations. Those results stimulate the studies with P. nitensVIRGULA which possess spread geographic distribution and it is still low studied. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] New species of Astyanax (Ostariophysi: Characiforms: Characidae) from the Upper Rio Paraná SystemVIRGULA Brazil.
column5: [Inglês] Astyanax bockmanniVIRGULA a new species of characidVIRGULA is widespread in streams in the upper Rio Paraná system of centralVIRGULA southeasternVIRGULA and southern Brazil. Samples of the species were identified by previous authors as A. eigenmanniorumVIRGULA a species originally described from far southern Brazil. Astyanax bockmanni differs from A. eigenmanniorum and all congeners in the combination of morphometricVIRGULA meristicVIRGULA and pigmentary features and details of oral dentition. Uncertainties concerning the generic placement of Astyanax paranahybae are discussedVIRGULA and it is proposed that the species is a member of a clade within the Characidae that does not include Astyanax. (AU)VIRGULA [Português] Astyanax bockmanniVIRGULA uma nova espécie de caracídeoVIRGULA é amplamente distribuída em riachos do Alto Rio ParanáVIRGULA nas regiões centro-oesteVIRGULA sudeste e sul do Brasil. Amostras dessa espécie foram previamente identificadas por diversos autores como A. eigenmanniorumVIRGULA uma espécie originalmente descrita do extremo sul do Brasil. Astyanax bockmanni difere de A. eigenmanniorum e demais congêneres por uma combinação de caracteres morfométricos e de pigmentaçãoVIRGULA além de detalhes da dentição oral. Incertezas quanto ao posicionamento genérico de Astyanax paranahybae são discutidas e propõe-se que a espécie seja membro de um clado de Characidae que não inclui Astyanax. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Priority areas for the conservation of Atlantic Forest large mammals
column5: [Inglês] Large mammal faunas in tropical forest landscapes are widely affected by habitat fragmentation and huntingVIRGULA yet the environmental determinants of their patterns of abundance remain poorly understood at large spatial scales. We analysed population abundance and biomass of 31 species of medium to large-bodied mammal species at 38 Atlantic forest sites (including three islandsVIRGULA 26 forest fragments and six continuous forest sites) as related to forest typeVIRGULA level of hunting pressure and forest fragment size using ANCOVAs. We also derived a novel measure of mammal conservation importance for each site based on a &#8220PONTOCOMMAMammalian Conservation Priority index&#8221PONTOCOMMA (MPi) which incorporates information on species richnessVIRGULA population abundanceVIRGULA body size distributionVIRGULA conservation statusVIRGULA and forest patch area. Mammal abundance was affected by hunting pressureVIRGULA whereas mammalian biomass of which was largely driven by ungulatesVIRGULA was significantly influenced by both forest type and hunting pressure. The MPi indexVIRGULA when separated into its two main components (i.e. site forest area and species-based conservation index Ci)VIRGULA ordered sites along a gradient of management priorities that balances species-focused and habitat-focused conservation actions. Areas with the highest conservation priority were located in semi-deciduous forest fragmentsVIRGULA followed by lowland forests. Many of these fragmentsVIRGULA which are often embedded within large private landholdings including biofuel and citrus or coffee cropsVIRGULA cattle ranches and pulpwood plantationsVIRGULA could be used not only to comply with environmental legislationVIRGULA but also enhance the prospects for biodiversity conservationVIRGULA and reduce edge effects and hunting. (AU)

column4: [Português] Predação de ninhos artificiais em uma ilha na Mata Atlântica: testando o local e o tipo de ovoVIRGULA [Inglês] Artificial nest predation in Atlantic Forest Island: testing the place and the different types of egg
column5: [Português] Experimentos com ninhos artificiais são utilizados para testar hipóteses ecológicas e comportamentais que influenciam na predação de ninhos naturais. O tamanho do ovoVIRGULA a textura da casca e a cor podem influenciar na taxa de predaçãoVIRGULA porém poucos estudos avaliam qual modelo de ovo é o mais adequado para simular a predação de ninhos em áreas tropicais. O objetivo deste trabalho foi comparar a predação de diferentes modelos de ovos (ovos de codornaVIRGULA massa de modelar e canários) no solo e a 1VIRGULA30 m de altura no sub-bosque. O experimento foi realizado Ilha AnchietaVIRGULA UbatubaVIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA Brasil. Foi encontrada uma diferença significativa na taxa de predação entre os ovos de codorna (71VIRGULA87%) e sintéticos (93VIRGULA75%) e entre os ovos de codorna e de canário (100%) no solo. EntretantoVIRGULA não houve diferença significativa entre os ovos sintéticos e de canário. Os ninhos no sub-bosque apresentaram um padrão diferenciado do solo quando se refere aos ovos de codorna (25%) e sintéticos (28VIRGULA1%)VIRGULA mas houve diferenças significativas quando os ovos de canário foram comparados com os ovos sintéticos e de codorna. Nosso trabalho demonstrou que diferentes tipos de ovos sobre uma mesma pressão de mesopredadores apresentaram taxas de predação diferentes. PortantoVIRGULA estudos que avaliam o sucesso reprodutivo da avifauna baseado na predação de ninhos artificiais devem considerar a utilização de diferentes tipos de ovos e estratos na vegetação. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] Experiments on artificial nests are usually used to test ecological hypothesis and behavioural that affects the predation of natural bird nests. It is has been discussed about the size of the eggVIRGULA texture and color affecting predation rateVIRGULA but a few studies evaluate which egg type is more appropriate to simulate nest predation in tropical areas. The objective of this work was to compare the predation of different models of eggs (Coturnix coturnixVIRGULA plasticine and Serinus canarius) on the ground and understory in a island with high abundance of nest predators. The study was carry out in October 2004 at Anchieta IslandVIRGULA UbatubaVIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA Brazil. The nests on the ground showed a statistical significance difference in the predation of quail eggsVIRGULA plasticine and canary eggs. HoweverVIRGULA we did not find differences between plasticine and canaries eggs. The nests in the understory had a different pattern on the ground of quail eggs (25%) and plasticine (28%) and there was a difference when we compare canary eggs with plasticine and quail eggs. Our work pointed out that different eggs may have different predation rates. ThereforeVIRGULA studies that evaluate reproductive fitness of the bird community based on artificial nests must considered different egg types and strata. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Density and population size of mammals introduced on a land-bridge island in southeastern Brazil
column5: [Inglês] The introduction of alien species is one of the main threats to the conservation of native speciesVIRGULA especially in island ecosystems. HereVIRGULA we report on the population growth of 15 species of mammals introduced in 1983 on the island of AnchietaVIRGULA an 828 ha land-bridge island in southeastern Brazil. We estimated the density of mammals through 296 km of line transect census. Five species introduced became extinct (coypuVIRGULA brocket deerVIRGULA six-banded armadilloVIRGULA nine-banded armadilloVIRGULA maned three-toed sloth)PONTOCOMMA six became overabundant (marmosetVIRGULA coatiVIRGULA agoutiVIRGULA seven-banded armadilloVIRGULA and capybara)PONTOCOMMA one has a stable population (capuchin monkey). Anchieta Island has the highest density of mammals in the entire Atlantic forest (486.77 ind/km2)VIRGULA especially nest predators (232.83 ind/km2) and herbivores (253.58 ind/km2). Agoutis (Dasyprocta spp.) and marmosets (Callithrix penicillata) wereVIRGULA by farVIRGULA the species with the highest population growth. The high density of mammals in this island may have strong consequences for plant recruitment and bird diversity. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Phytotoxic catechin leached by seeds of the tropical weed Sesbania virgata
column5: [Inglês] Sesbania virgata (Cav.) Pers (wand riverhemp) is a fast-growing tropical legume species that has been used for revegetation of riparian forests and rehabilitation of degraded areas and that exhibits an invasive behavior in certain regions of Brazil. Preliminary studies have shown that seed leachates inhibit the germination and development of seedlings of some crop species. In this studyVIRGULA we report that the seed leachates of S. virgata inhibit the growth of Arabidopsis thaliana and rice. The flavonoid (+)-catechin is found in high amounts in these leachates. It was active at concentrations of 50 &#956PONTOCOMMAg ml&#8722PONTOCOMMA1VIRGULA and its effect was not distinguishable from the (+)-catechin obtained from a commercial source. We found that (+)-catechin is located in the seed coat and is rapidly released in high concentrations (235 &#956PONTOCOMMAg per seed) at the beginning of imbibition. Quercetin was also detected in the seed coat of S. virgataVIRGULA but it was not released from the seeds. Other phytotoxic compounds in the seed leachates were also detected. The fact that S. virgata releases high amounts of (+)-catechinVIRGULA which also has antimicrobial activityVIRGULA and other phytotoxins from its seeds at the earliest stages of its development might represent some adaptative advantage to the seedling that contributes to its invasive behavior and successful establishment in different soils. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Purification and properties of exo-inulinases from Penicillium janczewskii growing on distinct carbon sources
column5: [Inglês] Penicillium janczewskiiVIRGULA isolated from the rhizosphere of Vernonia herbaceaVIRGULA grows rapidly on media containing either sucrose or inulinVIRGULA although inulin more than sucrose induced the production of inulinases. Three different extracellular ß-fructofuranosidases (two inulinases and one invertase) were purified from fungal cultures grown on sucrose or inulinVIRGULA through precipitation with ammonium sulfateVIRGULA and anion-exchangeVIRGULA hydrophobic interaction and gel filtration chromatographies. The optimum temperature of the three enzymes was approximately 60 CVIRGULA optimum pH 4&#8211PONTOCOMMA5.5 and apparent molecular mass of 80 kDa. Km and Vmax values determined for invertase on sucrose were respectively 3.7 10&#8211PONTOCOMMA4 M and 7.9 10&#8211PONTOCOMMA2 µmol/min/mLVIRGULA and on inulin 6.3 10&#8211PONTOCOMMA2 M and 2.09 10&#8211PONTOCOMMA2 µmol/min/mL. The values of km for the two inulinases were 8.11 10&#8211PONTOCOMMA4 and 2.62 10&#8211PONTOCOMMA3 MVIRGULA being lower for inulin when compared to those obtained for sucrose. The inulinases did not produce oligofructans from inulinVIRGULA indicating they are primarily exoinulinases. The differences found in inulinase induction patterns when inulin or sucrose was used seem to be related to modifications on the enzyme propertiesVIRGULA mainly concerning substrate affinity. (AU)

column4: [Português] Diversidade e distribuição espaço-temporal de anuros em região com pronunciada estação seca no sudeste do BrasilVIRGULA [Inglês] Temporal and spatial distribution and diversity of anurans in a region with pronounced dry season in southeastern Brazil
column5: [Inglês] Anthropic activities have deeply changed natural environments and constantly affected the diversity and distribution of anurans. This study aimed to investigate the following questions: (1) What is the frogs composition in a pasture region with a pronounced seasonal climate in extreme northwest of the state of São Paulo? (2) How are adults and tadpoles of the species distributed temporally and spatially? (3) Is species richness correlated to descriptors of reproductive habitats heterogeneity? In the study site 20 anuran species were recordedVIRGULA distributed in 11 genus of four families: Leptodactylidae (9)VIRGULA Hylidae (8)VIRGULA Microhylidae (2) and Bufonidae (1). From theseVIRGULA Chaunus schneideri (WernerVIRGULA 1894)VIRGULA Physalaemus centralis BokermannVIRGULA 1962 and Physalaemus fuscomaculatus (SteindachnerVIRGULA 1864) were recorded only by tadpoles collectionVIRGULA whereas Dendropsophus minutus (PetersVIRGULA 1872) and Leptodactylus labyrinthicus (SpixVIRGULA 1824) occurred only in water bodies next to the studied ones. The recorded species are known by their ample geographic distribution and for colonizing disturbed areas in other localities. There was no correlation between species richness and structural complexity of water bodies. HoweverVIRGULA the greater richness was recorded in temporary water bodies that kept water more than six months throughout the year. The temporary ponds of unstable hydroperiod were colonized initially by leptodactylidsVIRGULA while the permanent or temporary ponds were colonized by hylids. The vocalization and reproductive activity of most species were restricted to the warm and rainy period of the yearVIRGULA a typical pattern of communities in the tropical seasonal regions. Five species [Chaunus schneideriVIRGULA Dendropsophus nanus (BoulengerVIRGULA 1889)VIRGULA Hypsiboas albopunctatus SpixVIRGULA 1824VIRGULA Leptodactylus podicipinus (CopeVIRGULA 1862) and Pseudopaludicola aff. saltica (CopeVIRGULA 1887)] vocalized during the dry and rainy seasonsVIRGULA but only C. schneideri and H. albopunctatus reproduced during the dry season. The weak spatial and temporal segregationVIRGULA recorded to adults and tadpolesVIRGULA is not enough to explain reproductive isolation among species. Other factorsVIRGULA like acoustic segregation and calling site segregationVIRGULA may have major importance to explain species coexistence. Climatic severity (wide and pronounced dry seasonVIRGULA unpredictability and inconstancy of rains in the beginning of the rainy season)VIRGULA along with the high level of natural habitat being converted in cultivated areas areVIRGULA probablyVIRGULA the factors responsible for the predominance of species typical from disturbed areas. (AU)VIRGULA [Português] As atividades antrópicas têm alterado profundamente os ambientes naturais e muitas vezes afetado a diversidade e distribuição dos anuros. O objetivo deste estudo foi investigar as seguintes questões: (1) qual a composição da anurofauna em uma região de pastagem com clima marcadamente sazonal no extremo noroeste paulista? (2) como adultos e girinos das espécies se distribuem temporal e espacialmente? (3) a riqueza de espécies está correlacionada com descritores da heterogeneidade dos hábitats de reprodução? Na área estudada foram registradas 20 espécies de anurosVIRGULA distribuídas em 11 gêneros de quatro famílias: Leptodactylidae (9)VIRGULA Hylidae (8)VIRGULA Microhylidae (2) e Bufonidae (1). DestasVIRGULA Chaunus schneideri (WernerVIRGULA 1894)VIRGULA Physalaemus centralis BokermannVIRGULA 1962 e Physalaemus fuscomaculatus (SteindachnerVIRGULA 1864) foram registradas apenas por coleta de girinosVIRGULA enquanto Dendropsophus minutus (PetersVIRGULA 1872) e Leptodactylus labyrinthicus (SpixVIRGULA 1824) ocorreram somente em corpos d'água próximos aos selecionados. As espécies registradas são conhecidas por sua ampla distribuição geográfica e por colonizarem áreas alteradas em outras localidades. Não houve correlação entre a riqueza de espécies e a complexidade estrutural dos corpos d'água. EntretantoVIRGULA a maior riqueza de espécies foi registrada nos corpos d'água de longa duração. As poças temporárias de hidroperíodo instável foram colonizadas inicialmente por leptodactilídeosVIRGULA enquanto que as poças permanentes ou temporárias estáveis foram colonizadas por hilídeos. A atividade de vocalização e de reprodução da maioria das espécies foi restrita ao período quente e chuvoso do anoVIRGULA um padrão típico de ambientes tropicais sazonais. Cinco espécies [Chaunus schneideriVIRGULA Dendropsophus nanus (BoulengerVIRGULA 1889)VIRGULA Hypsiboas albopunctatus SpixVIRGULA 1824VIRGULA Leptodactylus podicipinus (CopeVIRGULA 1862) e Pseudopaludicola aff. saltica (CopeVIRGULA 1887)] vocalizaram durante a estação seca e chuvosaVIRGULA mas apenas C. schneideri e H. albopunctatus se reproduziram durante o período seco. A fraca partilha espacial e temporalVIRGULA registrada para adultos e girinosVIRGULA não foi suficiente para explicar o isolamento reprodutivo entre as espécies. Outros fatoresVIRGULA como a partilha acústica e a segregação dos sítios de vocalizaçãoVIRGULA podem ter maior importância para explicar a coexistência das espécies. A severidade climática (extensa e pronunciada estação secaVIRGULA imprevisibilidade e inconstância das chuvas no início da estação chuvosa)VIRGULA juntamente com o elevado grau de conversão do hábitat natural em áreas de cultivo sãoVIRGULA provavelmenteVIRGULA os fatores responsáveis pelo predomínio de espécies conhecidas por colonizar com sucesso áreas antrópicas em outras regiões do país. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] A new species of Baurusuchus (CrocodyliformesVIRGULA Mesoeucrocodylia) from the Upper Cretaceous of BrazilVIRGULA with the first complete postcranial skeleton described for the family Baurusuchidae
column5: [Português] O presente trabalho descreve uma espécie nova de Baurusuchidae proveniente de sedimentos do Cretáceo Superior da Bacia BauruVIRGULA no Estado de São PauloVIRGULA fornecendo a primeira descrição de um esqueleto pós-craniano completo para a família. Muitas características pós-cranianas da nova espécie estão presentes em outros táxons de Notosuchia gondwânicos e sãoVIRGULA desta formaVIRGULA consideradas plesiomórficas para o gênero. Entre estas se destacam: espinhas neurais cervicais muito longasPONTOCOMMA três vértebras sacraisPONTOCOMMA crista deltopeitoral do úmero robustaPONTOCOMMA porção proximal do radiale com grande área de contato para a ulnaPONTOCOMMA ulnare com projeção anterior distalPONTOCOMMA crista supra-acetabular bem desenvolvida lateralmentePONTOCOMMA processo pós-acetabular póstero-dorsalmente direcionadoPONTOCOMMA presença de uma crista crânio-medial no fêmurPONTOCOMMA quarto trocânter do fêmur em uma posição posteriorPONTOCOMMA diáfise da tíbia lateralmente curvadaPONTOCOMMA tubérculo do calcâneo orientado póstero-ventralmentePONTOCOMMA osteodermas ornamentados com sulcos e imbricados na região caudal. ContudoVIRGULA alguns caracteres são inéditosVIRGULA sendo ausentes nas demais famílias de Crocodyliformes. Estes são: processos transversos das vértebras sacrais direcionados dorsolateralmentePONTOCOMMA presença de uma crista longitudinal na superfície lateral das vértebras sacraisPONTOCOMMA presença de uma superfície semelhante a um côndilo no carpal pisiforme. A maioria destas características corrobora um padrão de locomoção cursorial para a espécie descrita neste trabalhoVIRGULA e para a família Baurusuchidae. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The present work describes a new species of Baurusuchidae from Upper Cretaceous sediments of the Bauru BasinVIRGULA and provides the first complete postcranial description for the family. Many postcranial features observed in the new species are also present in other notosuchian taxaVIRGULA and are thus considered plesiomorphic for the genus. These are: long cervical neural spinesPONTOCOMMA robust deltopectoral crest of the humerusPONTOCOMMA large proximal portion in the radiale that contacts the ulnaPONTOCOMMA ulnare anterior distal projectionPONTOCOMMA supra-acetabular crest well developed laterallyPONTOCOMMA post-acetabular process posterodorsally deflectedPONTOCOMMA presence of an anteromedial crest in the femurPONTOCOMMA fourth trocanter of femur posteriorly positionedPONTOCOMMA tibia with a laterally curved shaftPONTOCOMMA calcaneum tuber posteroventrally orientedPONTOCOMMA osteoderms ornamented with grooves and imbricated in the tail. On the other handVIRGULA we found the following sacral and carpal features to be unique among all mesoeucrocodylians analyzed: transverse processes of sacral vertebrae dorsolaterally deflectedPONTOCOMMA presence of a longitudinal crest in the lateral surface of sacral vertebraePONTOCOMMA pisiform carpal with a condyle-like surface. The majority of these cited features corroborates a cursorial locomotion for the new species described in the present studyVIRGULA suggesting that members of the family Baurusuchidae were also cursorial species. (AU)

column4: [Português] Distribuição espacial e temporal de uma comunidade de anfíbios anuros do município de Rio ClaroVIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA BrasilVIRGULA [Inglês] Temporal and spatial distribution in an anuran community in municipality of Rio ClaroVIRGULA SPVIRGULA Brazil
column5: [Português] A compreensão da composição e inter-relações das comunidades faunísticas são fundamentais para a execução de medidas conservacionistas em ambientes florestais. No presente estudo nos avaliamos a comunidade de anfíbios de uma floresta estadual no município de Rio ClaroVIRGULA SPVIRGULA com enfoque na biologia reprodutiva. Foram registradas 21 espéciesVIRGULA de quarto famílias: BufonidaeVIRGULA HylidaeVIRGULA Leptodactylidae e Microhylidae. As espécies da família Bufonidae reproduziram durante a estação fria e seca do ano e as demais somente durante a estação quente e chuvosa. Além de segregação temporalVIRGULA algumas espécies dividiram o ambiente físico durante o período reprodutivo. Acentuada sobreposição temporal e espacial foi observada entre espécies filogeneticamente próximasVIRGULA como entre Hyla nana e H. sanborniVIRGULA entre Scinax fuscovarius e Scinax sp. (aff. similis)VIRGULA e entre Leptodactylus fuscusVIRGULA L. mystacinusVIRGULA e Leptodactylus sp. (gr. fuscus). Nestes casosVIRGULA diferenças acústicas podem ter sido o principal fator responsável pela segregação reprodutiva. Ausência de segregação reprodutiva foi observada entre espécies do gênero BufoVIRGULA as quais foram vistas em amplexo interespecíficoVIRGULA apesar das diferenças acústicas entre seus cantos de anúncio. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The comprehension of structure and functioning of communities are fundamental for the execution of conservation efforts in forested areas. In the present study we evaluated a community of anurans in a State Forest in Southeast BrazilVIRGULA emphasizing the reproductive biology of the species. It has been found 21 speciesVIRGULA of four families: BufonidaeVIRGULA HylidaeVIRGULA LeptodactylidaeVIRGULA and Microhylidae. The species of the family Bufonidae reproduced during the dry and cold seasonVIRGULA while other species reproduced only during the wet and warm season of the year. Besides temporal segregationVIRGULA some species divided the physical environment during reproductive season. Strong temporal and spatial overlap was observed among phylogenetically close species (of the same genus)VIRGULA such as Hyla nana and H. sanborniVIRGULA Scinax fuscovarius and Scinax sp. (aff. similis)VIRGULA and Leptodactylus fuscusVIRGULA L. mystacinusVIRGULA and Leptodactylus sp. (gr. fuscus). In these casesVIRGULA acoustic differences may be the main factor responsible for the reproductive segregation. Lack of reproductive segregation was observed among species of the genus BufoVIRGULA which were found in interespecific amplexusVIRGULA even with acoustic differences in their advertisement calls. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Comparative cytogenetic analysis on four tree frog species (AnuraVIRGULA HylidaeVIRGULA Hylinae) from Brazil
column5: [Inglês] A comparative cytogenetic analysis was carried out on four Hylinae tree frogs from Brazil (Aparasphenodon brunoiVIRGULA Corythomantis greeningiVIRGULA Osteocephalus langsdorffiiVIRGULA and Scinax fuscovarius) using Giemsa stainingVIRGULA BrdU replication bandingVIRGULA Ag-NOR stainingVIRGULA C-bandingVIRGULA DAPI and CMA3 fluorochrome stainingVIRGULA and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) with an rDNA probe. All the species share closely similar 2n = 24 karyotypesVIRGULA almost indistinguishable by standard staining. The technique of BrdU incorporation allowed the identification of each pair of homologs and the establishment of extensive homeology for the great majority of the chromosomesVIRGULA mainly of A. brunoiVIRGULA C. greeningiVIRGULA and O. langsdorffii. Despite highly conserved replication banding patternsVIRGULA the use of the other banding techniques disclosed some minor differencesVIRGULA which reinforces the importance of extensive cytogenetic analyses for the karyotypic characterization of Anuran species. column4: [Inglês] Phylogeny of the Nymphalidae (Lepidoptera)
column5: [Inglês] A generic-level phylogeny for the butterfly family Nymphalidae was produced by cladistic analysis of 234 characters from all life stages. The 95 species in the matrix (selected from the 213 studied) represent all important recognized lineages within this family. The analysis showed the taxa grouping into six main lineages. The basal branch is the LibytheinaeVIRGULA with the Danainae and Ithomiinae on the next branch. The remaining lineages are grouped into two main branches: the Heliconiinae-NymphalinaeVIRGULA primarily flower-visitors (but including the fruit-attracted Coeini)PONTOCOMMA and the Limenitidinae (sensu strictu)VIRGULA BiblidinaeVIRGULA and the satyroid lineage (ApaturinaeVIRGULA CharaxinaeVIRGULA BiinaeVIRGULA CalinaginaeVIRGULA MorphinaeVIRGULA BrassolinaeVIRGULA and Satyrinae)VIRGULA primarily fruit-attracted. Data partitions showed that the two data sets (immatures and adults) are very differentVIRGULA and a partitioned Bremer support analysis showed that the adult characters are the main source of conflict in the nodes of the combined analysis tree. This phylogeny includes the widest taxon coverage of any morphological study on Nymphalid butterflies to dateVIRGULA and supports the monophyly and relationships of most presently recognized subgroupsVIRGULA providing strong evidence for the presently accepted phylogenetic scheme. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Geographical distribution of Eupatorieae (Asteraceae) in South-eastern and South Brazilian Mountain Ranges
column5: [Inglês] This study deals with the geographical distribution of Eupatorieae species in South-eastern and Southern Brazilian mountain rangesVIRGULA with special emphasis on the Mantiqueira range Serra da Mantiqueira. In the Mantiqueira rangeVIRGULA five localities were sampled for two years during the flowering period of the plants. Species composition in the Mantiqueira localities was then compared to data from a central range the Espinhaço and a southern coastal range. Cluster and ordination analyses showed clear floristic differences among the three ranges. Nearer localities were more similar floristically only within the Espinhaço range and across all rangesVIRGULA as shown by Mantel tests. The dendrogram in the Mantiqueira range clustered Itatiaia and Campos do JordãoVIRGULA two non-adjacent localities with similar environmentVIRGULA landscape and topography. Different processes may be influencing the structure and composition of the Eupatorieae flora at different geographical scales. Historical and biogeographical processes may be more important in determining community composition of different mountain rangesVIRGULA whereas factors such as climate and human impact may be determining differences among localities within each mountain range. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Ant-plant-herbivore interactions in the neotropical cerrado savanna
column5: [Inglês] The Brazilian cerrado savanna covers nearly 2 million km2 and has a high incidence on foliage of various liquid food sources such as extrafloral nectar and insect exudates. These liquid rewards generate intense ant activity on cerrado foliageVIRGULA making ant-plant-herbivore interactions especially prevalent in this biome. We present data on the distribution and abundance of extrafloral nectarines in the woody flora of cerrado communities and in the flora of other habitats worldwideVIRGULA and stress the relevance of liquid food sources (including hemipteran honeydew) for the ant fauna. Consumption by ants of plant and insect exudates significantly affects the activity of the associated herbivores of cerrado plant speciesVIRGULA with varying impacts on the reproductive output of the plants. Experiments with an ant-plant-butterfly system unequivocally demonstrate that the behavior of both immature and adult lepidopterans is closely related to the use of a risky host plantVIRGULA where intensive visitation by ants can have a severe impact on caterpillar survival. We discuss recent evidence suggesting that the occurrence of liquid rewards on leaves plays a key role in mediating the foraging ecology of foliage-dwelling antsVIRGULA and that facultative ant-plant mutualisms are important in structuring the community of canopy arthropods. Ant-mediated effects on cerrado herbivore communities can be revealed by experiments performed on wide spatial scalesVIRGULA including many environmental factors such as soil fertility and vegetation structure. We also present some research questions that could be rewarding to investigate in this major neotropical savanna. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Small-scale spatial autocorrelation and the interpretation of relationships between phenological parameters
column5: [Inglês] Question: Are flower production and associated phenological variables (onsetVIRGULA endVIRGULA durationVIRGULA and three measures of flowering synchrony) randomly distributed in space orVIRGULA alternativelyVIRGULA is there a neighbourhood structure (spatial autocorrelation) in the values of these variables? To which extent does spatial autocorrelation affect the correlation tests between phenological traits? Location: A tree savanna reserve in Southeastern Brazil (22°15'SVIRGULA 47°08'W). Methods: The flowering season of Chromolaena odorata was followed for all (96) individuals in a completely mapped area of 3000 m2. The phenological traits were estimated by counting flower heads in anthesis on individual plants every seven days for 14 weeks. Results: Flowering time was unimodally distributedVIRGULA but with different peak dates depending on whether individual flower heads or plants were counted. Three phenological traits and canopy closure above the plants showed some degree of spatial autocorrelationVIRGULA which caused loss of up to 35% of degrees of freedom in nine of 36 correlation tests. Such a decrease in the degrees of freedom resulted in loss of significance for correlations in three pairs of variables. Conclusions: We hypothesize that the spatial autocorrelation in phenological traits between C. odorata neighbours may be driven by genetic similarity among neighbouring plants and/or spatial structuring of environmental factors. Because location and distance between samples may affect their statistical independenceVIRGULA we suggest that spatial autocorrelation should be taken into account in future studies of plant phenologyVIRGULA e.g. by using effective sample size in statistical tests. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Comparing species richness among assemblages using sample units: why not use extrapolation methods to standardize different sample sizes?
column5: [Inglês] Comparisons of species richness among assemblages using different sample sizes may produce erroneous conclusions due to the strong positive relationship between richness and sample size. A current way of handling the problem is to standardize sample sizes to the size of the smallest sample in the study. A major criticism about this approach is the loss of information contained in the larger samples. A potential way of solving the problem is to apply extrapolation techniques to smaller samplesVIRGULA and produce an estimated species richness expected to occur if sample size were increased to the same size of the largest sample. We evaluated the reliability of 11 potential extrapolation methods over a range of different data sets and magnitudes of extrapolation. The basic approach adopted in the evaluation process was a comparison between the observed richness in a sample and the estimated richness produced by estimators using a sub-sample of the same sample. The Log-Series estimator was the most robust for the range of data sets and sub-sample sizes usedVIRGULA followed closely by Negative BinomialVIRGULA SO-J1VIRGULA LogarithmicVIRGULA Stout and VandermeerVIRGULA and Weibull estimators. When applied to a set of independently replicated samples from a species-rich assemblageVIRGULA 95% confidence intervals of estimates produced by the six best evaluated methods were comparable to those of observed richness in the samples. Performance of estimators tended to be better for species-rich data sets rather than for those which contained few species. Good estimates were found when extrapolating up to 1.8-2.0 times the size of the sample. We suggest that the use of the best evaluated methods within the range of indicated conditions provides a safe solution to the problem of losing information when standardizing different sample sizes to the size of the smallest sample. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Lophiobrycon weitzmaniVIRGULA a new genus and species of glandulocaudine fish (Characiformes: Characidae) from the Rio Grande drainageVIRGULA upper Rio Paraná systemVIRGULA southeastern Brazil
column5: [Inglês] A new genus and species of glandulocaudineVIRGULA Lophiobrycon weitzmaniVIRGULA is described based on specimens collected in headwater tributary streams of the rio GrandeVIRGULA upper rio Paraná systemVIRGULA State of Minas GeraisVIRGULA southeastern Brazil. The inclusion of the new species in the phylogeny of the subfamily Glandulocaudinae proposed by Weitzman & Menezes (1998)VIRGULA reveals a sister group relationship between the new genus and the monophyletic group composed of Glandulocauda and Mimagoniates that currently form the tribe Glandulocaudini. The new species can be readily distinguished from all other species of the tribe by the autapomorphic presence in adult male individuals (with more than 23.9 mm standard length) of an adipose-fin whose base extends for almost the entire distance between the posterior terminus of the base of the dorsal fin and the base of the upper lobe of the caudal fin and averages approximately 25% standard lengthVIRGULA along with the presence of globular expansions formed by the lepidotrichia and hypertrophied soft tissue in the middle portions of the first and second pectoral-fin rays. The diagnosis of the tribe Glandulocaudini is modified to accommodate the new genus. (AU)VIRGULA [Português] Um novo gênero e espécie de glandulocaudineVIRGULA Lophiobrycon weitzmaniVIRGULA é descrito com base em exemplares coletados em riachos de cabeceira da drenagem do rio GrandeVIRGULA sistema do alto rio ParanáVIRGULA estado de Minas GeraisVIRGULA sudeste do Brasil. A inclusão desta nova espécie na filogenia da subfamília GlandulocaudinaeVIRGULA proposta por Weitzman & Menezes (1998)VIRGULA revela uma relação de grupos irmãos entre o novo gênero e o grupo monofilético formado por Glandulocauda e MimagoniatesVIRGULA atualmente compondo a tribo Glandulocaudini. A nova espécie pode ser facilmente distinguida das demais da tribo pela posse autapomórficaVIRGULA nos machos adultos (com mais de 23VIRGULA9 mm de comprimento padrão)VIRGULA de uma nadadeira adiposa com a base estendendo-se por praticamente a totalidade da distância entre a terminação posterior da base da nadadeira dorsal e base do lobo caudal superiorVIRGULA equivalendo em média a aproximadamente 25% do comprimento padrãoVIRGULA juntamente com a presença de expansões globularesVIRGULA formadas por lepidotríquios e tecido mole hipertrofiadoVIRGULA na porção média do primeiro e segundo raios da nadadeira peitoral. A diagnose da tribo Glandulocaudini é modificada para acomodar o novo gênero. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Life cycle of Retracrus johnstoni Keifer (Acari: Phytoptidae)VIRGULA [Português] Ciclo de vida de Retracrus johnstoni Keifer (Acari: Phytoptidae)
column5: [Inglês] Eriophyoid mites are commonly associated to palm treesVIRGULA although few of them have been reported causing economic damage to those plants. One exception is Retracrus johnstoni KeiferVIRGULA a pest of Bactris gasipaes KunthVIRGULA plant used for palm heart production. R. jonhstoni is frequently found in large numbers on Arecaceae in southeast Brazil. The biology of this mite was studied under laboratory condition. Sections of leaves of the palm tree Syagrus romanzoffiana (Cham.) GlassmanVIRGULA with ca. 15 leafletsVIRGULA were kept alive by maintaining their bases in distilled water. Ca. 20 field collected adults of R. johnstoni were transferred onto each leaflet for oviposition. After 24hVIRGULA mites were removedVIRGULA leaving only one egg laid. Once a dayVIRGULA the eggs and the subsequent stages were examined to determine the life cycleVIRGULA oviposition rate and survivorship. Each immature stage of R. johnstoni lasted ca. seven daysVIRGULA corresponding to ca. 20.5 days for immature development. The sex ratio was ca. two females per male. Total fecundity was slightly over five eggs per female. Immature and adult mites secreted a layer of white materialVIRGULA which covered their bodies. Spermatophores of R. johnstoni resemble those of other species in the same superfamilyVIRGULA and consist of a head of ca. 6 x 6 µm onto a base ca. 6 µm long. Leaflets show dark spots on the lower surface and yellowish spots on the corresponding regions of the upper surface. Leaf spots become progressively larger and coalescentVIRGULA and the leaf dies and falls prematurely. (AU)VIRGULA [Português] Os ácaros Eriophyoidea estão comumente associados a palmeirasVIRGULA entretanto poucas espécies têm sido relatadas causando danos econômicos nessas plantas. Uma exceção é Retracrus johnstoni KeiferVIRGULA praga de Bactris gasipaes KunthVIRGULA planta utilizada na produção de palmito. R. johnstoni tem sido encontrado em grande número de arecáceas no Sudeste do Brasil. O objetivo deste trabalho foi estudar a biologia deste ácaro em laboratório. Seções de folhas da palmeira Syagrus romanzoffiana (Cham.) Glassman com cerca de 15 folíolos foram conservadas mantendo suas bases em água destilada. Aproximadamente 20 adultos de R. johnstoni foram transferidos para cada folíolo para oviposição. Após 24hVIRGULA os ácaros foram removidosVIRGULA deixando-se apenas um ovo por folíolo. Diariamente os ovos e os estágios subseqüentes foram examinados para determinação do ciclo de vidaVIRGULA taxa de oviposição e sobrevivência. Cada estágio imaturo de R. johnstoni teve duração de aproximadamente sete diasVIRGULA totalizando aproximadamente 20VIRGULA5 dias para o desenvolvimento de ovo a adulto. A razão sexual foi de aproximadamente duas fêmeas para cada macho. A fecundidade total foi de cinco ovos por fêmea. Formas imaturas e adultos eram cobertos por uma camada de material branco secretado por eles. O espermatóforo de R. johnstoni é semelhante ao de outras espécies da superfamíliaVIRGULA e consiste em uma cabeça de aproximadamente 6 x 6 µm e uma base de aproximadamente 6 µm de comprimento. Os danos apresentam-se como manchas escuras na superfície inferior e manchas amareladas nas regiões correspondentes da superfície. As manchas foliares aumentam progressivamenteVIRGULA coalescem e a folha morre e cai prematuramente. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Stigmaeidae mites (Acari: Raphignathoidea) from Arecaceae of the Atlantic Forest in São Paulo StateVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA [Português] Ácaros Stigmaeidae (Acari: Raphignathoidea) de Arecaceae da Mata Atlântica do estado de São Paulo
column5: [Português] Este trabalho registra os ácaros Stigmaeidae encontrados em plantas nativas da família Arecaceae em áreas da Mata Atlântica do estado de São Paulo. Foram realizadas quatro coletasVIRGULA uma em cada estaçãoVIRGULA no ano 2000 em CananéiaVIRGULA Pariquera-AçuVIRGULA Piracicaba e São PedroVIRGULA em nove espécies nativas de palmeiras. Duas espécies novas de Stigmaeidae foram encontradas e descritasVIRGULA Agistemus palmae sp. n. e Agistemus caissara sp. n. Com base em espécimes originários do estado de Mato GrossoVIRGULA estágios imaturos de Agistemus floridanus Gonzalez-RodriguezVIRGULA 1965 são descritos pela primeira vezVIRGULA enquanto machos e fêmeas adultas da mesma espécie são redescritos. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] This work reports the Stigmaeidae mites from native plants of the family ArecaceaeVIRGULA in areas of Atlantic Forest in the State of São Paulo. Samplings were conducted once in each season of the year 2000 in CananéiaVIRGULA Pariquera-AçuVIRGULA Piracicaba and São PedroVIRGULA on nine native species of palm trees. Two new species of Stigmaeidae were found and describedVIRGULA Agistemus palmae n. sp. and Agistemus caissara n. sp. Based on specimens from the State of Mato GrossoVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA immature stages of Agistemus floridanus Gonzalez-RodriguezVIRGULA 1965 are described for the first timeVIRGULA while adult males and females of the same species are redescribed. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Taxonomic review of the genus Thestylus simonVIRGULA 1880 (Scorpiones: Bothriuridae)
column5: [Espanhol] Se revisa el género Thestylus SimonVIRGULA 1880 (Scorpiones: Bothriuridae) y se reconocen dos especiesVIRGULA diferenciadas por caracteres de coloraciónVIRGULA morfología del hemiespermatóforo y el número de espinas ventrales en los tarsos de las patas. Thestylus glasioui lineatus GiltayVIRGULA 1928VIRGULA se sinonimiza con Thestylus glasioui (BertkauVIRGULA 1880)VIRGULA y se describe Thestylus aurantiurus sp. n. (localidad típica: BrasilVIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA SPVIRGULA Parque Estadual da Serra da Cantareira). Thestylus signatus Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA 1945VIRGULA cuyo holótipo está perdidoVIRGULA se considera como species inquirenda. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The genus Thestylus SimonVIRGULA 1880 (Scorpiones: Bothriuridae) was reviewed and two species were recognizedVIRGULA distinguished by characteristics of colorationVIRGULA hemispermatophore morphology and number of ventral spines on the leg tarsi. Thestylus glasioui lineatus GiltayVIRGULA 1928 is synonymized with Thestylus glasioui (BertkauVIRGULA 1880) and Thestylus aurantiurus sp. n. is described (type locality: BrazilVIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA SPVIRGULA Parque Estadual da Serra da Cantareira). Lectotype and paralectotype of Thestylus glasioui were designated in this paper. Thestylus signatus Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA 1945VIRGULA whose holotype is lostVIRGULA is considered as a species inquirenda. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Micropropagation of Anemopaegma arvense: conservation of an endangered medicinal plant
column5: [Inglês] Anemopaegma arvense (Vell.) Stellfeld ex de Souza is a medicinal species also known as Catuaba. All commercially available formulations of Catuaba have been produced from wild craftingVIRGULA the gathering of plant biomass from its native habitat. Nodal segments were used as explants and 4.8 new buds per explant were induced on MS media supplemented with 4.4 uM of kinetin in 30 days. The percentage of in vitro rooting was lowVIRGULA although acclimatization of unrooted plants into soil was successfully achieved. For germplasm maintenanceVIRGULA cultures of A. arvense were stored on 4 % (w/v) sorbitol and maintained viable at low growth rate without subcultures for six months. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Antinociceptive profile of (-)-spectaline: a piperidine alkaloid from Cassia leptophulla
column5: [Inglês] The antinociceptive activity of (-)-spectaline (1)VIRGULA a piperidine alkaloid isolated from Cassia leptophylla Vog. (Leguminosae)VIRGULA was investigated. We have also studied the acute oral toxicity of 1 in mice and it did not show any signals of toxicity in doses lower than 400 umol/kg. The antinociceptive effect of 1 was evaluated on chemical (acetic acidVIRGULA formalin and capsaicin) and thermal (hot plate and tail flick) pain models in miceVIRGULA using classical standard drugs. Dipyrone ID50 = 14.68 umol/kg (4.8 mg/kg)VIRGULA indomethacin ID50 = 0.78 umol/kg (0.28 mg/kg) and (-)-spectaline ID50 = 48.49 umol/kg (15.75 mg/kg)VIRGULA all produced a significant inhibition of acetic acid-induced abdominal writhing in mice. (-)-Spectaline was inactive in the hyperalgesic model of formalin and did not show any central analgesic activity (hot plate and tail flick models). In the capsaicin-induced neurogenic pain modelVIRGULA (-)-spectaline presented an important inhibitory effect with an ID50 = 20.81 ug/paw and dipyrone ID50 = 19.89 ug/paw. The ensemble of results permitted us to identify 1 as an antinociceptive compound. The mechanism underlying this antinociceptive effect of 1 remains unknownVIRGULA but the results suggest that such an effect could be related to pathways associated to vanilloid receptor systems. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Biology of catfishVIRGULA Trichomycterus sp. (PiscesVIRGULA Siluriformes)VIRGULA in a pristine stream in the Morro do Diabo State ParkVIRGULA southeastern Brazil
column5: [Inglês] The distributionVIRGULA activityVIRGULA dietVIRGULA and reproduction of an undescribed catfish species of the genus Trichomycterus (Trichomycteridae) were studied in the Morro do Diabo State ParkVIRGULA an important conservation area in the Rio Paranapanema basinVIRGULA State of São PauloVIRGULA southeastern Brazil. Trichomycterus sp. is a rheophilic species occurring solely in the riffle areas of the streams and hunts mostly immature aquatic insects during the day by picking them from the substrate. The population has a balanced sex ratioVIRGULA but females were uncommon in the smallest and largest size classes suggesting that females demonstrate a more accelerated growth pattern. Presence of mature individuals throughout the year represents an opportunistic reproductive tactic for fishes living in fast flowing watersVIRGULA where the clutches could be shifted by the currentVIRGULA but the high incidence of mature individuals in the wet season may be related to optimal environmental conditions for juveniles during that period. Because of the restriction of Trichomycterus sp. to riffle environmentsVIRGULA the conservation of this species depends on the maintenance of the original characteristics of these headwaters. That demands protecting the riparian vegetation and consequently the stream from excessive siltation resulting from runoff and erosion. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Description of a new reproductive mode in Leptodactylus (AnuraVIRGULA Leptodactylidae)VIRGULA with a review of the reproductive specialization toward terrestriality in the genus
column5: [Inglês] The genus Leptodactylus provides an example among anurans in which there is an evident tendency toward terrestrial reproduction. Herein we describe a new reproductive mode for the frog Leptodactylus podicipinusVIRGULA a member of the melanonotus group. This new reproductive mode represents one of the intermediate steps from the most aquatic to the most terrestrial modes reported in the genus. Three reproductive modes were previously recognized for the genus Leptodactylus. HoweverVIRGULA based on our dataVIRGULA and on several studies on Leptodactylus species that have been published since the last reviewsVIRGULA we propose a new classificationVIRGULA with the addition of two modes for the genus. (AU)

column5: [Inglês] This text reflects my experience in rearing chironomids in Brazil. Just after sortingVIRGULA the larvae were isolated in small vials in order to be sure about the associations. The vials stayed open and as soon as the larvae became pupaeVIRGULA the larval exuviae was fixed and the pupa transferred to a larger container with a lower superficial tension (provided by the superficial area) so they could emerge. The vials suggested by EPLER (1995PONTOCOMMA 2001) and by MERRITVIRGULA RESH & CUMMINS (1996) werent efficient for most of the chironomids Ive tried unsuccessfully to rear. (AU)
