column5: [Inglês] A comparative study of butterfly communities in 15 urban/suburban remnants of tropical semideciduous forest in Campinas (São Paulo stateVIRGULA SE BrazilPONTOCOMMA 24°SVIRGULA 47°W)VIRGULA with areas from 1.0 to 252 ha and widely varying histories and environmentsVIRGULA shows that the most significant factorsVIRGULA besides area and sampling timeVIRGULA distinguishing the sites and influencing their diversity (80-702 species) and composition are connectivityVIRGULA permanent waterVIRGULA vegetationVIRGULA flowersVIRGULA and human impact (negativeVIRGULA including pollution). The diversified Nymphalidae butterflies (38-213 species) and especially two fermented-bait-attracted groups (SatyrinaeVIRGULA 2-30 speciesVIRGULA and BiblidiniVIRGULA 9-44 species)VIRGULA are among the more useful indicators of the quality and diversity of the environments in these fragments. Effective conservation of butterfly communities in tropical cities may be achieved by maintenance of arboreal green corridors along streets and watercourses between moderately large (>10 ha) humid areasVIRGULA not near to the most built-up or polluted city centre(s)VIRGULA and the inclusion within these areas of ponds or streamsVIRGULA diversified native forestVIRGULA and open vegetation including abundant nectar-rich flowers. (AU)

column4: [Português] Actinedida e Acaridida (Arachnida: Acari) edáficos de PiracicabaVIRGULA estado de São PauloVIRGULA [Inglês] Edaphic Actinedida e Acaridida (Arachnida: Acari) from PiracicabaVIRGULA State of São PauloVIRGULA Brazil
column5: [Português] Este trabalho teve como objetivo identificar os ácaros edáficos das subordens Actinedida e Acaridida coletados no campus Luiz de Queiroz da Universidade de São Paulo (ESALQ/USP). Coletas de solo foram feitas em três ambientes diferentesVIRGULA uma área de mata residual secundáriaVIRGULA outra de cultura pereneVIRGULA representada pelo plantio de seringueira (Hevea brasiliensis Müll. Arg.)VIRGULA clone RRIM 600VIRGULA e outra de culturas anuais (milho seguido de feijão). Coletas de folhedo foram realizadas apenas na mata secundária e no plantio de seringueira. A extração da acarofauna edáfica foi feita por meio do método de Berlese-Tullgren modificado. Foi constatado um total de 32 espécies pertencentes a 22 gêneros de 14 famílias da subordem Actinedida em solo e folhedo. Os ácaros da família Eupodidae foram os mais numerosos nos dois substratos e nos três ambientes estudados. Eupodes sp. 2 (Eupodidae) foi a espécie mais numerosa. Foi constatado um total de sete espécies pertencentes a seis gêneros de quatro famílias da subordem Acaridida. Tanto no solo quanto no folhedo dos ambientes estudadosVIRGULA Acaridae foi a família mais abundanteVIRGULA destacando-se uma espécie do gênero Tyrophagus. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The objective of this work was to identify the edaphic mites of the suborders Actinedida and Acaridida collected on the campus Luiz de QueirozVIRGULA University of São Paulo. Soil samples were taken from three different environmentsVIRGULA i.e.VIRGULA a residual secondary forestVIRGULA a perennial crop represented by a rubber tree plantation (Hevea brasiliensis Müll. Arg.)VIRGULA clone RRIM 600VIRGULA and an area of annual crops (corn followed by beans). Litter samples were taken only from the secondary forest and the rubber tree plantation. Mites were extracted using a modified Berlese-Tullgren apparatus. A total of 32 species belonging to 22 genera of 14 families of the suborder Actinedida was found in soil and litter. Eupodidae mites were the most numerous in both substrates in the three environments. Eupodes sp.2 (Eupodidae) was the most numerous species. A total of seven species belonging to six genera of four families of the suborder Acaridida was found. Acaridae was the most numerous family in this suborder in both soil and litter of all three environmentsVIRGULA with a predominance of a species of Tyrophagus. (AU)

column4: [Português] Compatibilidade reprodutiva de duas populações de Iphiseiodes zuluagai Denmark & Muma (Acari: Phytoseiidae)VIRGULA [Inglês] Reproductive compatibility between two populations of Iphiseiodes zuluagai Denmark & Muma (Acari: Phytoseiidae)
column5: [Português] O presente trabalho consistiu na avaliação da compatibilidade reprodutiva entre duas populações de ácaros predadores preliminarmente identificadas como Iphiseiodes zuluagai Denmark & MumaVIRGULA obtidas de uma plantação comercial de Citrus sinensis (L.) Osbeck. (Rutaceae) e de plantas de Syagrus romanzoffiana (Cham.) Glassman (Arecaceae) encontradas em uma área de floresta. Os resultados deste estudo poderiam indicar a possibilidade de que estas últimas plantas pudessem servir de reservatório de I. zuluagai às primeiras. As colônias de I. zuluagai foram mantidas em laboratório através do método descrito por Reis et al. (1988)VIRGULA a 25±1oCVIRGULA 85±5% de U.R. e 12h de fotofase. A compatibilidade reprodutiva foi avaliada através de cruzamentos e retrocruzamentos entre ácaros de cada colônia e observações da fecundidade dos ácaros durante 10 dias. Cruzamentos heterogâmicos e retrocruzamentos produziram descendentes férteis em proporções comparáveis aos cruzamentos homogâmicos. Os resultados indicam que as populações testadas pertencem à mesma espécieVIRGULA o que sugere um possível papel positivo de S. romanzoffiana como reservatório de I. zuluagaiVIRGULA a partir da qual o predador eventualmente poderia recolonizar áreas de plantas cultivadas. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The present work consisted of an evaluation of the reproductive compatibility between two populations of a predatory mite preliminarily identified as Iphiseiodes zuluagai Denmark & MumaVIRGULA obtained from a commercial plantation of Citrus sinensis (L.) Osbeck. (Rutaceae) and from Syagrus romanzoffiana (Cham.) Glassman (Arecaceae) found in a forest area. The results of this study could indicate the possibility that the latter system could serve as a reservoir of I. zuluagai to the former. The colonies of I. zuluagai were maintained in a laboratory using the method described by Reis et al. (1988)VIRGULA at 25±1oCVIRGULA 85±5% of R.H. and 12h light: 12h dark. The reproductive compatibility was evaluated through crosses and back-crosses between mites of each colony and observations on their fecundity during 10 days. The heterogamic crosses and the back-crosses resulted in fertile progeny in proportions comparable to homogamic crosses. These results indicate that both tested populations belong to the same speciesVIRGULA which suggest a possible positive role of S. romanzoffiana as reservoir of I. zuluagaiVIRGULA from which the predator could eventually re-colonize patches of cultivated plants. (AU)

column5: [Inglês] The early stages of the Amazonian nymphalid butterfly Bia actorion were studied in four localities (three in Brazil and one in Ecuador). The eggs bore multiple transverse and longitudinal ridges. First instar larvae had a setose head-capsule without scoli. All other instars were characterized by basally fusedVIRGULA highly ramified and setose head scoliVIRGULA and a bifurcate plate on the tenth abdominal segment. These characters indicate that this species (and its monotypic tribe) belong within the Brassolinae. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Two new species of Charinus SimonVIRGULA 1892 from Brazil with biologicalnotes (ArachnidaPONTOCOMMA AmblypygiPONTOCOMMA Charinidae)
column5: [Inglês] Charinus acaraje n. sp. is described from Gruta Pedra do SinoVIRGULA Santa LuziaVIRGULA BahiaVIRGULA Brazil and Charinus asturius n. sp. from Morro PacuíbaVIRGULA IlhabelaVIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA Brazil. Charinus asturius is recorded from the most southern locality in South America. Charinus asturius is a nocturnal forager that in captivity accepted live termites and Drosophila (adults and larvae). The most common defensive behaviours of C. asturius were: to flee when disturbed by light or touchVIRGULA and to autotomize parts or entire legs when manipulated. Most of the reproductive activity of the species probably occurs during the wet-warm season (from October to March). The clutch size ranged from 10 to 15 eggs and the pre-nymphs hatched and remained on the mothers back for 2 weeks. The limited occurrence of C. asturius on Ilhabela Island (from 100 to 400m on only one mountain) and its demands for specific microhabitats make the species threatened and vulnerable to the environmental damage caused by human occupation in the lower lands of the study site. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Ecological distribution of the shrimp Pleoticus muelleri (BateVIRGULA 1888) (Decapoda: Penaeoidea) in southeastern Brazil
column5: [Inglês] The abundance and ecological distribution of the shrimp Pleoticus muelleri as a function of certain environmental factors were investigated from January 1998 through December 1999 in the region of UbatubaVIRGULA Sao PauloVIRGULA Brazil. The collections were made monthly in the bays of Ubatumirim (UBM)VIRGULA Ubatuba (UBA) and Mar Virado (MV). Each bay was divided into six sampling transectsVIRGULA four transects parallel to the shoreline and two near the rocky shores on the opposite side. We employed a commercial shrimp boat equipped with two double-rig nets. A total of 6252 shrimp were collectedVIRGULA including 3321 from MVVIRGULA 1467 from UBMVIRGULA and 1464 from UBA. Most of the shrimp were caught in the deeperVIRGULA higher-salinity areas. The high abundance of P. muelleri observed in the southern part of the region studied was related to a sediments with a higher percentage of silt and clay. The numbers of P. muelleri were positively correlated with periods of cooler temperatures. ThusVIRGULA temperature and the type of sediment were determinant factors in the distribution of P. muelleri in this region. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Ontogenesis of the fruit pulp layer of Hymenaea stigonocarpa (Fabaceae: Caesalpinioideae)
column5: [Inglês] HymenaeaVIRGULA a genus of major economic importanceVIRGULA has been the subject of several botanical studies. HoweverVIRGULA there is disagreement over the origin of the edible fruit pulp of HymenaeaVIRGULA as there are no ontogenetic studies on this organ. According to some authorsVIRGULA the edible layer results from transformations of the mesocarp and endocarpVIRGULA while according to othersVIRGULA it is considered a seed aril. There are still others who regard this layer as originating from an undefined region of the pericarp. To understand the nature and origin of the pulp layerVIRGULA Hymenaea stigonocarpa Mart. ex Hayne ovaries and fruit were processed according to standard techniques. The production of the fruit pulp layer starts immediately after anthesis. During anthesisVIRGULA the inner epidermal cells of the ovary show periclinal division and form a new layer of cells towards the mesocarpPONTOCOMMA this remains meristematic and initiates cell production by predominantly periclinal divisionsVIRGULA producing a compact tissue towards the locule. This tissue will become the fruit pulp layerVIRGULA the inner endocarp. The seed coat shows typical testal structure without evidence of aril formation. This allows us to conclude that the fruit pulp layers are exclusively made from part of the endocarp. We also observed resin cavities on outer mesocarp and outer endocarp. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Morphometric analyses of two species of Scolelepis (Polychaeta: Spionidae)
column5: [Inglês] Seven hundred and six specimens of Scolelepis cf. chilensis and 551 specimens of Scolelepis goodbodyi were analysed. Individuals of each species were classified according to sex (maleVIRGULA femaleVIRGULA and immature individuals). Width (w) and height (h) of setigers 3 and 5VIRGULA the position of the first and the last gametogenic setigersVIRGULA the total number of setigersVIRGULA and the total length of each worm were measured. The area and volume of the setigers were estimated. Discriminant analysis was used to determine whether there were sexually dimorphic featuresVIRGULA apart from the presence of gametes. Linear regression analysis was used to evaluate the relationship between each parameter and the number of setigers. Scolelepis cf. chilensis was found to be significantly larger than S. goodbodyi (t=2171 and t=3644VIRGULA P<005 for length and number of setigersVIRGULA respectively). These species also differed in the position of the first gametogenic setigerVIRGULA which averaged 27 (SD=3) in S. cf. chilensis and 22 (SD=1) in S. goodbodyi (t= 2918VIRGULA P<005). There were no sexually dimorphic features in either sex of S. cf. chilensis (Wilks' lambda=09675VIRGULA P>005VIRGULA eigenvalue=0034) or S. goodbodyi (Wilks' lambda=08429VIRGULA P>005VIRGULA eigenvalue=0186). The total length showed the strongest correlation with the number of setigers in both species (r2=0887 and 0850 for S. cf. chilensis and S. goodbodyiVIRGULA respectively)VIRGULA followed by the width and the volume of setigers. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Size-fecundity relationships and reproductive investment in female frogs in the PantanalVIRGULA south-western Brazil
column5: [Inglês] The ovarian complement of anurans exhibiting different reproductive modes is highly diverseVIRGULA and intraspecific variation in reproductive output of anurans is generally related to variation in female properties and/or environmental conditions. The size-fecundity relationshipsVIRGULA reproductive investmentVIRGULA and correlation between ovary mass and fat body mass were investigated for females of an anuran assemblage in the PantanalVIRGULA Brazil. Female body size was positively correlated with clutch size among seven of the eight species analyzed. HoweverVIRGULA these results seem to be influenced by seasonal variation in fecundity. Interspecific size-fecundity relationships revealed that female SVL was positively correlated with clutch size and egg size regardless of reproductive mode. Among 11 species analyzedVIRGULA the reproductive investment (RI: ovary mass relative to body mass) varied from 5.5 to 18%VIRGULA and there were no differences among reproductive modes and activity patterns (explosive / prolonged). RI correlated negatively with female size. Among three Leptodactylus species examinedVIRGULA negative correlation between ovary mass and fat body mass was verified for two species. Variations in the reproductive strategies are closely related to the reproductive activity patterns and reproductive modes exhibited by individual speciesVIRGULA but are also influenced by environmental conditions. HoweverVIRGULA regardless of reproductive mode or activity patternVIRGULA each species seems to exhibit a reproductive strategy that allows them to respond differently to the same environmental restrictions. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Surface contamination effects on leaf chemical composition in the Atlantic Forest
column5: [Inglês] The exogenous material that adheres to the leaf surface affects the elemental composition of the plant itselfVIRGULA thereby constituting one of the major error sources in plant analysis. The present work investigated the surface contamination of leaves from the Atlantic Forest. Instrumental neutron activation analysis (INAA) was applied to assess the efficiency of leaf EDTA-washing. Chemical element concentrations were corrected using Sc (soil tracer) since resuspended soil is the main source of contamination in leaves. As a resultVIRGULA EDTA-washing should be used mainly for the evaluation of terrigenous elementsVIRGULA while the Sc-corrected concentrations are considered satisfactory for the other elements. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Global biodiversity informatics: setting the scene for a new world of ecological modeling
column5: [Inglês] Recent developments in information and communication technology are allowing new experiences in the integrationVIRGULA analysis and visualization of biodiversity informationVIRGULA and are leading to development of a new field of researchVIRGULA biodiversity informatics. Although this field has great potential in diverse realmsVIRGULA including basic biologyVIRGULA human economicsVIRGULA and public healthVIRGULA much of this potential remains to be explored. The success of several concerted international efforts depends largely on broad deployment of biodiversity informatics information and products. Several global and regional efforts are organizing and providing data for conservation and sustainable development researchVIRGULA including the Global Biodiversity Information FacilityVIRGULA the European Biodiversity Information NetworkVIRGULA and the Inter-American Biodiversity Information Network. Critical to development of this field is building a biodiversity information infrastructureVIRGULA making primary biodiversity data freely and openly available over the Internet. In addition to specimen and taxonomic dataVIRGULA access to non-biological environmental data is critical to spatial analysis and modeling of biodiversity. Adoption of standards and protocols and development of tools for collection managementVIRGULA datacleaningVIRGULA georeferencingVIRGULA and modeling toolsVIRGULA are allowing a quantum leap in the area. Open access to research data and open-source tools are leading to a new era of web services and computational frameworks for spatial biodiversity analysisVIRGULA bringing new opportunities and dimensions to novel approaches in ecological analysisVIRGULA predictive modelingVIRGULA and synthesis and visualization of biodiversity information. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] A revision of the Neotropical spider genus Ancylometes bertkau (Araneae: Pisauridae)
column5: [Inglês] The spider genus Ancylometes BertkauVIRGULA 1880 is revised. A. vulpes BertkauVIRGULA 1880VIRGULA type species of the genusVIRGULA is considered a junior subjective synonym of Dolomedes concolor PertyVIRGULA 1833. Both types are lost and we redescribe the species based on specimens similar to those found at the type locality of A. vulpes. Spiders of the genus are large nocturnal ground-living hunting spiders with a strong affinity in most speciesVIRGULA to water bodies within their tropical environment. Those species hunt also on small vertebrates like frogsVIRGULA tadpoles and fishes. All species show slight sexual dimorphism in colour and body-to-leg-size relations. Females carry brown egg-sacs in chelicerae and build a nursery web. The genus is morphologically diagnosed by the presence of ventral spines on tarsi III and IV in both sexes and by their genital characters: filiform embolus with a basal membranous lobeVIRGULA wing-like conductor and hammer-like median apophysis in malesPONTOCOMMA female epigyne consisting of two broad lateral plates and a central plate in form of a bike saddle with its nose pointing posteriorly. Ten valid species are recognized and describedVIRGULA five of them are new: Ancylometes japuraVIRGULA A. jauVIRGULA A. riparius from AmazonasVIRGULA A. terrenus from AcreVIRGULA Amazonas and Mato Grosso and A. pantanal from Matto Grosso do SulVIRGULA all from Brazil. The female of A. amazonicus is described for the first time and the female of A. hewitsoni for the first time based on an adult specimen. Ancylometes vulpes BertkauVIRGULA Ctenus argentinus HolmbergVIRGULA Ancylometes bolivianus TullgrenVIRGULA Lycoctenus bahiensis StrandVIRGULA Lycoctenus selenkae StrandVIRGULA Lycoctenus paraguayensis StrandVIRGULA Cupiennius argentinus PetrunkevitchVIRGULA Ctenus paulensis Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA Cupiennius diplocellatus Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA Ctenus originalis Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA Ctenus iophorus Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA Corinoctenus anomalostomus Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA Ctenus infelix (Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA Ctenus metatarsalis Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA Phoneutria niveobarbata Mello-Leitão and Corinoctenus greenwayi Carcavallo & Martinez are newly synonymized with A. concolor (Perty). Ctenus fuscus WalckenaerVIRGULA Ctenus giganteus TaczanowskiVIRGULA Ctenus bimaculatus TaczanowskiVIRGULA Leptoctenus tenkatei HasseltVIRGULA Lycoctenus brunneus Pickard-CambridgeVIRGULA Lycoctenus gigas Pickard-CambridgeVIRGULA Lycoctenus demerarensis Pickard-CambridgeVIRGULA Lycoctenus saraensis StrandVIRGULA Lycoctenus paraensis StrandVIRGULA Ancylometes pindareensis Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA Ancylometes pindareannus Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA Ctenus juruensis Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA Ctenus striolatus Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA Ctenus xerophilus Mello-Leitão and Lycoctenus titanus Caporiacco are newly synonymized with A. rufus (Walckenaer). Lycoctenus palustris Pickard-CambridgeVIRGULA Ancylometes orinocensis SimonVIRGULA Lycoctenus venezuelensis StrandVIRGULA Lycoctenus caracasensis Strand and Ctenus nasutus Kraus are newly synonymized with A. bogotensis (Keyserling). A. valentinei PetrunkevitchVIRGULA 1925 from Panama is a Cupiennius (new combination) and considered a senior synonym of C. panamensis Lachmuth et al.VIRGULA 1985. The geographical distribution is NeotropicalVIRGULA with one northern widespread species (A. bogotensis) reaching Central AmericaVIRGULA one widespread species of the Amazon reaching the São Paulo coastal area and one widespread species of central Brazil reaching Argentina. From the Amazon region six rarely collected species are described and one species was recently collected in the Pantanal of Brazil. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] The fauna of Tephritidae (Diptera) from capitula of Asteraceae in Brazil
column5: [Inglês] This is the first comprehensive survey of the fauna of Tephritidae that breed in capitula of Asteraceae in southern and southeastern BrazilVIRGULA resulting from a sampling program begun in 1985. The Tephritidae is the most diverse and abundant family of endophages of Asteraceae flowerheads in Brazil. From approximately 1VIRGULA800 samples of capitula from 403 species of AsteraceaeVIRGULA we reared 9VIRGULA697 Tephritidae individuals belonging to 80 species and 18 genera. Of theseVIRGULA at least 31 species and 3 genera are undescribedVIRGULA and 30% of the described species were not previously recorded from Brazil. The most diverse tribes of Asteraceae in the NeotropicsVIRGULA Vernonieae and EupatorieaeVIRGULA have the greatest diversity of associated tephritidsVIRGULA although Vernonieae has a greater number of specialist species. Although the tribe Senecioneae is moderately diversified in the studied areaVIRGULA it is rarely attacked and has no specialist tephritid speciesVIRGULA in contrast with other areas of the world. The tephritid fauna in Brazilian Asteraceae flowerheads is dominated by Neotropical genera (e.g.VIRGULA TomoplagiaVIRGULA XanthaciuraVIRGULA DictyotrypetaVIRGULA TetreuarestaVIRGULA and Trypanaresta) that represent 80% of the obtained species and 90% of the obtained individuals. Most of these tephritid species are restricted to one tribe or some lower taxonomic level of Asteraceae. The main host plants for 75% of them belong to one genus or group of related genera of host plants. Most of our host records for genera and species of tephritids agree with previously published records from other world regionsVIRGULA showing that there is little variation in the set of host plants of tephritid species and genera among areas. The geographic distribution and host plants for each genus are discussedVIRGULA and a list of host plants and localities is presentedVIRGULA for the identified speciesVIRGULA totaling 167 new host records. (AU)

The known distribution ranges of A. attarum and A. luederwaldti are extended from Rio de Janeiro to Brasilia (Distrito Federal) and from São Paulo to Minas Gerais and Mato GrossoVIRGULA respectively. column5: [Inglês] Beach clam fisheries often provide an alternate income for traditional fishermenVIRGULA but this activity is highly vulnerable to urbanization of coastal areas. Tivela mactroides is a beach clam commonly harvested in the Caribbean (Venezuela) and on the south-eastern Brazilian coast. Only localized records on its spatial structure in size and abundance are available to support management of this clam. The present study showed that the spatial distribution in abundance and size of T. mactroides in Caraguatatuba BayVIRGULA state of S o PauloVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA has both along- and across-shore (intertidal and subtidal) components. The nature of this distribution should be taken into account in the design of further population or monitoring studies concerning this species. Clam density varied along-shoreVIRGULA with a tendency towards higher numbers of individuals in the stations near the northern side of river mouths of this bay. Lower densities were related to the occurrence of sea-stars and sand-dollars. The intertidal and subtidal across-shore distribution of clam abundance and size varied between and within areas (southern and northern). The individuals from the southern area were concentrated at intermediate tidal levels (0.2-0.6 m in relation to mean low water)VIRGULA whereas in the northern area the clams were more homogeneously distributed. The uppermost limit of their distribution was 0.8 m (southern) and 0.4 m (northern)VIRGULA and an upwards tendency towards increased size was more evident in the northern area. In the subtidalVIRGULA abundance and individual size tended to increase from the deepest (4.5 m) to the shallowest (0.5 m) levels only in the southern area. Individual clams in the northern area tended to be smaller and more abundant than in the southern area. The species had an ontogenic distribution: small-sized individuals were recorded only in the subtidal. Possible causes for these patterns and for the differences between areas (human exploitationVIRGULA organic pollutionVIRGULA beach morphodynamicsVIRGULA differential recruitmentVIRGULA and adult-larvae interactions) are discussedVIRGULA and specific studies are suggested to evaluate formally the proposed hypotheses. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] On the sticky cobwebs of two theridiid spiders (Araneae: Theridiidae)
column5: [Inglês] In this study we describe and illustrate a new speciesVIRGULA Chrysso intervales n. sp.VIRGULA based on males and females collected in Parque Estadual IntervalesVIRGULA an area of Atlantic Forest in the State of S o PauloVIRGULA Brazil. We present data on habitat selectionVIRGULA web architectureVIRGULA thread adhesivenessVIRGULA dietVIRGULA and mortality due to fungi for both Chrysso intervales and the sympatric speciesVIRGULA Helvibis longicauda. Both species build webs on vegetation close to river marginsVIRGULA but they were not found in forest sites away from these shaded and extremely humid corridors. The webs of both species are entirely composed of viscid silk linesVIRGULA occupying the space between two or more large leaves. The construction of this web type by Helvibis and ChryssoVIRGULA and the large amount of viscid droplets in their threadsVIRGULA indicate that the investment in adhesive components in theridiids may be dependent on the ambient conditions. We suggest that the costs of maintaining viscid silk lines in humid areas may be relatively lowVIRGULA explaining the habitat restriction observed in the species studied. By selecting humid habitatsVIRGULA howeverVIRGULA these spiders are susceptible to attacks by fungi. The webs constructed by both species intercepted mostly DipteraVIRGULA especially tipulidsVIRGULA but H. longicauda was also observed consuming a wide variety of prey types. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Monomer composition of polysaccharides of seed cell walls and the taxonomy of the Vochysiaceae
column5: [Inglês] The distribution of polysaccharides from the seed cell walls of 57 samples of Vochysiaceae native to Brazil were studiedVIRGULA comprising 16 species distributed among the genera CallistheneVIRGULA QualeaVIRGULA Salvertia and Vochysia. The polysaccharides were extracted with hot waterVIRGULA then hydrolyzed with the resulting monomers analyzed by HPLC. All samples yielded arabinoseVIRGULA galactoseVIRGULA glucoseVIRGULA mannose and rhamnoseVIRGULA the relative amounts of each monomerVIRGULA howeverVIRGULA varying from one sample to another. Arabinose was always the predominant componentVIRGULA which implies that it might possibly be used as a marker of the Vochysiaceae. The quantitative distribution of monosaccharides was similar between the species of Qualea and CallistheneVIRGULA characterized by the predominance of arabinose and mannoseVIRGULA and between the species of Salvertia and VochysiaVIRGULA which contained higher amounts of arabinose and galactose. Such results are consistent with affinities inferred from floral morphologyVIRGULA wood anatomy and molecular data. Substantial intraspecific variation was observed for some species. UPGMA analysis based on the distribution of the monosaccharides reveals two main clustersVIRGULA according to the links commented above. The resultant phenogram is not coherent with the current sectional classification of the VochysiaceaeVIRGULA but the differences in the monosaccharides distribution between the two clusters are strongly supported by ANOVA. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Interhabitat differences in ant activity on plant foliage: ants at extrafloral nectaries of Hibiscus pernambucensis in sandy and mangrove forests
column5: [Inglês] The association between visiting ants and the extrafloral nectaries (EFN)-bearing shrub Hibiscus pernambucensis Arruda (Malvaceae) was investigated in two different coastal habitats - a permanently dry sandy forest and a regularly inundated mangrove forest. In both habitats the frequency of plants with ants and the mean number of ants per plant were much higher on H. pernambucensis than on non-nectariferous neighbouring plants. In the sandy forest the proportion of live termite baits attacked by ants on H. pernambucensis was much higher than on plants lacking EFNs. In the mangroveVIRGULA howeverVIRGULA ants attacked equal numbers of termites on either plant class. Ant attendance to tuna/honey baits revealed that overall ant activity in the sandy forest is higher than in the mangrove area. The vertical distribution (ground vs. foliage) of ant activity also differed between habitats. While in the mangrove foraging ants were more frequent at baits placed on foliageVIRGULA in the sandy forest ant attendance was higher at ground baits. Plants housing ant colonies were more common in the mangrove than in the sandy forest. Frequent flooding in the mangrove may have resulted in increased numbers of ant nests on vegetation and scattered ant activity across plant foliageVIRGULA irrespective of possession of EFNs. Thus plants with EFNs in the mangrove may not experience increased ant aggression towards potential herbivores relative to plants lacking EFNs. The study suggests that the vertical distribution of ant activityVIRGULA as related to different nest site distribution (ground vs. foliage) through a spatial scaleVIRGULA can mediate ant foraging patterns on plant foliage and probably affect the ants' potential for herbivore deterrence on an EFN-bearing plant species. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Xyloglucan mobilisation in cotyledons of developing plantlets of Hymenaea courbaril L. (Leguminosae-Caesalpinoideae)
column5: [Inglês] Many seeds contain storage compounds that are used by the embryo:plantlet as a source of nutrients after germination. In seeds of Hymenaea courbarilVIRGULA a leguminous treeVIRGULA the main reserve consists of a structurally unusual xyloglucan stored in thickened walls of the cotyledon cells. The present work aimed to study H. courbaril xyloglucan metabolism during and after germination in order to compare its degrading system with the other known xyloglucan containing seeds. Polysaccharide degradation occurred after germination between 35 and 55 days after planting. The activities of alpha-xylosidaseVIRGULA betha-glucosidaseVIRGULA betha-galactosidase and XET rose during the period of xyloglucan disassembling but a low level of endo-b-glucanase activity was detectedVIRGULA suggesting that this XET has high affinity for the oligosaccharides. The pH optimum of betha-galactosidase was different from the alpha-xylosidaseVIRGULA betha-glucosidase and XET optima suggesting that the former may be important in the control of the mobilisation process. A tentative model for xyloglucan disassembling in vivo is proposedVIRGULA where betha-galactosidase allows the free oligosaccharides to bypass a transglycosylation cycle and be disassembled by the other exo-enzymes. Some ecophysiological comparisons among H. courbaril and other xyloglucan storing seeds are discussed. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Mobilisation of storage cell wall polysaccharides in seeds
column5: [Inglês] Plants store carbohydrate polymers in a number of forms. Starch is the principal formVIRGULA followed by fructans and cell wall storage polysaccharides (CWSP). The latter are present mainly in seeds and consist of magnifications of one of the polysaccharides present in one of the cell wall matrices. CWSPs are classified as mannansVIRGULA xyloglucans and galactansVIRGULA the first being subdivided into pure mannansVIRGULA galactomannans and glucomannans. The present review updates the principal discoveries concerning occurrenceVIRGULA structureVIRGULA metabolism and eco-physiological significance of the seed storage cell wall polysaccharides with emphasis on their importance for plant metabolism and adaptation to their respective environments during evolution. The properties of CWSPs as storage polysaccharides are compared with starch and fructans and the current knowledge on the catabolism (including control) of mannan/galactomannanVIRGULA xyloglucanVIRGULA and galactan is reviewed. On the basis of these dataVIRGULA the idea that the CWSPs are multifunctional molecules is proposed and this feature is used as evidence for the hypothesis thatVIRGULA during evolutionVIRGULA the CWSPs were involved in cycles of transference of functions which led them to become storage polysaccharidesVIRGULA yet preserving some of their previous primary cell wall functions. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Insight into multi-site mechanisms of glycosyl transfer in (1-4) Betha-glycans provided by the cereal mixed-linkage (1-3)VIRGULA (1-4) Betha-glucan synthase
column5: [Inglês] Synthases of celluloseVIRGULA chitinVIRGULA hyaluronanVIRGULA and all other polymers containing (1-4)Betha-linked glucosylVIRGULA mannosyl and xylosyl units have overcome a substrate orientation problem in catalysis because the (1-4) Betha--linkage requires that each of these sugar units be inverted nearly 180° with respect to its neighbors. We and others have proposed that this problem is solved by two modes of glycosyl transfer within a single catalytic subunit to generate disaccharide unitsVIRGULA whichVIRGULA when linked processivelyVIRGULA maintain the proper orientation without rotation or re-orientation of the synthetic machinery in 3-dimensional space. A variant of the strict (1-4) Betha-linkage structure is the mixed-linkage (1-3)VIRGULA (1-4) Betha-glucanVIRGULA a growth-specific cell wall polysaccharide found in grasses and cereals. Betha-Glucan is composed primarily of cellotriosyl and cellotetraosyl units linked by single (1-3) Betha-linkages. In reactions in vitro at high substrate concentrationVIRGULA a polymer composed of almost entirely cellotriosyl and cellopentosyl units is made. These results support a model in which three modes of glycosyl transfer occur within the synthase complex instead of just two. The generation of odd numbered units demands that they are connected by (1-3) Betha-linkages and not (1-4) Betha. In this short review of Betha-glucan synthesis in maizeVIRGULA we show how such a model not only provides simple mechanisms of synthesis for all (1-4) Betha-glycans but also explains how the synthesis of calloseVIRGULA or strictly (1-3) Betha-glucansVIRGULA occurs upon loss of the multiple modes of glycosyl transfer to a single one. (AU)

column5: [Inglês] Populations of Aeria olena and Tithorea harmonia pseudethra (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidade: Ithomiinae) showed large variations in abundance along the year in four sitesVIRGULA with peaks at the end of the wet season. Both species differ from other members of the Ithomiinae community in the region by feeding on Apoeynaceae vines as larvaeVIRGULA not congregating in 'ithomiine pockets' and having low population numbers in the dry season. column4: [Inglês] Evaluation of methods for estimating macroinvertebrate species richness using individual stones in tropical streams
column5: [Inglês] 1) The most straightforward way to assess diversity in a site is the species count. HoweverVIRGULA a relatively large sample is needed for a reliable result because of the presence of many rare species in rich assemblages. The use of richness estimation methods is suggested by many authors as a solution for this problem in many casesPONTOCOMMA 2) we examined the performance of 13 methods for estimating richness of stream macroinvertebrates inhabiting riffles both at local (stream) and regional (catchment) scales. The evaluation was based on (1) the smallest sub-sample size needed to estimate total richness in the sampleVIRGULA (2) constancy of this sizeVIRGULA (3) lack of erratic behaviour in curve shape and (4) similarity in curve shape through different data sets. Samples were from three single stream sites (local) and three from several streams within the same catchment basin (regional). All collections were made from protected forest areas in south-east BrazilVIRGULA 3) all estimation methods were dependent on sub-sample sizeVIRGULA producing higher estimates when using larger sub-sample sizes. The Stout and Vandermeer method estimated total richness in the samples with the smallest sub-sample sizeVIRGULA but showed some erratic behaviour at small sub-sample sizesVIRGULA and the estimated curves were not similar among the six samples. The Bootstrap method was the best estimator in relation to constancy of sub-sample sizesVIRGULA but needed an unacceptably large sub-sample to estimate total richness in the samples. The second order Jackknife method was the second best estimator both for minimum sub-sample size and constancy of this size and we suggest its use in future studies of diversity in tropical streams. Despite the inferior performance of several other methodsVIRGULA some produced acceptable results. Comments are made on the utility of using these estimators for predicting species richness in an area and for comparative purposes in diversity studies. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Interaction between cellulose and storage xyloglucans: the influence of the degree of galactosylation
column5: [Inglês] Xyloglucan (Xg) is a polymer found in the primary cell walls of growing tissues and also in the seeds of many dicotyledons as a storage polysaccharide. In this study the interaction with cellulose and Xgs with different fine structures was studied. pH and temperature did not have a marked effect on the interactionVIRGULA except for a slightly higher interaction at pH 6.0. Ultrastructural analysis showed that the binding capacity depends on the surface area of the cellulose. Among different sources of XgVIRGULA the binding capacity varied significantly. HPAEC-PAD analysis of the Xg cellulase-limit digest oligosaccharides of bound Xg suggested that there might be a certain pattern of galactosyl substitution which is related to a higher Xg binding capacity. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Broteochactas feiVIRGULA a new scorpion species (ScorpionesVIRGULA Chactidae) from Brazilian AmazoniaVIRGULA with notes on its abundance and association with termites
column5: [Português] Broteochactas fei n.sp. es descrito de ManausVIRGULA Estado de AmazonasVIRGULA Brasil. Pertenece al grupo de especies BrotheochactasVIRGULA donde difiere del resto de las especies por presentar dos ojos lateralesVIRGULA carapacho rojizoVIRGULA terguitos finamente granulados y telson casi liso. A partir de dos métodos de muestreo se estimaron abundancias diferentes de 0VIRGULA0027 y 0VIRGULA022 ind/m2. Estos valores pueden considerarse bajos cuando son comparados con la abundancia de otras especies simpátricas de escorpiones. La nueva especie es aparentemente termitófila (27 de los 30 especímenes fueron colectados em termiteros)VIRGULA encontrándose asociada a 13 especies de termitas pertenecientes a três subfamilias. Sin embargoVIRGULA hembras con juveniles fueron colectadasVIRGULA con mayor frecuenciaVIRGULA en termiteros pertenecientes a especies de Apicotermitinae. (AU)^EsVIRGULA [Inglês] Brotheochactas fei sp. nVIRGULA from ManausVIRGULA State of AmazonasVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA is newly described. B. fei belongs to the Brotheochactas species-groupVIRGULA and differs from the remaining species by having two lateral eyesVIRGULA a reddish carapaceVIRGULA finely granulate tergites and a nearly smooth telson. Based on two sampling methodsVIRGULA different estimates of abundance were obtained: 0.0027 and 0.022 ind/m2. These values are low when compared to the abundance of other sympatric scorpion species. The species is apparently termitophile (27 out of 30 specimens were collected in termite mounds). They were found associated with 13 species of termites from 3 subfamilies. HoweverVIRGULA females with young were more frequent in the mounds of apicotermitine termites. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Placentation in the Capybara (Hydrochaerus hydrochaeris)VIRGULA Agouti (Dasyprocta aguti) and Paca (Agouti paca)
column5: [Inglês] Placentae of three hystricimorph rodents-capybaraVIRGULA agouti and paca-were examined by conventional histologyVIRGULA immunohistochemistry for cytokeratin and vimentinVIRGULA and TUNEL staining. The placentae were divided into lobules of labyrinthine syncytium separated by interlobular and marginal trophoblast. The subplacenta comprised cytotrophoblastsVIRGULA supported on lamellae of allantoic mesodermVIRGULA and syncytiotrophoblast. The central excavation was still apparent in the definitive placenta of capybara. In agouti and pacaVIRGULA the decidua of the junctional zone formed a mesoplacenta comprising a capsule and a pedicle. Towards term the pedicle formed a tenuous attachment between placenta and uterine wall comprising a few maternal vessels surrounded by degraded tissue. In paca placentaVIRGULA it was shown by TUNEL staining that breakdown of this tissue occurred by apoptosis. The visceral yolk sac was highly villous andVIRGULA in agoutiVIRGULA the yolk sac villi were extremely long. Lateral to its attachment to the placentaVIRGULA the fetal surface was covered with non-vascular yolk sac endoderm. A layer of spongiotrophoblast cells was interposed between the endoderm and the marginal trophoblast. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] New records and laboratory-rearing data for Ixodes schulzei (Acari: Ixodidae) in Brazil
column5: [Inglês] Ixodes schulzei Aragão and Fonseca was described from Brazil in 1951 based on female tickscollected on wild ratsfrom the statesof Rio de Janeiro and Santa Catarina. Since that timeVIRGULA there have been no additional reportsof I. schulzei in the literature.Wereport two new recordsof I. schulzei: a female collected on the water rat Nectomys squamipes (Brants) from Minas Gerais StateVIRGULA and another female from this same host species from São Paulo State. This last specimen was engorged and oviposited fertile eggs in the laboratory. Larvae hatched from these eggs were used for subsequent infestationsunder laboratory conditionsVIRGULA aswere nymphsobtained from the engorged larvae. Naïve laboratory rats (Rattus norvegicus Berkenhout) and wild mice (Calomys callosus Rengger) were used to feed ticks. C. callosus was a more suitable host than R. norvegicusVIRGULA ass ignificantly more ticks (P_0.05) were recovered and successfully molted after feeding on the former host species. A significantly (P_0.05) greater proportion of larvae detached from C. callosus during daylight (71.3%) when compared with those that detached from R. norvegicus in the same period (54.8%). A total of nine engorged nymphs (one from R. norvegicusVIRGULA and eight from C. callosus) were recovered in the infestations. All of them successfully molted to adultsVIRGULA which were all females. The male of I. schulzei remainsunknown. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Testes size in Leptodactylid frogs and occurrence of multimale spawning in the genus Leptodactylus in Brazil
column5: [Inglês] Although rareVIRGULA some anurans show multimale spawning. Herein we present data on testes mass relative to body mass for 11 leptodactylids and report multimale spawning in Leptodactylus chaquensis and Leptodactylus podicipinus. Testes mass averaged 4.13% of body mass for L. chaquensis and 0.75% for L. podicipinus. Testes size of both leptodactylid species with multimale spawning show that they are large and close to values recorded for rhacophorid frogs with multimale breeding (0.71-7.79%). Large testes size in frogs with multimale spawning supports the sperm competition hypothesis. (AU)

A new diagnostic character observed for the genus is the presence of fringes of fingersVIRGULA and fringes and webbing of toesVIRGULA finely serratePONTOCOMMA the serrate edge of the fringe and webbing can be keratinized in malesVIRGULA femalesVIRGULA and subadults. Hydrolaetare dantasi (Bokermann) is characterized by robust body and limbsVIRGULA a broad and depressed headVIRGULA slightly shorter than wideVIRGULA and longVIRGULA pointed and basally webbed toes. Hydrolaetare dantasi differs from the only other species in this genusVIRGULA Hydrolaetare schmidti (Cochran and Goin)VIRGULA mainly by having toes webbed basally (fully webbed in H. schmidti). The advertisement call of H. dantasi is composed of two componentsPONTOCOMMA an initial note produced by the impact of the vocal sac against the ground and a second note corresponding to a long whistle of ascending frequency. The initial note is a percussive sound and represents an unusual form of sound emission in anuransPONTOCOMMA the second note is a vocalization. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Ibotyporanga Mello-Leitão: tropical spiders in Brazilian semi-arid habitats (Araneae: Pholcidae)
column5: [Inglês] Three new species of the previously monotypic ninetine genus Ibotyporanga Mello-LeitãoVIRGULA 1944 are described: I. emekori sp. n.VIRGULA I. diroa sp. n.VIRGULA and I. ramosae sp. n.VIRGULA all from the Brazilian state Bahia. All were collected in caatingaVIRGULA a vegetation type that covers most of the area with semiarid climate in the northeastern region of Brazil. It is argued that two alternative explanations might account for the apparently almost universal restriction of ninetines to relatively inhospitable areas: they might be a relict group (possibly monophyletic)VIRGULA displaced from more favorable areas by more modern pholcidsPONTOCOMMA or they might be a polyphyletic assemblage of lineages that independently evolved the ability to thrive in arid and semiarid areas by reducing their body size and appendage length to fit into spaces with tolerable microclimate. Preliminary cladistic analyses based on morphology alone have not been able to settle this question. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Calanoida (Copepoda) species composition changes in the reservoirs of São Paulo State (Brazil) in the last twenty years
column5: [Inglês] Among the zooplankton groups the Calanoida copepods present a high degree of endemism with a very restricted geographic distribution. This endemism can be a response to the sensibility of these organisms to changes in chemical and physical factors such as pHVIRGULA conductivity and ionic ratios. Studies on the composition and distribution of the Calanoida species in 21 reservoirs of São Paulo StateVIRGULA carried out from 1979 onwardsVIRGULA and the studies on Barra Bonita Reservoir show a complete change in species composition including the appearance of a new species. Species which were frequent such as Notodiaptomus conifer in the majority of the reservoirs of the Middle Tietê and Paranapanema River basinsVIRGULA disappeared completelyVIRGULA being substituted by other species. At the Barra Bonita ReservoirVIRGULA species such as Argyrodiaptomus furcatusVIRGULA and Scolodiaptomus corderoiVIRGULA which are typical of waters of low conductivity (up to 100 &#956PONTOCOMMAS cm&#8722PONTOCOMMA1) and pH near 7.0VIRGULA were substituted by species of Notodiaptomus iheringi and N. cearensis dwellers in waters of conductivity much higher than 100 &#956PONTOCOMMAS cm&#8722PONTOCOMMA1 (up to 500 &#956PONTOCOMMAS cm&#8722PONTOCOMMA1) and lower pH than 7.0. Structural changes in the zooplankton community can be the first step towards large scale changes in reservoir functions as a consequence of eutrophication and toxicity. (AU)

column5: [Inglês] Information on the life cycle of individual species is vital to an understanding of their ecologyVIRGULA particularly their distribution. In this investigationVIRGULA aspects of the Macrothrix flabelligera (CladoceraVIRGULA Macrothricidae) life cycle were studied in laboratory cultures under controlled conditions. Daily measurements of body length and age were madeVIRGULA to obtain the growth rateVIRGULA size and age of primipara. column4: [Inglês] Indole glucoalkaloids from Chimarrhis turbinata and their evaluation as antioxidant agents and acetylcholinesterase inhibitors

column4: [Inglês] Native trees as biomonitors of chemical elements in the biodiversity conservation of the Atlantic Forest
column5: [Inglês] The Atlantic ForestVIRGULA a hotspot in the world with a great diversity of plants and animalsVIRGULA is located in the most industrialized area of BrazilVIRGULA a potential source of chemical elements for the atmosphere. From its original area about 10% has been preserved mainly through the implementation of conservation unitsVIRGULA among which the Parque Estadual Carlos Botelho (PECB) is one of the most representative. HereVIRGULA leaves of the predominant species in the PECB were analyzed by instrumental neutron activation analysis (INAA) for the establishment of natural backgrounds of AsVIRGULA BaVIRGULA BrVIRGULA CaVIRGULA CdVIRGULA CeVIRGULA CoVIRGULA CsVIRGULA FeVIRGULA HgVIRGULA KVIRGULA NaVIRGULA RbVIRGULA ScVIRGULA SeVIRGULA Sr and Zn. Biomonitoring of the Atlantic Forestwas realized through the tree community study taking in account the interspecies and the intraspecies variability of chemical concentrations. Results pointed out the low status of pollution based on the concentrations of chemical elements of environmental concerning. HoweverVIRGULA Br concentrations were higher in the understory speciesVIRGULA which could be related to the possible effects of atmospheric pollution or sea influence. In additionVIRGULA some Hyeronima alchorneoides trees showed to be hyperaccumulators of Co. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Compartments in insect-plant associations and their consequences for community structure
column5: [Inglês] Compartmentation has been less explored than other forms of community structure. We assessed compartmentation of associations between insects and plants on a regional scaleVIRGULA and analysed some of its causes and consequences. The data set used was the host records of fruit flies (DipteraPONTOCOMMA Tephritidae) that breed in flowerheads of plants of the tribe Vernonieae (Asteraceae) in the Espinhaço Mountain rangeVIRGULA Minas GeraisVIRGULA Brazil. This data set was obtained with a consistent sampling protocol and is taxonomically fully resolvedPONTOCOMMA the binary association matrix had a total of 35 insect and 81 plant species. Most of the insects were specialized on plants of a single subtribeVIRGULA genus or species group. Correspondence analysis showed that the association matrix is divided in six well-delimited compartments of insects specialized on subtribes or genera of plantsPONTOCOMMA host dissimilarity among insects and insect dissimilarity among plants were expressed as Jaccard distances. Tests with a multi-response permutation procedure (MRPP) showed that both kinds of dissimilarities were higher among compartments than within themPONTOCOMMA Monte Carlo randomizations were used to compare matrix parameters with values expected in the absence of compartments. In 4000 runsVIRGULA the number of insect species that shared at least one host plant (ecological neighbours) was smaller than expected. NeverthelessVIRGULA mean host similarity among insectsVIRGULA and the proportion of exclusive host plants used by each insect species did not differ from null model predictions. Host similarity of insects with their nearest neighbours in niche space was higher than expected by the null model. On the other handVIRGULA host similarity with farthest neighbours was lower than expectedPONTOCOMMA the observed compartmentation of insect/plant associations can be ascribed to the marked specialization of flowerhead tephritidsVIRGULA and allows the reduction of diffuse competition among insects. HoweverVIRGULA compartmentation did not decrease overall niche overlap among insects because reduction in number of neighbours is offset by increased overlap with species in the same compartment. ThereforeVIRGULA the pattern in this system cannot be derived from resource partitioning alone. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Colonization by macroinvertebrates of experimentally disturbed stones in three tropical streams differing in size
column5: [Inglês] We experimentally disturbed stones in three streams of different sizes and followed the macroinvertebrate colonization process in terms of abundanceVIRGULA species richness and similarity over 64 days. We hypothesized that colonization in the smallest and in the largest streams would be slower than in the mediumsized stream. The small upstream pool of colonists available in the smallest stream could restrict colonizationVIRGULA while in the largest stream predation by the diverse fish assemblage could restrict drifting colonists. The medium-sized stream did not have these two constraints. We found similar colonization patterns in all three streamsVIRGULA leading to the rejection of the stated hypotheses. Lack of support of the original hypothesis might be due to the weakness of the two hypothesized restrictions on colonization. In additionVIRGULA colonization by crawling species from undisturbed nearby patches might be of significant importance. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Breeding ecology of Scinax trapicheiroi (AnuraVIRGULA Hylidae) at a creek in the Atlantic Rainforest of Ilha GrandeVIRGULA southeastern Brazil
column5: [Inglês] We analyzed the breeding biology in a population of the hylid Scinax trapicheiroi and evaluated how some environmental and structural factors affect the temporal and spatial distribution of the clutches. Fieldwork was carried out at a small stream running inside the Atlantic Rainforest at Ilha GrandeVIRGULA an island in Rio de Janeiro StateVIRGULA southeastern BrazilVIRGULA from October 2000 to September 2001. Breeding occurred all year roundVIRGULA but the presence of females and clutches was affected by rain from the previous days. Clutches had an aggregate distributionVIRGULA because they were mainly laid on lentic waters (with slow water flow). Rain affected the availabilityVIRGULA stability and size of ponds. The high numbers of eggs per clutchVIRGULA and the fast development of eggs and larvae are influenced by an unpredictable environment. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Speciation without changes in genital shape: a case study on Brazilian pholcid spiders (Araneae: Pholcidae)
column5: [Inglês] Speciation in arthropods is usually coupled with marked changes in genital morphologyVIRGULA which explains the usefulness of genitalia in distinguishing closely related species. The present paper describes specimens that are assigned to separate species based on extreme size differences and colour pattern differencesVIRGULA but the shape of the genitalia is essentially identical. We argue that such cryptic species may be more common than currently assumedVIRGULA but if marked morphological (non-genital) differences are missingVIRGULA traditional taxonomic methodology is biased against discovering them. The two new species from the Brazilian Atlantic Forest are tentatively assigned to the genus Psilochorus: Psilochorus itaguyrussu n. sp. and Psilochorus ybytyriguara n. sp. (AU)

column5: [Inglês] Five new species and a new genus of terrestrial ostracods from Brazil are described: Callistocypris mckenziei sp. nov.VIRGULA Callistocypris rossettii sp. nov.VIRGULA Terrestricypris wurdigae sp. nov.VIRGULA Caaporacandona shornikovi gen. et sp. nov. and Caaporacandona iguassuensis gen. et sp. nov. This is the first time that Callistocypris ShornikovVIRGULA 1980 and Terrestricypris ShornikovVIRGULA 1980 have been found since their original description from the Solomon Islands. The family Terrestricyprididae Shornikov is here lowered to the rank of tribe within the CandoninaePONTOCOMMA this tribe comprises TerrestricyprisVIRGULA Terrestricandona Danielopol & BetschVIRGULA 1980 (from Madagascar) and Caaporacandona gen. nov. Putative heterochronic character evolution within this tribe (in valves A1 and A2) is compared to a parallel evolutionary pathway in another group of terrestrial ostracodsVIRGULA the Mesocypridini. The similarity between the terrestrial ostracod faunas of Brazil and the Western Pacific Islands (including New Zealand) and the dissimilarity between those of Africa and South America is indicated. The putative causality of the prevalence of asexual reproduction in terrestrial ostracods is briefly discussed. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Ixodes (Ixodes) pararicinus Keirans & CliffordVIRGULA 1985 (Acari: Ixodidae): description of the immature stagesVIRGULA distributionVIRGULA hosts and medical/veterinary importance
column5: [Inglês] The immature stages of the Neotropical tick Ixodes (Ixodes) pararicinus Keirans & CliffordVIRGULA 1985 are described from specimens in a laboratory colony initiated from engorged females collected on cattle and larvae fed on mice and chickens. AdditionallyVIRGULA immature stages of I. pararicinus collected on wild mice and birds in Uruguay and Argentina were compared with specimens from the laboratory colony. A taxonomic key to the nymphs of the species of the ricinus complex established in the Western Hemisphere is presented. The distribution of I. pararicinus comprises ArgentinaVIRGULA Colombia and UruguayVIRGULA but it is also probably established in BoliviaVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA Chile and Peru. Most adult ticks of this species have been found on introduced domestic artiodactylesVIRGULA although Neotropical deer species must have been the ancestral host. Larvae and nymphs of I. pararicinus have also been found on sigmodontine rodents and passeriform birds. Although I. pararicinus is a member of the ricinus complexVIRGULA which contains the main vectors of Borrelia burgdorferi (sensu lato)VIRGULA there are few studies concerning its potential for pathogen transmission. column4: [Inglês] Placentation in the paca (Agouti paca L)
column5: [Inglês] The paca is a South American rodent with potential as a commercial food animal. We examined paca placenta as part of a wider effort to understand the reproductive biology of this species. Methods: Thirteen specimens between midgestation and term of pregnancy were studied by light and transmission electron microscopy. Results: The placenta is divided into several lobes separated by interlobular trophoblast. Maternal arterial channels and fetal veins are found at the centre of each lobe. In the labyrinthVIRGULA maternal blood flows through trophoblast-lined lacunae in close proximity to the fetal capillaries. The interhaemal barrier is of the haemomonochorial type with a single layer of syncytiotrophoblast. Caveolae occur in the apical membrane of the syncytiotrophoblast and recesses in the basal membraneVIRGULA but there is no evidence of transtrophoblastic channels. The interlobular areas consist of cords of syncytiotrophoblast defining maternal blood channels that drain the labyrinth. Yolk sac endoderm covers much of the fetal surface of the placenta. The subplacenta comprises cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast. There are dilated intercellular spaces between the cytotrophoblasts and lacunae lined by syncytiotrophoblast. In the junctional zone between subplacenta and deciduaVIRGULA there are nests of multinucleated giant cells with vacuolated cytoplasm. The entire placenta rests on a pedicle of maternal tissue. An inverted yolk sac placenta is also present. The presence of small vesicles and tubules in the apical membrane of the yolk sac endoderm and larger vesicles in the supranuclear region suggest that the yolk sac placenta participates in maternal-fetal transfer of protein. Conclusion: The paca placenta closely resembles that of other hystricomorph rodents. The lobulated structure allows for a larger exchange area and the development of precocial young. (AU)

column4: [Português] Circadian rhythm of anti-fungal prenylated chromene in leaves of Piper aduncum
column5: [Inglês] Leaves of Piper aduncum accumulate the anti-fungal chromenes methyl 2VIRGULA2-dimethyl-2H-1-chromene-6-carboxylate (1) and methyl 2VIRGULA2-dimethyl-8-(3 2-methyl-2 2-butenyl)-2H-1-chromene-6-carboxylate (2). The enzymatic formation of 2 from dimethylallyl diphosphate and 1 was investigated using cell-free extracts of the title plant. An HPLC assay for the prenylation reaction was developed and the enzyme activity measured in the protein extracts. The prenyltransferase that catalyses the transfer of the dimethylallyl group to C-2 2 of  1 was soluble and required dimethylallyl diphosphate as the prenyl donor. In the leavesVIRGULA the biosynthesis of the prenylated chromene 2 was time-regulated and prenyltransferase activity depended upon circadian variation. Preliminary characterisation and purification experiments on the prenyltransferase from P. aduncum have been performed. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Riffle and pool fish communities in a large stream of southeastern Brazil
column5: [Português] A estrutura das comunidades de peixes de um poço e uma corredeira do ribeirão Santa Bárbara é descrita. Esse é um ribeirão de quinta ordemVIRGULA afluente direto do rio Tietê no sistema do Alto rio Paraná. Trinta e três espéciesVIRGULA de nove famílias e três ordensVIRGULA foram capturadas nos dois meso-hábitats: 31 no poço e 18 na corredeira. CharaciformesVIRGULA Siluriformes e Perciformes apresentaram o maior número de espécies nos dois meso-hábitats. As famílias Characidae e Loricariidae foram as mais ricas em espéciesVIRGULA seguidas por CichlidaeVIRGULA no poçoVIRGULA e por ParodontidaeVIRGULA na corredeira. A maioria das espécies foi acidentalVIRGULA 17 no poço e dez na corredeiraPONTOCOMMA somente seis espécies foram constantes nos dois meso-hábitats. As maiores diversidade e uniformidade ocorreram no poço. A variação sazonal no poço e na corredeira foi altaVIRGULA com o poço apresentando uma grande substituição de espéciesVIRGULA que pode ser devida à proximidade com o canal principal do rio Tietê. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The structure of the fish communities of a pool and a rapid in the ribeirão Santa Bárbara is described. This stream of 5th order is a direct tributary of the rio Tietê in the system of the upper rio Paraná. Thirty three speciesVIRGULA from nine families and three ordersVIRGULA were referred in the two mesohabitats: the pool with 31 speciesVIRGULA and the rapid with 18. Orders CharaciformesVIRGULA SiluriformesVIRGULA and Perciformes presented the greatest number of species in the two mesohabitats. The families Characidae and Loricariidae were the most speciousVIRGULA followed by Cichlidae in the poolVIRGULA and by Parodontidae in the rapid. Most species were accidentalVIRGULA 17 in the poolVIRGULA and 10 in the rapidVIRGULA and only six were constant in the two mesohabitats. The greatest diversity and evenness occurred in the pool. The seasonal variation for both assemblages was highVIRGULA with the pool having a high turnover of species that could be due to the proximity with main channel of the rio Tietê. (AU)

column4: [Português] Influência de vegetação vizinha na distribuição de ácaros em seringal (Hevea brasiliensis Muell. Arg.VIRGULA Euphorbiaceae) em São José do Rio PretoVIRGULA SPVIRGULA [Inglês] Influence of neighboring vegetation in the distribution of mites in a rubber tree culture (Hevea brasiliensis Muell. Arg.VIRGULA Euphorbiaceae) in São José do Rio PretoVIRGULA SPVIRGULA Brazil
column5: [Português] Existem poucos estudos sobre a influência de vegetação vizinha na ocorrência e distribuição de ácaros em monoculturas. No presente estudo foi analizada a influência de duas áreas diferentes (fragmento de mata e pastagem) sobre a acarofauna de um cultivo de seringueira. Três linhas foram estabelecidasVIRGULA uma na borda com o fragmento de mataVIRGULA uma no interior do seringal e uma na borda com a área de pastagem. Cinco plantas foram selecionadas em cada linha e 10 folhas de cada planta foram analisadas. No total foram registrados 159.011 ácaros de 19 espéciesVIRGULA pertencentes a 12 famílias. TodosVIRGULA com exceção dos exemplares de Calacarus heveae FeresVIRGULA contados diretamente nos folíolosVIRGULA foram montados em lâminas de microscopia com o meio de Hoyer. C. heveae foi a espécie mais abundante e freqüente (99VIRGULA1%)VIRGULA sendo que sua maior distribuição ocorreu na linha central e a menor na linha próxima ao fragmento de mata. Devido à dominância dessa espécieVIRGULA a diversidade e a uniformidade foram baixas. As espécies predadoras apresentaram maior abundância na linha mais próxima ao fragmento de mataVIRGULA sugerindo um possível deslocamento dessas espécies entre a mata e o cultivo. Esses dados indicam que a vegetação nativa influenciou a acarofauna no monocultivo e que sua presença deveria ser considerada nos programas de manejo de pragas. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] There are few studies about the neighboring vegetation influence on the mites occurrence and distribution in monocultures. In the present study we analyzed the influence of two different areas (forest fragment and pasture) about mite fauna of a rubber tree culture. Three lines were establishedVIRGULA one in the edge with the forest fragmentVIRGULA one in the interior of the rubber tree culture and one at the edge with the pasture area. In each lineVIRGULA five plants were selected and 10 leaves for each plant were analyzed. The total number of mites sampled was 159VIRGULA011 of 19 species belonging to 12 families. All the mitesVIRGULA except Calacarus heveae FeresVIRGULA which were direct counted on the leafletsVIRGULA were mounted in microscopy slides using Hoyer medium. C. heveae was the most abundant and frequent species (99.1%)VIRGULA having its greatest abundance in the central line and its smallest in the line closest to the native forest fragment. Due to dominance of this speciesVIRGULA the diversity and uniformity of the mite fauna were low. The predatory species presented higher abundance in the line close to the forest fragmentVIRGULA suggesting a possible dispersion from this vegetation to the culture. These data indicated that native neighboring vegetation have influenced the mite fauna of the monoculture and that its presence should be considered in pest management programs. (AU)

column4: [Português] Ácaros (Acari) de dois sistemas de cultivo da seringueira no noroeste do estado de São PauloVIRGULA [Inglês] Mites (Acari) of two cultivation systems adopted in northwestern State São Paulo
column5: [Português] A cultura da seringueira (Hevea brasiliensis Muell. Agr.) vem se expandindo consideravelmente no noroeste do estado de São Paulo. O objetivo deste trabalho foi avaliar a fauna de ácaros em dois sistemas comuns de cultivo nessa regiãoVIRGULA um em monocultivo e outro em consórcio com gariroba (Syagrus oleracea (Mart.) Becc. O estudo foi conduzido entre maio de 2002 e abril de 2003VIRGULA tomando-se amostras mensais de 150 folíolos de seringueira de cada plantação e 150 folíolos de gariroba. As faunas dos dois sistemas foram semelhantesPONTOCOMMA os números de espéciesVIRGULA gêneros e famíliasVIRGULA assim como as famílias mais diversas e mais abundantes foram semelhantes entre eles. Dezoito espécies ocorreram exclusivamente em plantas de gariroba. O número de ácaros sobre estas foi consideravelmente menorVIRGULA mas a riqueza de espécies foi maior que em seringueiras. Dentre as espécies mais freqüentes e abundantes em seringueiraVIRGULA Eutetranychus banksi (McGregor) e Pronematus sp. foram as únicas também freqüentes em garirobaVIRGULA porém bem menos abundantes. Nenhum dos predadores abundantes em seringueira (Zetzellia aff. yustiVIRGULA Euseius citrifolius Denmark & MumaVIRGULA Pronematus sp. e Spinibdella sp.) foi abundante em gariroba. O fungo Hirsutella thompsonii Fisher foi o único patógeno de ácaros encontrado neste estudoVIRGULA atacando Calacarus heveae Feres. AparentementeVIRGULA na forma como cultivada na regiãoVIRGULA a gariroba não constitui um reservatório adequado dos ácaros predadores mais importantes em seringueira. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The cultivation of rubber trees (Hevea brasiliensis Muell. Agr.) has increased considerably in northwestern State of São Paulo. The objective of this work was to evaluate the mite fauna in two cultivation systems commonly found in this regionVIRGULA one in monocrop and other in which it is intercropped with "gariroba"VIRGULA Syagrus oleracea (Mart.) Becc. The study was conducted between May 2002 and April 2003VIRGULA taking monthly samples of 150 leaflets of rubber tree of each plantation and 150 leaflets of gariroba. The faunas of the two systems were similarPONTOCOMMA the numbers of speciesVIRGULA genera and familiesVIRGULA as well as the most diverse and abundant families were also similar. Eighteen species were found exclusively on gariroba. The number of mites on the latter was considerably smaller but species richness was larger than on rubber tree. Of the most frequent and abundant mites on rubbe treeVIRGULA Eutetranychus banksi (McGregor) and Pronematus sp. were the only ones also frequent on garirobaVIRGULA but much less abundant. None of the predators abundant on rubber tree (Zetzellia aff. yustiVIRGULA Euseius citrifolius Denmark & MumaVIRGULA Pronematus sp. e Spinibdella sp.) were significantly abundant on gariroba. The fungus Hirsutella thompsonii Fisher was the only mite pathogen found in this studyVIRGULA attacking Calacarus heveae Feres. ApparentlyVIRGULA in the way it is cultivated in the regionVIRGULA gariroba does not represent an adequate reservoir of the most important predatory mites on rubber tree. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Phylogenetic relationships of the new world Troidini swallowtails (Lepidoptera: Papilionidae) based on COIVIRGULA COIIVIRGULA and EF-1alpha genes
column5: [Inglês] A phylogeny of the Neotropical members of the Tribe Troidini (Lepidoptera: Papilionidae) was obtained with sequences of three protein-coding genes: two mitochondrial (COI and COII)VIRGULA and one nuclear (EF-1 alpha). Parsimony and Bayesian analyses of 33 taxa resulted in very similar trees regardless of method used with the 27 troidines always forming a monophyletic clade. Within TroidiniVIRGULA the genus Battus is sister group to the remaining troidinesVIRGULA followed by a clade formed by the Paleotropical taxa (here represented by three exemplars). The genus Euryades is the next branchVIRGULA and sister group of Parides. The genus Parides is monophyleticVIRGULA and is divided into four main groups by Maximum Parsimony analysisVIRGULA with the most basal group composed of tailed species restricted to SE Brazil. Character optimization of ecological and morphological traits over the phylogeny proposed for troidines indicated that the use of several species of Aristolochia is ancestral over the use of few or a single host-plant. For the other three charactersVIRGULA the ancestral states were the absence of long tailsVIRGULA forest as the primary habitat and oviposition solitary or in loose group of several eggs. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] New anti-alzheimer drugs from biodiversity: the role of the natural acetylcholinesterase inhibitors
column5: [Inglês] Alzheimers disease (AD) is progressive neurodegenerative pathology with severe economic and social impact. There is currently no cureVIRGULA although cholinesterase inhibitors provide effective temporary relief of symptoms in some patients. NowadaysVIRGULA drug research and development are based on the cholinergic hypothesis that supports the cognition improvement by regulation of the synthesis and release of acetylcholine in the brain. There are only four commercial medicines approved for treatment of ADVIRGULA and natural products have played an important alternative role in the research for new acetylcholinesterase inhibitorsVIRGULA as exemplified through the discovery of galantamine. This profile conducts us to give in this paper an overview relating the several classes of natural products with anti-cholinesterasic activity as potential templates to the design of new selective and powerful anti-Alzheimer drugs. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Morphological correlates of incipient arboreality and ornithophagy in island pitvipersVIRGULA and the phylogenetic position of Bothrops insularis
column5: [Inglês] Morphological differences between two semi-arborealVIRGULA bird-eating island pitvipersVIRGULA Bothrops insularis and Gloydius shedaoensisVIRGULA and their mainland relatives were investigated.Mitochondrial DNA sequence data for two genes show B. insularis to be rooted within B. jararaca. Bothrops insularis has a more anterior heartVIRGULA a relatively longer tailVIRGULA a longer headVIRGULA and shorter fangs than B. jararaca. The greater head length is paralleled in the ecologically similar G. shedaoensis. Increased head size may represent an adaptation to the abundance of larger food items (migratory passerine birds)VIRGULA providing a selective advantage to snakes able to switch to larger prey at an earlier age. FurthermoreVIRGULA B. insularis and G. shedaoensis have converged on similar body sizes from opposite ancestral states. Other charactersVIRGULA including fang lengthVIRGULA tail length and size of neonates do not show parallel variation in G. shedaoensis and B. insularisVIRGULA suggesting that caution is required when interpreting character state shifts coinciding with ecological shifts in a single species only. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] The inguinal macroglands of the frog Physalaemus nattereri (Leptodactylidae): structureVIRGULA toxic secretion and relationship with deimatic behavior
column5: [Inglês] Amphibian skin is characterized by the presence of mucous glandsVIRGULA related to cutaneous breathingVIRGULA reproduction and water balanceVIRGULA and granular glandsVIRGULA related to the production of toxins used in defence. In some species the granular glands can form accumulations in certain regions of the body. This is the case for inguinal macroglands of the leptodactylid frog Physalaemus nattereriVIRGULA where these structures form a pair of black discs associated with deimatic behaviour. The morphology of the inguinal macroglands and their secretion were studied in this species and correlated to deimatic behaviour. The inguinal macroglands are formed from elongated granular glands thatVIRGULA in contrast with the granular glands of the rest of the skinVIRGULA have small spherical granules with a proteinic content. In the dermis of the whole bodyVIRGULA except for the inguinal macroglands and the inguinal regionVIRGULA a well-developed calcified dermal layer is observed. During deimatic behaviour these macroglands discourage a potential predator from attackingVIRGULA but if visual cues are insufficient and the predator persists in the attackVIRGULA a toxic secretion is eliminated in its mouth. This elimination is favoured by the absence of a calcified dermal layer in the macroglandsVIRGULA which makes the dermal region softer than the rest of the dorsal skin. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Acoustic repertoire and calling behavior of Scinax fuscomarginatus (AnuraVIRGULA Hylidae)
column5: [Inglês] Vocalizations are important in anuran communicationVIRGULA especially during the breeding season. Calling affects spatial organization of males at breeding sitesVIRGULA promotes attraction of new individuals to the chorusVIRGULA and attracts mature females for reproduction. We describe four distinct vocalizations (advertisement callsVIRGULA sporadic callsVIRGULA and two types of aggressive calls) emitted by adult males of Scinax fuscomarginatus. With the exception of the advertisement callVIRGULA the remaining descriptions are novel. We also describe calling sitesVIRGULA calling seasonVIRGULA and nightly calling activity. Fieldwork was made in a fragment of Cerrado (Estação Ecológica de Itirapina)VIRGULA Municipalities of Itirapina and BrotasVIRGULA State of São PauloVIRGULA southeastern Brazil. At this ecological stationVIRGULA S. fuscomarginatus exhibits a complex acoustic repertoireVIRGULA social interactions and a prolonged reproductive pattern similar to observations of congeneric species at other localities. column4: [Inglês] Faunistic similarity and historic biogeography of the harvestmen of southern and southeastern Atlantic rain forest of Brazil
column5: [Inglês] Harvestmen show a high degree of endemism in the Atlantic Rain Forest (eastern coast of Brazil). This biome shows the highest diversity of harvestmen inhabiting BrazilPONTOCOMMA 2/3 of the species are found in this area. Most of the species are distributed in a few thousand square kilometersVIRGULA almost always within one mountain range. The similarities of 26 localities were studiedVIRGULA including sites from the Brazilian savannaVIRGULA using data from recent collections (more than 8VIRGULA000 specimens) and published data. A cluster analysis using Sørensens Coefficient indicated a high degree of endemism of species of harvestmen (similarity indexes below 0.5). It resulted in six main clusters related to the large mountain ranges and near sites. A high variation in richness was observedPONTOCOMMA 4-64 species per locality. The distribution of 84 species of four recently reviewed subfamilies of Gonyleptidae (GoniosomatinaeVIRGULA CaelopyginaeVIRGULA Progonyleptoidellinae and Sodreaninae) was studied. Eleven areas of endemismVIRGULA with 3-14 endemic species eachVIRGULA were proposed. A primary Brooks Parsimony Analysis showed a possible first vicariant event splitting the fauna of two northern areas from the restVIRGULA and a second event splitting the fauna of southern areas (until 248350S) from those areas related to certain mountain ranges in the central Atlantic Rain Forest. The vicariant events were related to the uplifting of the Serra do Mar and the Serra da MantiqueiraVIRGULA and the appearance of large rivers and climatic changes. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Comparative bark anatomy of root and stem in Styrax camporum (Styracaceae)
column5: [Inglês] The bark of Styrax camporum Pohl (Styracaceae) differs anatomically in the root and stem. Stems have non-layered secondary phloemPONTOCOMMA longer sieve tubes with compoundVIRGULA scalariformVIRGULA inclined sieve platesPONTOCOMMA sclerified cells and brachysclereidsPONTOCOMMA a developed peridermVIRGULA and a non-persistent rhytidome. Prismatic crystalsVIRGULA starch grainsVIRGULA phenolic compounds and lipidic contents were observed in root and stem bark cells. The differences between the secondary phloem of root and stem are discussed. (AU)
