column4: [Inglês] Testing the functions of detritus stabilimenta in webs of Cyclosa fililineata and Cyclosa morretes (Araneae: Araneidae): do they attract prey or reduce the risk of predation?
column5: [Inglês] Spiders of the genus Cyclosa often add prey remains and other debris to their orb-webs. The function of silk decorations is generally associated with defense against predators or with the attraction of preyVIRGULA but few studies have focused on stabilimenta containing detritus. In this studyVIRGULA we used artificial webs with and without the detritus stabilimenta of two species of Cyclosa to investigate whether these structures increase the number of insects intercepted. Artificial models of spiders and stabilimenta were used to compare the frequency of attacks against different shapes. We also conducted choice experiments in laboratory to determine whether detritus columns attracted Drosophila melanogaster (Diptera: Drosophilidae) and Trigona angustula (Hymenoptera: ApidaeVIRGULA Meliponinae) to the webs. The frequency of interception in artificial webs with a stabilimentum was similar to that of webs without such structure. The taxonomic composition and biomass of insects were also similar in both types of artificial webs. The choice experiments showed no significant tendency in attraction to webs with a stabilimentum. HoweverVIRGULA models of spiders were attacked at a higher frequency than those simulating detritus columns and silk decorations. These findings argue against the prey attraction hypothesis and suggest that the addition of stabilimenta to webs of Cyclosa could reduce the intensity of predationVIRGULA possibly by disrupting the image of the spider's outline. (AU)

column4: [Português] Chironomidae (Diptera) em substratos artificiais num pequeno reservatório: Represa do MonjolinhoVIRGULA São CarlosVIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA BrasilVIRGULA [Inglês] Chironomidae (Diptera) on artificial substrates within a small reservoir: Represa do Monjolinho (São CarlosVIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA Brasil)
column5: [Português] O presente estudo teve como objetivo verificar possíveis diferenças taxonômicas e funcionais entre as assembléias de Chironomidae que colonizam substratos orgânicos e inorgânicos estruturalmente distintos. Substratos poliméricos (isopor e tela de náilon)VIRGULA minerais (pedra de argila expandida e areia grossa) e orgânicos vegetais (detritos de Scirpus cubensis e Cabomba piauhyensisPONTOCOMMA detritos de madeira)VIRGULA contidos em sacos de náilonVIRGULA foram submersos na Represa do Monjolinho. EstesVIRGULA após 30 diasVIRGULA foram retiradosVIRGULA lavados em peneira de malha de 0VIRGULA21 mm e os organismos retidos identificados sob microscópios estereoscópicos e/ou óptico. A análise de 3432 larvas indicou a presença de 17 unidades taxonômicas das quais Goeldichironomus neopictus foi predominanteVIRGULA com expressiva participação em todos os substratos (>73%). As análises de agrupamentos quantitativa (Distância Euclidiana) e qualitativa (Coeficiente de Jaccard) apontaram para diferentes arranjos. A primeira agrupou as assembléias que colonizaram areia e madeira (com maiores densidades numéricas e riqueza de táxons)VIRGULA os substratos poliméricos (isopor e tela de náilon) e os detritos de macrófitas. A segunda indicou maior semelhança entre as assembléias presentes nos substratos orgânicos vegetais e nos minerais. Em contraposiçãoVIRGULA devido à elevada representatividade de coletores em todos os substratos (>95%)VIRGULA as assembléias apresentaram-se funcionalmente similares. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The present study aimed to verify possible taxonomic and functional differences between the Chironomidae assemblages that colonize organic and inorganic substrates of different structures. Polymers (polystyrene and nylon mesh)VIRGULA minerals (pyro clay and sand) and organic vegetable substrates (wood branches and litter of Scirpus cubensis and Cabomba piauhyensis) were immersed in Monjolinho Reservoir water column in nylon mesh bags. After 30 daysVIRGULA they were taken and washed through a 0.21 mm mesh sieve. The organisms retained by the sieve were identified under stereoscopic and/or optic microscopes. The 3432 larvae analyzed pointed to the presence of 17 taxonomic units. Goeldichironomus neopictus was the predominant speciesVIRGULA colonizing abundantly all the substrates (>73%). The quantitative (Euclidean Distance) and qualitative (Jaccard Coefficient) cluster analyses pointed to different groups. The former grouped the assemblages that had colonized sand and wood branches (substrates with the greatest numeric densities and richness)VIRGULA polymeric substrates (polystyrene and nylon mesh) and macrophyte litters. Jaccard Coefficient pointed to the greatest similarity of the assemblages present on organic vegetable and on mineral substrates. On the other handVIRGULA the assemblages were functionally similar because of the high participation of collectors on all the substrates (>95%). (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Flower-headsVIRGULA herbivoresVIRGULA and their parasitoids: food web structure along a fertility gradient
column5: [Inglês] The ways in which a soil fertility gradient affects three trophic level food webs defined by plants of the family AsteraceaeVIRGULA flower-head herbivoresVIRGULA and their parasitoids was investigated. It was tested how the fertility gradient alters: (i) the abundance and richness of plantsVIRGULA herbivoresVIRGULA and their parasitoidsVIRGULA (ii) the herbivore-plant ratioVIRGULA and (iii) the connectance of the plant-herbivore community matrix.  From April to May 2000VIRGULA plants and insects were sampled in 16 Brazilian Cerrado (sensu stricto) sites along a physiognomic gradient varying from open shrublands (cerrado) to closed woodlands (cerradão). Sites were objectively positioned along the physiognomic gradient by a single indexVIRGULA tree density. Sixty-seven per cent of the variation in tree density among sites was correlated to two principal components of a PCAVIRGULA representing gradients of soil fertility.  Asteraceae abundanceVIRGULA richnessVIRGULA and flower-head availability were negatively related to tree density due to their preference for sunny environmentsVIRGULA despite the surplus of soil nutrients. The abundance and richness of Diptera and LepidopteraVIRGULA the most important flower-head herbivoresVIRGULA were also negatively related to tree density. Parasitoid abundance decreased with tree densityPONTOCOMMA howeverVIRGULA the number of parasitoids per hosts was lower in cerradoVIRGULA suggesting that top-down forces are not getting stronger in more productive sitesVIRGULA as could be expected. Community allometry analyses showed that the herbivore to plant ratio was independent of community richness and did not respond to tree density. Connectance of the plant-herbivore matrix was dependent on the community matrix size. ProportionallyVIRGULA species-rich cerrado sites had fewer interactions than their species-poor counterparts. NeverthelessVIRGULA after removing the effect of the matrix sizeVIRGULA connectance was not related to tree density. Soil fertilityVIRGULA as the primary cause of the cerrado-cerradão physiognomic gradientVIRGULA strongly affected the abundance and richness of plantsVIRGULA herbivores and their parasitoidsPONTOCOMMA howeverVIRGULA it had little effect on important community attributesVIRGULA such as the herbivore-plant ratio and the connectance of the plant-herbivore matrix. column4: [Inglês] Conservation of terrestrial invertebrates and their habitats in Brazil
column5: [Inglês] As one of the world's prime megadiverse countriesVIRGULA Brazil holds an immense number of terrestrial invertebrates. Current knowledge of this biota is very heterogeneous. Several taxa are sufficiently well known to be used as indicators of ecological integrity or of endemism. The current Brazilian national and regional red lists include 130 terrestrial invertebrate speciesVIRGULA of which 42% are butterflies. These lists are contingent on available knowledgeVIRGULA and many taxa that are omitted certainly include species at risk. Knowledge of various biomes and habitats is also quite irregularVIRGULA with the Caatinga and Pantanal in need of more studyVIRGULA compared with the Atlantic ForestVIRGULA the AmazonVIRGULA and Cerrado. CanopyVIRGULA host-associatedVIRGULA and soil faunas also need further intensive study. Invertebrate conservation will be promoted more effectively by habitat preservation and management rather than single-species initiatives. To this endVIRGULA better geographic surveys of entire taxonomic or functional assemblages are needed. An improved understanding of the invertebrate role in ecosystem processes will strengthen enormously the case for their conservation. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Evaluation of Strychnos pseudoquina St. Hil. leaves extract on gastrointestinal activity in mice
column5: [Inglês] Strychnos pseudoquina ST. HIL. (Loganiaceae) was investigated for its ability to protect the gastric mucosa against injuries caused by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (piroxicam) and a necrotizing agent (HCl/EtOH) in mice. The MeOH extract and enriched alkaloidic fraction (EAF) provided significant protection in experimental models wheer used at doses of 250 and 1000 mg/kg. In vivo tests were carried out to evaluate for possible toxic effects and no mortality was observed up to the 5 g/kg dose level. Phytochemical investigation led to the isolation of a new indole alkaloidVIRGULA which elucidated the observed pharmacological effects. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Systematic review of the frog family hylidaeVIRGULA with special reference to hylinae: phylogenetic analysis and taxonomic revision
column5: [Inglês] Hylidae is a large family of AmericanVIRGULA AustralopapuanVIRGULA and temperate Eurasian treefrogs of approximately 870 known speciesVIRGULA divided among four subfamilies. Although some groups of Hylidae have been addressed phylogeneticallyVIRGULA a comprehensive phylogenetic analysis has never been presented. The first goal of this paper is to review the current state of hylid systematics. We focus on the very large subfamily Hylinae (590 species)VIRGULA evaluate the monophyly of named taxaVIRGULA and examine the evidential basis of the existing taxonomy. The second objective is to perform a phylogenetic analysis using mostly DNA sequence data in order to (1) test the monophyly of the HylidaePONTOCOMMA (2) determine its constituent taxaVIRGULA with special attention to the genera and species groups which form the subfamily HylinaeVIRGULA and c) propose a newVIRGULA monophyletic taxonomy consistent with the hypothesized relationships. We present a phylogenetic analysis of hylid frogs based on 276 terminalsVIRGULA including 228 hylids and 48 outgroup taxa. Included are exemplars of all but 1 of the 41 genera of Hylidae (of all four nominal subfamilies) and 39 of the 41 currently recognized species groups of the species-rich genus Hyla. The included taxa allowed us to test the monophyly of 24 of the 35 nonmonotypic genera and 25 species groups of Hyla. The phylogenetic analysis includes approximately 5100 base pairs from four mitochondrial (12SVIRGULA tRNA valineVIRGULA 16SVIRGULA and cytochrome b) and five nuclear genes (rhodopsinVIRGULA tyrosinaseVIRGULA RAG-1VIRGULA seventh in absentiaVIRGULA and 28S)VIRGULA and a small data set from foot musculature. Concurring with previous studiesVIRGULA the present analysis indicates that Hemiphractinae are not related to the other three hylid subfamilies. It is therefore removed from the family and tentatively considered a subfamily of the paraphyletic Leptodactylidae. Hylidae is now restricted to HylinaeVIRGULA PelodryadinaeVIRGULA and Phyllomedusinae. Our results support a sister-group relationship between Pelodryadinae and PhyllomedusinaeVIRGULA which together form the sister taxon of Hylinae. AgalychnisVIRGULA PhyllomedusaVIRGULA LitoriaVIRGULA HylaVIRGULA OsteocephalusVIRGULA PhrynohyasVIRGULA PtychohylaVIRGULA ScinaxVIRGULA SmiliscaVIRGULA and Trachycephalus are not monophyletic. Within HylaVIRGULA the H. albomarginataVIRGULA H. albopunctataVIRGULA H. arboreaVIRGULA H. boansVIRGULA H. cinereaVIRGULA H. eximiaVIRGULA H. geographicaVIRGULA H. granosaVIRGULA H. microcephalaVIRGULA H. miotympanumVIRGULA H. tuberculosaVIRGULA and H. versicolor groups are also demonstrably nonmonophyletic. Hylinae is composed of four major clades. The first of these includes the Andean stream-breeding HylaVIRGULA AplastodiscusVIRGULA all Gladiator FrogsVIRGULA and a Tepuian clade. The second clade is composed of the 30-chromosome HylaVIRGULA LysapsusVIRGULA PseudisVIRGULA ScarthylaVIRGULA Scinax (including the H. uruguaya group)VIRGULA SphaenorhynchusVIRGULA and Xenohyla. The third major clade is composed of NyctimantisVIRGULA PhrynohyasVIRGULA PhyllodytesVIRGULA and all South American/West Indian casque-headed frogs: AparasphenodonVIRGULA ArgenteohylaVIRGULA CorythomantisVIRGULA OsteocephalusVIRGULA OsteopilusVIRGULA TepuihylaVIRGULA and Trachycephalus. The fourth major clade is composed of most of the Middle American/Holarctic species groups of Hyla and the genera AcrisVIRGULA AnothecaVIRGULA DuellmanohylaVIRGULA PlectrohylaVIRGULA PseudacrisVIRGULA PtychohylaVIRGULA PternohylaVIRGULA SmiliscaVIRGULA and Triprion. A new monophyletic taxonomy mirroring these results is presented where Hylinae is divided into four tribes. Of the species currently in HylaVIRGULA 297 of the 353 species are placed in 15 generaPONTOCOMMA of theseVIRGULA 4 are currently recognizedVIRGULA 4 are resurrected namesVIRGULA and 7 are new. Hyla is restricted to H. femoralis and the H. arboreaVIRGULA H. cinereaVIRGULA H. eximiaVIRGULA and H. versicolor groupsVIRGULA whose contents are redefined. Phrynohyas is placed in the synonymy of TrachycephalusVIRGULA and Pternohyla is placed in the synonymy of Smilisca. The genus Dendropsophus is resurrected to include all former species of Hyla known or suspected to have 30 chromosomes. Exerodonta is resurrected to include the former Hyla sumichrasti group and some members of the former H. miotympanum group. Hyloscirtus is resurrected for the former Hyla armataVIRGULA H. bogotensisVIRGULA and H. larinopygion groups. Tityus aba n. sp. belongs to the Tityusbahiensis group LourençoVIRGULA 2002 characterized by medium sized specimensVIRGULA ranging from five to seven cm in lengthVIRGULA reddish-brown or brownish coloration patterns and basal middle lamellae of female pectines not dilatated in most species. T. aba n. sp. is distinguished from T. stigmurus by the color of the prossomaVIRGULA which is almost blackVIRGULA by the higher number of pectinal teeth and by the larger body size. The males are distinguished from the females by the slender pedipalps and more dilatated metasomal segments IV and V. (AU)VIRGULA [Português] Uma nova espécie do gênero Tityus C.L. column4: [Inglês] The role of forest structureVIRGULA fragment size and corridors in maintaining small mammal abundance and diversity in an Atlantic forest landscape
column5: [Inglês] Using the abundance and distribution of small mammals at 26 sites in an Atlantic forest landscapeVIRGULA we investigated how species abundance and alpha and beta diversity are affected by fragment size and the presence of corridors. To account for the variability in forest structure among fragmentsVIRGULA we described and minimized the influence of foliage density and stratification on small mammal data. Sites were distributed among three categories of fragment size and in continuous forest. For small and medium-sized categoriesVIRGULA we considered isolated fragments and fragments connected by corridors to larger remnants. Small mammal abundance and alpha and beta diversity were regressed against site scores from the first axis of a Principal Component Analysis on forest structure variables. Residuals were used in analyses of variance to compare fragment size and connectivity categories. Forest structure influenced total abundance and abundance of some species individuallyVIRGULA but not the diversity of small mammal communities. Total abundance and alpha diversity were lower in small and medium-sized fragments than in large fragments and continuous forestVIRGULA and in isolated compared to connected fragments. Three species were less commonVIRGULA but none was more abundant in smaller fragments. At least one species was more abundant in connected compared to isolated fragments. Beta diversity showed an opposite relationship to fragment size and corridorsVIRGULA increasing in small and isolated fragments. Results highlight the importance of secondary forest for the conservation of tropical faunaVIRGULA the hyper-dynamism of small isolated fragments and the potential of corridors to buffer habitat fragmentation effects in tropical landscapes. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Insects on plants: diversity of herbivore assemblages revisited
column5: [Inglês] The diversity and composition of herbivore assemblages was a favored theme for community ecology in the 1970s and culminated in 1984 with Insects on Plants by StrongVIRGULA Lawton and Southwood.We scrutinize findings since thenVIRGULA considering analyses of country-wide insect-host catalogsVIRGULA field studies of local herbivore communitiesVIRGULA and comparative studies at different spatial scales. Studies in tropical forests have advanced significantly and offer new insights into stratification and host specialization of herbivores. Comparative and long-term data sets are still scarceVIRGULA which limits assessment of general patterns in herbivore richness and assemblage structure. Methods of community phylogenetic analysisVIRGULA complex networksVIRGULA spatial and among-host diversity partitioningVIRGULA and metacommunity models represent promising approaches for future work. column4: [Inglês] Pesky gnats: ridding Dipteran classification of the Nematocera
column5: [Inglês] The classification of the lower Diptera is reviewed. Published papers on the relationships between lower Dipteran clades since the 1960s agree that the Nematocera is a paraphyletic taxon. A new classification of the Diptera is proposed in which the usual infraorders of Diptera are raised to subordinal rankVIRGULA and the name Nematocera is abandoned. Possible future changes in Diptera phylogeny are considered and their consequences for diptera classification are discussed. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Successional changes in cerrado and cerrado/forest ecotonal vegetation in western São Paulo stateVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA 1962-2000
column5: [Inglês] Surveys over a period of 38 years have shown a rapid successional change in the remaining areas of cerrado vegetation in western São Paulo State. Cerradão (the denseVIRGULA tallVIRGULA forest form of cerrado (sensu lato)) and cerrado/Atlantic forest ecotonal vegetation have replaced more open forms (such as campo cerrado) during this period. An aerial photographic survey in 1962 showed 75% cerrado (sensu stricto)VIRGULA 16% campo cerradoVIRGULA and only 9% cerradãoVIRGULA while a survey combining Landsat imaging of 1992 with aerial photography of 1984 gave 69%VIRGULA 0.6%VIRGULA and 30.5% respectively for the same physiognomies. Visiting 10% of the sites of the latter survey in 2000 showed that cerradão had become the dominant vegetation of 68% of them. In a particular 180 ha site in Assis municipalityVIRGULA cerradão increased from 12.0 to 41.4% of the area in 22 years. Reduction of anthropic pressuresVIRGULA such as fire and cattle-grazingVIRGULA is considered responsible for these rapid changes. Conservation issues and research priorities related to these changes are discussed and proposed. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Structure in plant - animal interaction assemblages
column5: [Inglês] We present a comprehensive approach to detect pattern in assemblages of plant and animal species linked by interactions such as pollinationVIRGULA frugivory or herbivory. Simple structural models produce gradientVIRGULA compartmented or nested patterns of interactionPONTOCOMMA intermediate patterns between a gradient and compartments are possibleVIRGULA and nesting within compartments produces a combined model. Interaction patterns can be visualized and analyzed either as matricesVIRGULA as bipartite networks or as multivariate sets through correspondence analysis. We argue that differences among patterns represent outcomes of distinct evolutionary and ecological processes in these highly diversified assemblages. Instead of choosing one model a prioriVIRGULA assemblages should be probed for a suite of patterns. A plant -pollinator assemblage exemplifies a simple nested patternVIRGULA whereas a plant - herbivore assemblage illustrates a compound pattern with nested structures within compartments. Compartmentation should reflect coevolutionary histories and constraintsVIRGULA whereas differences in species abundance or dispersal may generate nestedness. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Temporal stability in fishing spots: conservation and co-management in brazilian artisanal coastal fisheries
column5: [Inglês] The management of small-scale artisanal fisheries in Brazil should be a priority because of their importance as a source of food for internal markets and their location in sites with high biodiversityVIRGULA such as the Atlantic Forest coast. Fishing spotsVIRGULA territoriesVIRGULA and sea tenure have been widely studied within artisanal fisheriesVIRGULA andVIRGULA in this studyVIRGULA a fishing spot of this type may be a defended area or an area that imposes rules for usersVIRGULA making the exclusion of outsiders feasibleVIRGULA or even a place in which fishing occurs with some exclusivity. This analysis takes into account the importance of fishing areas for the conservation of artisanal fishing in Brazil and the relative temporal stability of these areas. In particularVIRGULA examples of the use of the marine space on the coast of Brazil in areas such as Rio de JaneiroVIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA and Bahia States are presented. Fishing spots used by artisanal fishers were marked using a Global Positioning System (GPS). An informal division of the marine space and high temporal stabilityVIRGULA often in the range of 10-30 yrVIRGULA in the use of the fishing spots were found. For some fishing areasVIRGULA information published in the 1960s provided a relevant comparison for the current use of the fishing spots at sea. Such information is very helpful for the management of artisanal fishing in Brazil because tourism has increased in some areasVIRGULA recreational fishers have been fishing in marine spots used by artisanal fishersVIRGULA and industrial fishers are spread over a wide range of the marine space in these coastal waters. This stability in the use of marine space among artisanal fishers plus local rules support the case for local co-management of artisanal fisheries. Reserving areas for artisanal fishers and understanding the behavior of other users are essential aspects for the management and conservation of artisanal fishing in Brazil. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Mutagenic activity promoted by amentoflavone and methanolic extract of Byrsonima crassa Niedenzu
column5: [Inglês] Byrsonima crassa is a plant pertaining to the Brazilian central savannah-like belt of vegetation and popularly used for the treatment of gastric dysfunctions and diarrhoea. The methanol extract contains catechinVIRGULA tanninsVIRGULA terpenes and flavonoidsPONTOCOMMA both mutagenic potential and antioxidant properties have been ascribed to flavonoids. The mutagenicity of some flavonoids is believed to be associated with the formation of reactive oxygen species and seems to depend on the number and position of hydroxyl groups. The acetate fraction showed strong signs of mutagenicity without S9VIRGULA suggesting that in this enriched fraction were concentrated the compounds that induced mutagenic activity. column4: [Inglês] Phylogenetic relationships among the Ithomiini (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae) inferred from one mitochondrial and two nuclear gene regions
column5: [Inglês] A phylogenetic hypothesis for the tribe Ithomiini (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae: Danainae) is presentedVIRGULA based on sequences of the mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunits I and II (COI-COII) region and regions of the nuclear genes wingless and Elongation factor 1-alpha. column4: [Inglês] Can the aqueous decoction of mango flowers be used as an antiulcer agent?
column5: [Inglês] This study was designed to determine the effect of Mangifera indica flowers decoctionVIRGULA on the acute and subacute models of induced ulcer in mice and rats. A single oral administration of the aqueous decoction (AD) from M. indica up to a dose of 5 g/kgVIRGULA p.o. did not produce any signs or symptom of toxicity in the treated animals. The oral pre-treatment with AD (250VIRGULA 500 and 1000 mg/kg) in rats with gastric lesions induced by ethanolVIRGULA decreased the gastric lesions from 89.0±6.71 (control group) to 9.25±2.75VIRGULA 4.50±3.30 and 0VIRGULA respectively. Pretreatment with AD (250VIRGULA 500 and 1000 mg/kg) to mice with HCl/ethanol- or stress-induced gastric lesions resulted in a dose-dependent significant decrease of lesion index. In the piroxicam-induced gastric lesionsVIRGULA the gastroprotective effect of AD was reducing with the increase of the AD dose. In the pylorusligatureVIRGULA AD (p.o.) significantly decreased the acid output indicating the antisecretory property involved in the gastroprotective effect of M. indica. Treatment with AD during 14 consecutive days significantly accelerated the healing process in subacute gastric ulcer induced by acetic acid in rats. Pretreatment with N-nitro-l-arginine methyl ester (l-NAME)VIRGULA an inhibitor of NO-synthaseVIRGULA did not abolish the gastroprotective effects (99% with saline versus 80% with l-NAME) of AD against ethanol-induced gastric lesions. Pretreatment with N-ethylmaleimide (NEM)VIRGULA a blocker of endogenous sulphydryl groupVIRGULA significantly abolished the protective effects of AD against ethanol-induced gastric ulcers (95% with saline versus 47% with NEM). Phytochemical screening showed the presence of steroidsVIRGULA triterpenesVIRGULA phenolic compounds and flavonoids. Estimation of the global polyphenol content in the AD was performed by Folin-Ciocalteu method and showed approximately 53% of total phenolic on this extract. These findings indicate the potential gastroprotective and ulcer-healing properties of aqueous decoction of M. indica flowers and further support its popular use in gastrointestinal disorders in Caribbean. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Optimisation of conditions for the extraction of casearins from Casearia sylvestris using response surface methodology
column5: [Inglês] Optimal conditions for the extraction of casearins from Casearia sylvestris were determined using response surface methodology. The maceration and sonication extraction techniques were performed using a 3 x n3 x 3 full factorial design including three acidity conditionsVIRGULA three solvents of different polarities and three extraction times. The yields and selectivities of the extraction of casearins were significantly influenced by acidity conditions. Taking into account all variables testedVIRGULA the optimal conditions for maceration extraction were estimated to involve treatment with dichloromethane saturated with ammonium hydroxide for 26 h. Similar yields and selectivities for casearins were determined for sonication extraction using the same solvent but for the much shorter time of 1 h. The best results for stabilisation of the fresh plant material were obtained using leaves that had been oven dried at 40¢XC for 48 h. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Effects of physical habitat degradation on the stream fish assemblage structure in a pasture region
column5: [Inglês] We compared the fish assemblage structure from streams with different intensities of physical habitat degradation and chemical water pollution by domestic sewage in southeastern Brazil. Eight streams (R1-R8) showing less disturbed or more disturbed conditions of chemical water quality and of physical habitat quality were selected. Cumulative abundance and biomassVIRGULA combined in ABC plotsVIRGULA revealed a) biomass curves above the abundance curvesVIRGULA represented by the streams R1-R2 (water and habitat less disturbed) and R5-R6 (water more disturbed and habitat less disturbed)PONTOCOMMA and b) biomass curves below the abundance curvesVIRGULA represented by the streams R3-R4 (water less disturbed and habitat more disturbed) and R7-R8 (water and habitat more disturbed). The quantitative structure of the ichthyofauna showed significant correspondence with physical habitat condition but not with chemical water quality. The most significant species to cause the dissimilarity between less disturbed and more disturbed physical habitats was the exotic Poecilia reticulata. Such results indicate that in the focused region-with little influence of industrial pollutionVIRGULA noncritical domestic sewage dischargeVIRGULA and soil predominantly used for pasture-streams with high physical habitat integrity possess a differently structured ichthyofauna than streams with relatively low physical habitat integrityVIRGULA reinforcing the importance of the physical habitat quality and riparian conservation along these water coursesVIRGULA warranting the conservation of these systems. IndeedVIRGULA our results also reinforce the importance of including biotic descriptorsVIRGULA particularly of the ichthyo-faunaVIRGULA in water-monitoring programs designed to reveal signs of human interference. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Chromosomal analysis of the leptodactylids Pleurodema diplolistris and Physalaemus nattereri (AmphibiaVIRGULA Anura)
column5: [Inglês] Detailed characterizations of the karyotypes of the Brazilian leptodactylid frogs Pleurodema diplolistrisVIRGULA the only species of Pleurodema not studied cytogenetically so farVIRGULA and Physalaemus nattereriVIRGULA a species in the Ph. biligonigerus groupVIRGULA are presented. Both karyotypes had 2n = 22 and their chromosomes had a very similar morphologyVIRGULA except for pair 11VIRGULA which was metacentric in Pl. diplolistris and telocentric in Ph. nattereri. The localization of nucleolar organizer regions (NORs) and heterochromatic bands allowed the differentiation of chromosomes that were morphologically indistinguishable between these speciesVIRGULA such as pairs 1VIRGULA 3 and 10VIRGULA which showed interstitial C-bands in Ph. nattereriVIRGULA and pair 8VIRGULA that had an NOR and an adjacent C-band in Pl. diplolistris. Pair 8 also has NOR-bearing chromosomes in many other Pleurodema species. HoweverVIRGULA in these speciesVIRGULA the NOR is located proximal to the centromere on the short armVIRGULA while in Pl. diplolistris it occurred distally on the long armVIRGULA a condition that may be considered a derived state. In Ph. nattereriVIRGULA the NOR occurred on chromosome 11 and differed from the other species of the Ph. biligonigerus group. In contrastVIRGULA C-banding revealed a heterochromatic block near the centromere on the short arm of pair 3VIRGULA a characteristic common to all members of this group of Physalaemus. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Ticks (Ixodidae) on humans in South America
column5: [Inglês] Twenty eight species of Ixodidae have been found on man in South America (21 AmblyommaVIRGULA 1 BoophilusVIRGULA 2 DermacentorVIRGULA 2 HaemaphysalisVIRGULA 1 Ixodes and 1 Rhipicephalus species). Most of them are rarely found on man. HoweverVIRGULA three species frequently parasitize humans in restricted areas of Argentina (A. neumanni reported from 46 localities)VIRGULA Uruguay (A. triste from 21 sites) and Argentina-Brazil (A. parvum from 27 localities). The most widespread ticks are A. cajennense (134 localities in ArgentinaVIRGULA BoliviaVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA ColombiaVIRGULA EcuadorVIRGULA French GuianaVIRGULA GuyanaVIRGULA ParaguayVIRGULA Suriname and Venezuela)VIRGULA A. ovale (37 localities in ArgentinaVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA EcuadorVIRGULA French GuianaVIRGULA GuyanaVIRGULA ParaguayVIRGULA Suriname and Venezuela) and A. oblongoguttatum (28 sites in BrazilVIRGULA ColombiaVIRGULA French GuianaVIRGULA GuyanaVIRGULA Suriname and Venezuela). Amblyomma aureolatum (18 localities in ArgentinaVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA French Guiana and Paraguay)VIRGULA A. cajennenseVIRGULA and A. triste are vectors of rickettsioses to man in South America. A better understanding of the respective roles of these and other tick species in transmitting pathogens to humans will require further local investigations. Amblyomma ticks should be the main subjects of these studies followed by species of BoophilusVIRGULA DermacentorVIRGULA Haemaphysalis and Rhipicephalus species. In contrast with North AmericaVIRGULA Europe and AsiaVIRGULA ticks of the genus Ixodes do not appear to be major players in transmitting diseases to human. IndeedVIRGULA there is only one record of an Ixodes collected while feeding on man for all South America. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Soil-leaf transfer of chemical elements for the Atlantic Forest
column5: [Inglês] Soil analysis could improve environmental studies since soil is the main source of chemical elements for plants. In this studyVIRGULA soil samples collected at 0-10 cm depth under tree crown projection were analyzed by INAA. Using the chemical composition of the leaf previously determinedVIRGULA the leaf-soil transfer factors of chemical elements could be estimated for the Atlantic Forest. Despite the variability of the intra-speciesVIRGULA the transfer factors were specific for some plant species due to their element accumulation in the leaves. Similar Br-Zn combined transfer factors were obtained for the species grouped according to habitats in relation to their position (understory or dominant species) in the forest canopy. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Atlantic Forest: a natural reservoir of chemical elements
column5: [Inglês] The accumulation of chemical elements in biological compartments is one of the strategies of tropical species to adapt to a low-nutrient soil. This study focuses on the Atlantic Forest because of its eco-environmental importance as a natural reservoir of chemical elements. About 20 elements were determined by INAA in leafVIRGULA soilVIRGULA litter and epiphyte compartments. There was no seasonality for chemical element concentrations in leavesVIRGULA which probably indicated the maintainance of chemical elements in this compartment. Considering the estimated quantitiesVIRGULA past deforestation events could have released large amounts of chemical elements to the environment. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Out of the Andes: patterns of diversification in clearwing butterflies
column5: [Inglês] Global biodiversity peaks in the tropical forests of the AndesVIRGULA a striking geological feature that has likely been instrumental in generating biodiversity by providing opportunities for both vicariant and ecological speciation. HoweverVIRGULA the role of these mountains in the diversification of insectsVIRGULA which dominate biodiversityVIRGULA has been poorly explored using phylogenetic methods. Here we study the role of the Andes in the evolution of a diverse Neotropical insect groupVIRGULA the clearwing butterflies. We used dated species-level phylogenies to investigate the time course of speciation and to infer ancestral elevation ranges for two diverse genera. We show that both genera likely originated at middle elevations in the Andes in the Middle MioceneVIRGULA contrasting with most published results in vertebrates that point to a lowland origin. Although we detected a signature of vicariance caused by the uplift of the Andes at the Miocene-Pliocene boundaryVIRGULA most sister species were parapatric without any obvious vicariant barrir. Combined with an overall decelerating speciation rateVIRGULA these results suggest an important role for ecological speciation and adaptive radiationVIRGULA rather than simple vicariance. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Nymphalid butterflies diversify following near demise at the Cretaceous/Tertiary boundary
column5: [Inglês] The butterfly family Nymphalidae contains some of the most important non-drosophilid insect model systems for evolutionary and ecological studiesVIRGULA yet the evolutionary history of the group has remained shrouded in mystery. We have inferred a robust phylogenetic hypothesis based on sequences of 10 genes and 235 morphological characters for exemplars of 400 of the 540 valid nymphalid genera representing all major lineages of the family. By dating the branching eventsVIRGULA we infer that Nymphalidae originated in the Cretaceous at 90 MaVIRGULA but that the ancestors of 10-12 lineages survived the end-Cretaceous catastrophe in the Neotropical and Oriental regions. Patterns of diversification suggest extinction of lineages at the Cretaceous/Tertiary boundary (65 Ma) and subsequent elevated speciation rates in the Tertiary. (AU)

column5: [Português] Estudamos qualitativamente os conteúdos estomacais de 20 exemplares (36VIRGULA1-71VIRGULA3 mm de comprimento padrão) de Crenicichla britskii (Jacundá ou Joaninha)VIRGULA coletados na bacia do rio AguapeíVIRGULA estado de São PauloVIRGULA sudeste do BrasilVIRGULA em um trecho de 100 m de riacho de segunda ordem correndo no interior de uma mata de galeria rala localizada dentro de uma grande área de pastagem. column5: [Português] Foram estudados 24 ovários pertencentes a 13 cutias adultas (em dois exemplares pesquisou-se apenas o ovário esquerdo)VIRGULA sendo 7 gestantes e 6 não gestantesVIRGULA provenientes do Núcleo de Estudos e Preservação de Animais Silvestres da Universidade Federal do Piauí. Os ovários apresentam-se de forma elipsóideVIRGULA achatados dorsoventralmenteVIRGULA situando-se na região sub-lombarVIRGULA caudalmente aos rinsVIRGULA com pequenas áreas transparentes em sua superfície externa. A margem mesovárica e a face lateral estão cobertas pelo mesossalpinge (bolsa ovárica). O ovário direito apresenta em média: peso - 0VIRGULA082gPONTOCOMMA comprimento - 0VIRGULA83cmPONTOCOMMA largura - 0VIRGULA49cm e espessura - 0VIRGULA24cmPONTOCOMMA o ovário esquerdo: peso - 0VIRGULA058gPONTOCOMMA comprimento - 0VIRGULA74cmPONTOCOMMA largura - 0VIRGULA45cm e espessura - 0VIRGULA23cm. HistologicamenteVIRGULA constam de epitélio de revestimento cúbico simplesVIRGULA córtex periférico e medula centralVIRGULA constituída basicamente por tecido conjuntivo frouxo entremeado por vasos sangüíneos. Conclui-se que os ovários da cutiaVIRGULA macro e microscopicamenteVIRGULA seguem o padrão observado nos demais roedores sexualmente ativos. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] It were studied 24 ovaries belonging to 13 adult agoutis (in two copies it was just researched the left ovary)VIRGULA being 7 pregnant and 6 not pregnantVIRGULA coming of the "Núcleo de Estudos e Preservação de Animais Silvestres"VIRGULA of the Federal University of Piauí. The organs were described in locoVIRGULA measuredVIRGULA submitted to section and observed in Optical Microscope. The ovariesVIRGULA ellipsoidsVIRGULA were located in the sub-lumbar areaVIRGULA flow to the kidneysVIRGULA flatVIRGULA with external surface evidencing small transparent areas and the margin mesovarian and lateral face coming covers for the mesossalpinge (ovaric bag). For the right ovaryVIRGULA was observed on the average: weight - 0VIRGULA082gPONTOCOMMA length - 0VIRGULA83cmPONTOCOMMA width - 0VIRGULA49cm and thickness - 0VIRGULA24cmPONTOCOMMA the left ovary: weight - 0VIRGULA058gPONTOCOMMA length - 0VIRGULA74cmPONTOCOMMA width - 0VIRGULA45cm and thickness - 0VIRGULA23cm. HistologicallyVIRGULA this gonads were correspondents with the majority of the rodents sexually actives studiesVIRGULA showing epithelium of simple cubic coatingVIRGULA the outlying cortex and the central medulla (constituted basically by conjunctive slack tissue mixed with vases of blood). In the pregnant females it was counted two to three great central luteous bodies and many other smaller. In the not pregnant the luteous bodies was smaller and more numerous. The cortex is rich in cellular types of conjunctive nature and follicles in different phases of the maturationVIRGULA which migration of the mesovarian margin for the tubaric extremityVIRGULA as they increase of size. It was conclued that the ovaries of the agoutisVIRGULA macro and microscopicallyVIRGULA coming the pattern observed in the others rodents actives sexually. (AU)

column5: [Português] A cutia é um roedor silvestreVIRGULA encontrado no sul da América Central e em regiões tropicais da América do SulVIRGULA principalmente nas regiões norteVIRGULA nordeste e sudeste do Brasil. Estes animais fornecem proteína de origem animal e por issoVIRGULA apresentam importância sócioeconômica para as regiões do norte e nordeste do Brasil. Para o presente trabalho foram utilizadas sete placentas de cutias (Dasyprocta aguti)VIRGULA em diferentes fases da gestação. Nos aspectos morfológicos a placenta da cutia apresenta uma forma esférica e uma estrutura lobada estando conecta ao útero através da mesoplacenta. O fluxo sangüíneo fetal flui do interlobo para o centro do loboVIRGULA ou sejaVIRGULA centripetamenteVIRGULA enquanto que o materno flui centrifugamente. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The agouti is a wild rodent found in the south of Central America and in tropical regions of South AmericaVIRGULA especially in the NorthernVIRGULA Northeastern and Southeastern regions of Brazil. These animals represent an important socio-economic factor in the North and Northeastern regions of Brazil since they provide animal protein. For this paper 07 agouti (Dasyprocta aguti) placentas were usedVIRGULA in differents stages of gestation. The placenta presents a spherical shape and lobular structure connecting to the uterus by means of a mesoplacenta. Fetal blood flows from the interlobium to the center of the lobeVIRGULA that isVIRGULA centripetallyVIRGULA while maternal blood flows centrifugally. (AU)

column4: [Português] Estrutura e composição da ictiofauna de riachos do Rio ParanapanemaVIRGULA sudeste e sul do Brasil
column5: [Português] Foram amostrados 17 trechos de riachos com 100 m de extensãoVIRGULA todos de ordem igual ou menor a trêsVIRGULA ao longo de ambas as margens do canal principal do Rio ParanapanemaVIRGULA SP e PR. O ponto médio de cada trecho foi georreferenciado via satélite com receptor GPS e o uso de metodologia padronizada de coleta de dados ambientais e peixes (baseada principalmente na pesca elétrica)VIRGULA possibilitou a obtenção das seguintes informações em cada local: 1) composição taxonômica da ictiofauna e contribuiçãoVIRGULA em termos de número de indivíduos e biomassaVIRGULA de cada espécie para a ictiofauna local como um todoPONTOCOMMA 2) documentação fotográfica de espécimes representativos de cada espécie coletada com sua coloração naturalPONTOCOMMA 3) descrição de cada ambiente coletadoVIRGULA com ilustrações fotográficas coloridasVIRGULA e seus principais parâmetros bióticos e abióticos. No total foram coletados 3.683 exemplaresVIRGULA pertencentes a seis ordensVIRGULA 16 famíliasVIRGULA 37 gêneros e 52 espéciesVIRGULA com biomassa total de 16VIRGULA8 kg. Das espécies coletadasVIRGULA aproximadamente 36% pertencem a ordem SiluriformesVIRGULA 36% a CharaciformesVIRGULA 11% a GymnotiformesVIRGULA 10% a PerciformesVIRGULA 4% a Cyprinodontiformes e 2% a Synbranchiformes. As espécies mais abundantes em termos de número de indivíduos foram Astyanax altiparanae (15VIRGULA2%) e Astyanax sp. 1 (12VIRGULA3%)PONTOCOMMA aquelas com maior biomassa foram A. altiparanae (28%) e Geophagus brasiliensis (13%). A composição da ictiocenose em termos de abundância e biomassa por família indica a predominância expressiva de CharacidaeVIRGULA seguida por LoricariidaeVIRGULA Pimelodidae e Cichlidae. Dentre os trechos amostradosVIRGULA o trecho 14 (24 espécies) e o 13 (cinco espécies)VIRGULA apresentaram a maior e a menor riqueza em espéciesVIRGULA respectivamenteVIRGULA coincidindo com os valores obtidos para o índice de diversidade específica de Shannon-Wienner (H´= 0VIRGULA99 e 0VIRGULA32VIRGULA respectivamente). A riqueza média encontrada foi de 11 espécies por trecho de riacho. [] (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] Seventeen 100 m long streams stretchesVIRGULA none of an order higher than threeVIRGULA were sampled to both sides of the main channel of Rio Paranapanema in the States of São Paulo and ParanáVIRGULA southeastern and southern Brazil. Each stream stretch had its midpoint located with a GPS satellite receiver and had its fish fauna sampled via a standardized environmental data and fish collection methodology (primarily utilizing electrofishing) with the aim of providing the following information about each stream: 1) the taxonomic composition of the fish fauna and the contribution of each species in that stream in terms of both number of individuals and biomassPONTOCOMMA 2) a photographic documentation of the live coloration of representative specimens of each collected speciesPONTOCOMMA and 3) the description of each sampled environmentVIRGULA with colored photographic illustrations and details of the main biotic and abiotic parameters. Overall 3VIRGULA683 fishes were collectedVIRGULA belonging to six ordersVIRGULA 16 familiesVIRGULA 37 generaVIRGULA and 52 speciesVIRGULA with a total biomass of 16.8 kg. Of the collected speciesVIRGULA approximately 36% were SiluriformesVIRGULA 36% CharaciformesVIRGULA 11% GymnotiformesVIRGULA 10% PerciformesVIRGULA 4% CyprinodontiformesVIRGULA and 2% Synbranchiformes. The most abundant species in terms of total number of individuals were Astyanax altiparanae (15.2%) and Astyanax sp. 1 (12.3%)PONTOCOMMA the species with the largest biomasses were Astyanax altiparanae (28%) and Geophagus brasiliensis (13%). In terms of abundance and biomass collected for each familyVIRGULA the Characidae was clearly the predominant family followed by the LoricariidaeVIRGULA PimelodidaeVIRGULA and Cichlidae. Among the sampled stream stretchesVIRGULA locality 14 with 24 species and locality 13 with five species yielded the highest and lowest richness in terms of species numbersVIRGULA respectively. This coincides with the values obtained for the Shannon-Wienner index of specific diversity (H´ = 0.99 and 0.32VIRGULA respectively [] (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Biological activities from extracts of endophytic fungi isolated from Viguiera arenaria and Tithonia diversifolia
column5: [Inglês] A total of 39 endophytic fungi have been isolated from Viguiera arenaria and Tithonia diversifoliaVIRGULA both collected in Sao Paulo StateVIRGULA Brazil. The isolates were identified based on their ribosomal DNA sequences.  The ethyl acetate (EtOAc) extracts of all endophytic fungi were evaluated for their antimicrobialVIRGULA antiparasitic and antitumoral activity. Antimicrobial screening was conducted using an agar diffusion assay against three pathogenic microorganisms: Staphylococcus aureusVIRGULA Escherichia coli and Candida albicans. Antiparasitic activity was determined by enzymatic inhibition of gGAPDH of Trypanosoma cruzi and adenine phosphorybosiltransferase (APRT) of Leishmania tarentolae. Antitumoral activity was tested against human T leukemia cells by theMosmann colorimetric method. All extracts showed activity in at least one assay: 79.5% of the extracts were cytotoxic against leukemia cellsVIRGULA 5.1% of the extracts were active against S. aureusVIRGULA 25.6% against E. coli and 64.1% against Candida albicans. Only one extract showed promising results in the inhibition of parasitic enzymes gGAPDH (95.0%) and three were found to inhibit APRT activity. The cytotoxic extract produced by the strain VA1 (Glomerella cingulata) was fractionated and yielded nectriapyrone and tyrosol. Nectriapyrone showed relevant cytotoxic activity against both human T leukemia and melanoma tumor cell lines. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Testing the ecomorphological hypothesis in a headwater riffles fish assemblage of the rio São FranciscoVIRGULA southeastern Brazil
column5: [Português] A ecomorfologia de 14 espécies de peixes residentes em um trecho de corredeiras do curso superior do rio São FranciscoVIRGULAsudeste do BrasilVIRGULA foi analisada e combinada com dados de comportamento alimentar e dietaVIRGULA previamente obtidos por nós. Os três principais agrupamentos ecomorfológicos de espécies identificados refletem a ocupação espacial de micro-hábitats da seguinte forma: a) caracídeos nectônicos com corpos comprimidosVIRGULA olhos laterais e nadadeiras peitorais lateraisVIRGULA com hábitos noturnos e oportunistas alimentares (Astyanax rivularisVIRGULA Bryconamericus stramineus e Bryconamericus sp.)PONTOCOMMA b) nectobentônicos com corpos fusiformes e nadadeiras peitorais expandidasVIRGULA que incluem os caracidiíneos predadores de espreita que se alimentam principalmente de larvas aquáticas bentônicas de insetos (Characidium fasciatum e Characidium zebra)VIRGULA parodontídeos pastadores de epilíton (Apareiodon ibitiensis e Parodon hilarii) e bagres especuladores de substratos que se alimentam principalmente de larvas aquáticas de insetos (Cetopsorhamdia iheringiVIRGULA Imparfinis minutusVIRGULA Rhamdia quelen e Trichomycterus sp.)PONTOCOMMA c) bentônicos com corpos deprimidosVIRGULA lábios modificados em discos orais suctoriasVIRGULA olhos dorsais e nadadeiras peitorais amplasVIRGULA representados pelos cascudos perifitívoros (Hisonotus sp.VIRGULA Harttia sp. e Hypostomus garmani). Correlação entre dieta e morfologia geral não foi significative em nossa análiseVIRGULA a não ser quando o conjunto analisado incluiu apenas as espécies nectônicas e bentônicasVIRGULA indicando que a ausência de correlação entre esses fatores é mais pronunciada no grupo de espécies nectobentônicas. A constatação do caso inequívoco de convergência morfológica entre os Characidiinae e Parodontidae nectobentônicos é um claro exemplo de como a integração da informação filogenética com a ecomorfologia pode identificar objetivamente casos de convergência e divergência adaptativa. FinalmenteVIRGULA a congruência entre os resultados ecomorfológicos com aqueles obtidos independentemente sobre a ecologia das espécies estudadas em seu ambiente natural parece ser uma forte evidência em favor do proposto valor preditivo da hipótese ecomorfológica. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The ecomorphology of 14 fish species resident in a headwater riffles area of the São Francisco riverVIRGULA southeastern BrasilVIRGULA was analyzed and combined with diet and feeding behavior dataVIRGULA previously obtained by us. The three larger species groups formed in the ecomorphological analysis were found to reflect primarily microhabitat occupation in the following manner: a) nektonic characids with compressed bodiesVIRGULA lateral eyes and lateral pectoral finsVIRGULA with diurnal and opportunistic feeding habits (Astyanax rivularisVIRGULA Bryconamericus stramineusVIRGULA and Bryconamericus sp.)PONTOCOMMA b) nektobenthic characiforms and siluriforms with fusiform bodies and expanded pectoral finsVIRGULA including sit-and-wait characidiinsVIRGULA predators of aquatic insect larvae (Characidium fasciatum and Ch. zebra)VIRGULA as well as the algae grazing parodontids (Apareiodon ibitiensis and Parodon hilarii)VIRGULA and also the heptapterid and trichomycterid catfishes that practice substrate speculation and feed on benthic aquatic insect larvae (Cetopsorhamdia iheringiVIRGULA Imparfinis minutusVIRGULA Rhamdia quelenVIRGULA and Trichomycterus sp.)PONTOCOMMA c) benthic species with depressed bodiesVIRGULA suctorial oral discsVIRGULA dorsal eyesVIRGULA and horizontal pectoral finsVIRGULA represented by the periphytivorous loricariid catfishes (Hisonotus sp.VIRGULA Harttia sp.VIRGULA and Hypostomus garmani). Correlation between diet and general morphology was not significant in our analysisVIRGULA unless when the analyzed set included only nektonic and benthic speciesVIRGULA indicating that the lack of correlation between these factors is most pronounced in the group of nektobenthic species. The unequivocal case of morphological convergence found between the nektobenthic Characidiinae and Parodontidae is a clear example of the integration between phylogenetic information and ecomorphologyVIRGULA and provides a way to objectively identify cases of morphological and adaptive convergence and divergence. FurthermoreVIRGULA the general congruence between the ecomorphological results and the independently obtained ecological data about the analyzed fish species in their natural environment seems to be strong evidence in favor of the proposed predictive capabilities of the ecomorphological hypothesis. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Revision of genera Gaza and Callogaza (VetigastropodaVIRGULA Trochidae)VIRGULA with description of a new Brazilian species
column5: [Inglês] A revision of the trochid genera Gaza and CallogazaVIRGULA inhabiting the deep waters of western Atlantic Ocean and eastern Pacific OceanVIRGULA is here provided. Species are separated mainly by shell charactersVIRGULA but anatomical features are also used in some species. The species considered in this study are: Gaza compta n. sp. (SE Brazil)VIRGULA G. daedala WatsonVIRGULA 1879 (Central Pacific)VIRGULA G. rathbuni DallVIRGULA 1890 (tropical W Pacific)VIRGULA G. fischeri DallVIRGULA 1889 (E Caribbean)VIRGULA G. superba (DallVIRGULA 1881) (Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean)VIRGULA G. cubana Clench & AguayoVIRGULA 1940 (N Caribbean)VIRGULA G. olivacea QuinnVIRGULA 1991 (NE South America and SE Brazil)VIRGULA Callogaza watsoni DallVIRGULA 1881 (Gulf of Mexico)VIRGULA C. sericata (KiraVIRGULA 1959) (NW Pacific) and C. frederici (SmithVIRGULA 1906) (S India). Anatomical data are provided for: Gaza comptaVIRGULA G. olivaceaVIRGULA GVIRGULA fischeriVIRGULA G. superba and G. cubana. Both Gaza and Callogaza are characterized by having iridescentVIRGULA thin-walled shellVIRGULA with the outer lip deflected (determined growth)VIRGULA and a flat callus partially or completely covering the wide umbilicusVIRGULA making it a hollow chamber. AnatomicallyVIRGULA the examined Gaza spp. have long epipodial tentacles and two series of holes between the propodium and the base of the head. The number of these structures can assist in the differentiation of species. Based on similarities of the shell and comparison with species of other trochid generaVIRGULA we conclude that Gaza and Callogaza have some characters in commonVIRGULA which most probably constitute synapomorphies that support a monophyletic branch of the family. Microgaza is not regarded as part of this trochid branchVIRGULA but may rather belong to Solariellinae. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] A review of Anapausis Enderlein (Diptera: Scatopsidae) in the neotropical regionVIRGULA with four new species and comments on the phylogeny of the genus
column5: [Inglês] Four new Neotropical species of Anapausis are described: A. clivicola sp. nov.VIRGULA A. wirthi sp. nov.VIRGULA A. mayana sp. nov.VIRGULA and A. mourei sp. nov. Anapausis fuscinervis Edwards is redescribedVIRGULA and a key for the Neotropical species of the genus is provided. The homology of the sclerites of the male terminalia is considered. Shared features allow recognition of four major clades within the genusVIRGULA one composed of the species in AustraliaVIRGULA New ZealandVIRGULA ChileVIRGULA and southern BrazilVIRGULA one composed of a pair of Central American speciesVIRGULA one composed of the Afrotropical and Oriental speciesVIRGULA and one composed of the Holarctic species. The Central American species of Anapausis appear to be more connected to the circumantarctic and the Afro-Oriental clades than to the Holarctic clade of the genus. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Ecology of Thestylus aurantiurus of the Parque Estadual da Serra da CantareiraVIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA Brazil (ScorpionesVIRGULA Bothriuridae)
column5: [Inglês] Individuals of a Thestylus aurantiurus Yamaguti & Pinto-da-Rocha 2003 population in the Parque Estadual da Serra da Cantareira (São PauloVIRGULA SPVIRGULA Brazil) show an increase of activity throughout the year. This increase is related to the reproductive season of these scorpionsVIRGULA from September to November. The abundance of scorpions was related to environmental factors in four different areas of the park. More scorpions were collected in the higher areasVIRGULA far away from water sources of the park and not exposed to flooding. A short description of the Thestylus aurantiurus burrows is also presented. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Liquid chromatography/electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry profiling of compounds from the infusion of Byrsonima fagifolia Niedenzu
column5: [Inglês] A rapid analytical approach suitable to achieve a comprehensive characterization of the compounds present in the infusion prepared from the leaves of Byrsonima fagifolia Niedenzu (Malpighiaceae)VIRGULA a Brazilian plant used as an infusion to treat gastric disordersVIRGULA was developed. The method was based on high-performance liquid chromatography coupled to electrospray negative ionisation multistage ion trap mass spectrometry (HPLC/ESI-ITMSn).The main ions in the ESI-ITMS spectra were attributed to a quinic acid core containing from one to five galloyl units. Quercetin derivatives containing one and two sugar moieties as well as galloyl esterification were also detected. These results indicated that HPLC/ESI-ITMSn is easily applicable to infusions of this plant and allows the rapid and direct identification of these compounds in crude plant extracts. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Lipoperoxidation and cyclooxygenase enzyme inhibitory piperidine alkaloids from Cassia spectabilis green fruits

column4: [Inglês] Lipoperoxidation and cyclooxygenases 1 and 2 inhibitory compounds from Iryanthera juruensis
column5: [Inglês] Plants from Iryanthera genus have been traditionally used as food supplements by South American Indians. The MeOH extract of leaves of Iryanthera juruensisVIRGULA one of the plants endemic to the Amazon region and consumed in BrazilVIRGULA and the hexane extract from its seeds inhibited lipid peroxidation (LPO) and cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and -2) enzymes in in vitro assays. Further analyses of these extracts yielded 5-deoxyflavones (1-5) from the leaf extract and sargachromenol (6)VIRGULA sargaquinoic acid (7)VIRGULA a novel juruenolic acid (8)VIRGULA alpha-arylalkanoic acids (9a-c)VIRGULA and the lignan guaiacin (10) from the seed extract. Compounds 3-5 inhibited LPO by 86%VIRGULA 77%VIRGULA and 88% at 10 ppmVIRGULA respectivelyVIRGULA and compounds 6 and 9a-c showed inhibition at 76% and 78% at 100 ppmVIRGULA respectively. HoweverVIRGULA compounds 7 and 8 were inactive and lignan 10 exhibited LPO inhibitory activity by 99% at 100 ppm compared to commercial antioxidants butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA)VIRGULA butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT)VIRGULA and vitamin E. The flavones 1-5 also inhibited COX-1 and -2 enzymes by 50-65% at 100 ppm. Compound 6 showed high but nonselective inhibition of COX-1 and COX-2 enzymesVIRGULA when compared to aspirin and CelebrexVIRGULA a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). Compounds 7 and 10 inhibited COX-1 by 60% and 65% and COX-2 by 37% and 18%VIRGULA respectivelyVIRGULA whereas compounds 8 and 9a-c showed little or no activity against these enzymes. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] The pulvinus endodermal cells and their relation to leaf movement in legumes of the Brazilian cerrado
column5: [Inglês] Legume pulvini have a clearly delimited endodermisVIRGULA whose variable content has been associated with the velocity and type of leaf movement: pulvini in leaves with fast nastic movement contain starch grainsPONTOCOMMA pulvini in leaves with slow nastic movements have calcium oxalate crystals as well as starch grains in the endodermis. HoweverVIRGULA the studies carried out to date have involved few legume species. This study therefore purported to examine the consistency of this hypothesis in other legumes. ThusVIRGULA the structure and content of the pulvinus endodermal cells of nine legumes of the Brazilian cerradoVIRGULA with different types and velocities of leaf movementVIRGULA were investigated: slow nyctinastic and heliotropic movements (Bauhinia rufaVIRGULA Copaifera langsdorffiiVIRGULA Senna rugosa - CaesalpinioideaePONTOCOMMA Andira humilis and Dalbergia miscolobium - FaboideaePONTOCOMMA Stryphnodendron polyphyllum - Mimosoideae)VIRGULA slow heliotropic movement (Zornia diphylla - Faboideae)VIRGULA and fast seismonastic and slow nyctinastic and heliotropic movements (Mimosa rixosa and Mimosa flexuosa - Mimosoideae). Samples were prepared following standard plant anatomy and ultrastructure techniques. The endodermis of all the species contains starch grains. In the species displaying only slow movementsVIRGULA calcium oxalate prismatic crystals were observed in addition to starch grainsVIRGULA except in Zornia diphylla. In conclusionVIRGULA oxalate crystals occur only in endodermal cells of pulvini that display slow movementsVIRGULA while starch grains are always present in pulvinus endodermal cells of plants with any kind of movement. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Mutagenic evaluation and chemical investigation of Byrsonima intermedia A. Juss. leaf extracts
column5: [Inglês] Byrsonima intermedia is a native species of the cerrado formation (tropical American savannah). Members of the genus Byrsonima (Malpighiaceae) are employed not only in the folk medicine but also as food to make juiceVIRGULA jellies and liquor. The aim of this work was to evaluate the mutagenic effects of Byrsonima intermediaVIRGULA common name murici. column4: [Inglês] Effects of Erythrinian alkaloids isolated from Erythrina mulungu (Papilionaceae) in mice submitted to animal models of anxiety
column5: [Inglês] The effects of acute oral administration of erythrinian alkaloidsVIRGULA i.e. (+)-alpha-hydroxy-erysotrineVIRGULA erythravine and (+)-11 alpha-hydroxy-erythravine isolated from the flowers of Erythrina mulungu were investigated in two animal models of anxiety in mice - the light-dark transition model (LDTM) and the elevated plus-maze (EPM). In the LDTMVIRGULA erythravine (3VIRGULA 10 mg/kg) and (+)- 11 alpha-hydroxy-erythravine (10 mg/kg) increased the time spent by the animals in the illuminated compartment and (+)-11 alpha-hydroxy-erythravine (3 mg/kg) increased the number of transitions between compartments of the LDTMVIRGULA suggesting an anxiolytic-like effect of these erythrinian alkaloids. NeverthelessVIRGULA the third alkaloid studiedVIRGULA (+)-alpha-hydroxy-erysotrineVIRGULA did not change any behavioral response with the range of doses used (3-10 mg/kg). Since the oral administration of the crude extract of E. mulungu (EM) (100-400 mg/kg) did not modify the conventional measures of anxiety in the EPMVIRGULA this animal model was not chosen to evaluate the anxiolytic properties of the isolated alkaloids. These results suggest that the alkaloids erythravine and (+)-11 alpha-hydroxy-erythravine are responsible for the anxiolytic effects of the crude extract of E. mulungu. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Chemical composition and antimicrobial activity of the essential oils from two species of Eucalyptus
column5: [Inglês] The leaf-essential oil from Eucalyptus robusta and E. salignaVIRGULA the latter in two phenologic stagesVIRGULA were analysed by gas chromatography coupled to mass spectrometry (GC-MS). In the vegetative phaseVIRGULA the major constituents were p-cymene (54.2%) and gama-terpinene (43.8%)VIRGULA while during the blossoming alpha-pinene became the major constituent followed by p-cymene (22.5%). column4: [Inglês] The tadpole of Scinax catharinae (Anura: Hylidae) with description of the internal oral morphologyVIRGULA and a review of the tadpoles from the Scinax catharinae group
column5: [Inglês] We present a description of the external morphology and internal oral features of the tadpole of Scinax catharinae and comparisons with the known tadpoles of the S. catharinae group. Two characters of the external morphology present some intraspecific variation: the row of submarginal papillaeVIRGULA which can be uniseriate or absentVIRGULA and the tail tipVIRGULA which can be large or smallVIRGULA truncated or not. That saidVIRGULA the tadpole of S. catharinae presents some distinguishing features that differentiate it from other tadpoles in the S. catharinae group: i) the marginal row of papillae with alternate dispositionVIRGULA ii) the spiracle opening on the midline of the bodyVIRGULA iii) longest snout lengthVIRGULA and iv) largest interorbital distance. The studied species were segregated into five ecomorphological guildsVIRGULA characterized by external morphological featuresVIRGULA tadpole habitat use and vegetation formation of species range. The taxonomy of the S. catharinae group is complexVIRGULA due to the morphological similarities among the adults. Larval characters could help in the resolution of the taxonomic and phylogenetic complexitiesVIRGULAsince the morphological differences among the tadpoles in this group seem more conspicuous than those found among the adults. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Oral glands in dipsadine goo-eater snakes: morphology and histochemistry of the infralabial glands in Atractus reticulatusVIRGULA Dipsas indicaVIRGULA and Sibynomorphus mikanii
column5: [Inglês] Although snake infralabial glands are generally constituted of mucous cellsVIRGULA among dipsadinesVIRGULA they are much more developed and predominantly serous in natureVIRGULA possibly due to the peculiar feeding habits of some species of this groupVIRGULA the goo-eatersVIRGULA which feed on soft and viscous invertebrates. We compared the morphology and histochemistry of the infralabial glands of three goo-eater species of Southeast BrazilVIRGULA Atractus reticulatusVIRGULA Dipsas indica and Sibynomorphus mikanii. In A. reticulatus the glands are formed by mixed acini composed of mucous and seromucous cells and in D. indicaVIRGULA they are composed of mucous tubules and seromucous acini. In S. mikanii the glands are organized in se romucous aciniPONTOCOMMA mucous cells are restricted to the gland anterior region and to the duct lining epithelium. UltrastructurallyVIRGULA secretory granule electron density varies from low to moderateVIRGULA depending on their mucous or seromucous nature. The results indicate a large morphological and histochemical variation in the infralabial glandsVIRGULA probably reflecting differences in the secretion chemical composition and in feeding specialization among the three species. The protein content in the secretory cells can be related with the presence of toxins that can be used in chemical prey immobilization or detaching of snails from their shells. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Occurrence of Mesocyclops ogunnus OnabamiroVIRGULA 1957 (Copepoda Cyclopoida) in water bodies of São Paulo stateVIRGULA identified as Mesocyclops kieferi Van de VeldeVIRGULA 1984VIRGULA [Português] Ocorrência de Mesocyclops ogunnus OnabamiroVIRGULA 1957 (Copepoda Cyclopoida) nos corpos de água do estado de São PauloVIRGULA identificado como Mesocyclops kieferi Van de VeldeVIRGULA 1984
column5: [Português] Este trabalho teve por objetivo esclarecer a identificação da espécie Mesocyclops ogunnus que ocorre nos reservatórios do estado de São Paulo e que havia sido identificada por vários autores como Mesocyclops kieferi. As duas espécies foram identificadas pela primeira vez em águas do continente africanoVIRGULA porém somente Mesocyclops ogunnus tem ocorrido na América do Sul e na América Central. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The aim of this work is to clarify the identification of Mesocyclops ogunnus that occurs in several reservoirs in the State of São Paulo and that was previously identified as Mesocyclops kieferi. These two species are closely related species with very similar characteristics. The differential characteristics are presented and the distribution of both species in the world is discussed. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Brazilian distribution of Amblyomma varium KochVIRGULA 1844 (Acari: Ixodidae)VIRGULA a common parasite of sloths (Mammalia: Xenarthra)
column5: [Inglês] Amblyomma variumVIRGULA commonly known in Brazil as the carrapato-gigante-da-preguiça (sloth's giant tick) is found from southern Central America to Argentina. These vials included data on the host and collection localities. The biology of A. varium is unknown. However it is known thatVIRGULA during the adult stageVIRGULA the tick presents a high host specificity and is found almost exclusively on the sloths Bradypus tridactylusVIRGULA B. variegatusVIRGULA B.torquatus (Bradypodidae)VIRGULA Choloepus hoffmanni and C. didactylus (Megalonychidae). column4: [Inglês] Synthesis of fructans by fructosyltransferase from the tuberous roots of Viguiera discolor (Asteraceae)
column5: [Inglês] Sucrose: sucrose fructosyltransferase (SST) and fructan:fructan fructosyl-transferase (FFT) activities from crude extracts of tuberous roots of Viguiera discolor growing in a preserved area of cerrado were analyzed in 1995-1996. SST activity was characterized by the synthesis of 1-kestose from sucrose and FFT activity by the production of nystose from 1-kestose. The highest fructan-synthesizing activity was observed during early dormancy (autumn)VIRGULA when both (SST and FFT) activities were high. The increase in synthetic activity seemed to start during the fruiting phase in the summerVIRGULA when SST activity was higher than in spring. During winter and at the beginning of sproutingVIRGULA both activities declined. The in vitro synthesis of high molecular mass fructans from sucrose by enzymatic preparations from tuberous roots collected in summer showed that long incubations of up to 288 h produced consistently longer polymers which resembled those found in vivo with respect to chromatographic profiles. (AU)

column4: [Português] Diversidade de Lepidoptera em Santa TeresaVIRGULA Espírito Santo
column5: [Português] Os ambientes bem preservadosVIRGULA acidentados e muito heterogêneous da região de Santa TeresaVIRGULA ES abrigam a comunidade de Lepidoptera mais rica conhecida para a Mata Atlântica. As 533 espécies já registradas nas famílias mais amostradas - NymphalidaeVIRGULA PieridaeVIRGULA Papilionidae (borboletas) e Saturniidae and Sphingidae (mariposas) - são seis a mais que as registradas no segundo sítio em riqueza (ItatiaiaVIRGULA RJ/MG) e permitem prever uma fauna total de menos 900 espécies de borboletas. Diversas espécies nessas cinco famílias são ilustradasVIRGULA com informações dadas sobre habitats e recursos das borboletas. Correlação simplesVIRGULA PCAVIRGULA e ordenação canônica demostram que a estrutura e riqueza da comunidade de borboletas em 14 sítios de Mata Atlântica podem ser explicadas por fatores locais de climaVIRGULA topografiaVIRGULA vegetação e pertubação. A fauna de Santa Teresa inclui uma mariposa e onze borboletas (com mais de 22 esperadas) nas listas brasileiras e estaduais de animais ameaçados de extinção e outras 20 espécies (com 11 esperadas) indicadoras raras e restritas aos ambientes mais ricos e especiais na região. A preservação da vegetação natural e o uso tradicional da terra nessa região poerão assegurar a continuidade desta rica biotaVIRGULA derivada de quatro regiões diferentes (Hiléia BaianaVIRGULA Litoral FluminenseVIRGULA Serra da Mantiqueira e Florestas Semi-Decíduas do interior). (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The well-preservedVIRGULA steep and heterogenous environments of the region of Santa TeresaVIRGULA Espírito SantoVIRGULA shelter the richest known Lepidoptera community in the Atlantic Forest (broad sense). The 533 species already recorded in the five best sampled families - NymphalidaeVIRGULA Pieridae and Papilionidae (butterflies) and Saturniidae and Sphingidae (moths) - are six more than the total listed for the next richest site (ItatiaiaVIRGULA Rio de Janeiro/Minas Gerais)VIRGULA and permit the prediction of a total fauna of at least 900 butterfly species. Many species I these five families are illustratedVIRGULA and habitats and resources are given for the butterflies. CorrelationsVIRGULA PCS and canonical ordination show that the structure and richness of the butterfly community in 14 Atlantic Forest sites can be explained by local climaticVIRGULA topographicalVIRGULA vegetationVIRGULA and disturbance factors. The Santa Teresa fauna includes 12 species of Lepidoptera (with another 22 expected ro occur) on Brazilian national or state lists of threatened animalsVIRGULA and a further 20 (with 11 expected) that are rare indicators restricted to the richest and most unique environments in the region. Preservation of the natural vegetation and traditional lan-usu patterns in the region should assure the continuity of this rich biotaVIRGULA derived from four different regions (the Bahia Hylaea. The Rio de Janeiro coastal plainVIRGULA the Mantiqueira mountainsVIRGULA and the semi-deciduous forest in the interior). (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Atlantic Forest butterflies: indicators for landscape conservation
column5: [Português] A região da Mata Atlântica latu sensu inclui ambientes tropicais muito complexosVIRGULA cada vez mais ameagados por extensa conversão antrópica (>90%). Insetos pequenosVIRGULA especializadosVIRGULA e de ciclo rápido (borboletas) são avaliados neste trabalho como indicadores para o monitoramento da riqueza de comunidadesVIRGULA integridade de paisagensVIRGULA e uso sustentável de recursos na região. As >2100 espécies de borboletas na região da Mata Atlântica têm sido recenseadas em muitos sítios durante os últimos 35 anosVIRGULA dando listas comparáveis diáriasVIRGULA semanaisVIRGULA mensais e totais para cada sítio. Os 21 sítios mais intensivamente estudados incluem 218-914 espéciesVIRGULA das quais metade pode ser amostrada em uma semana ou menos. As comunidades de borboletas são divididas em seis sub-regiões faunísticas relativamente distintasVIRGULA centradas no nordesteVIRGULA nos tabuleiros baianosVIRGULA no litoral do sudesteVIRGULA nas regiões montanhosas no interior dos estados do sudesteVIRGULA no Planalto CentralVIRGULA e nos estados do sul. A riqueza de espécies é maior nas serras costeiras entre 15 e 23°S. As comunidades locais de borboletas possuem alta reposiçãoVIRGULA com 20 a 40 por cento das espéciesVIRGULA especialmente os pequenos Lycaenidae e HesperiidaeVIRGULA registradas em populações instáveis ou sendo apenas turistas. As espécies facilmente amostradas na familia NymphalidaeVIRGULA especialmente as atraidas a iscas fermentadasVIRGULA são mais correlacionadas com a riqueza total e podem ser usadas como estimadores da riqueza total no ambiente. Na maior parte dos grupos de borboletasVIRGULA a riqueza de espécies é altamente correlacionada com conectividade simples da paisagemVIRGULA e com índices compostos de heterogeneidadeVIRGULA perturbação naturalVIRGULA e (negativamente) perturbação total no ambiente. As análises de componentes principais e de redundância mostram que as riquezas e proporções de diferentes grupos de borboletas são variavelmente explicadas por perturbaçãoVIRGULA sazonalidadeVIRGULA temperaturaVIRGULA vegetaçãoVIRGULA solosVIRGULA e conectividade. Vários grupos podem assim ser úteis como indicadores rápidos de diferentes tipos de mudanças na comunidadeVIRGULA no seu ambienteVIRGULA e na paisagem. Espécies raras e ameaçadas podem também ser usadas para indicar os sistemas mais únicos na região (palcoambientes)VIRGULA que necessitam de atenção especial. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The Atlantic Forest region (wide sense) includes very complex tropical environmentsVIRGULA increasingly threatened by extensive anthropogenic conversion (>90%). Ecologically specializedVIRGULA short-generation insects (butterflies) are evaluated here as indicators for monitoring community richnessVIRGULA landscape integrityVIRGULA and sustainable resource use in the region. The > 2100 butterfly species in the Atlantic Forest region have been censused in many sites over 35 yearsVIRGULA giving comparable dailyVIRGULA weeklyVIRGULA monthlyVIRGULA and long-term site lists. The 21 most thoroughly studied sites include 218-914 speciesVIRGULA of which half can be censused in a week or less. The butterfly communities are divided into six relatively distinct faunal regionsVIRGULA centered in the northeastVIRGULA the central coastal tablelandsVIRGULA the southeast coastal plainVIRGULA the mountains plus interior of the southeastern statesVIRGULA the central plateauVIRGULA and the southern states. Species richness shows the highest values in coastal mountains from 15 to 23°S. Local butterfly communities show a high turnoverVIRGULA with 20 to 40 percent of the speciesVIRGULA especially small Lycaenidae and HesperiidaeVIRGULA recorded only as unstable populations or tourists. Easily sampled species in the family NymphalidaeVIRGULA and especially its bait-attracted subfamiliesVIRGULA are best correlated with the entire butterfly fauna and can be used as surrogates for species diversity. In most butterfly groupsVIRGULA species richness is well predicted by landscape connectivity aloneVIRGULA or by composite indices of environmental heterogeneityVIRGULA natural disturbanceVIRGULA and (negatively) anthropogenic disturbance. Principal components and redundancy analyses showed that the richness and proportions of different butterfly groups in the local fauna are variably explained by disturbanceVIRGULA seasonalityVIRGULA temperatureVIRGULA vegetationVIRGULA soilsVIRGULA and landscape connectivity. Various groups thus can be used as rapid indicators of different types of change in the communityVIRGULA its environmentVIRGULA and the landscape. Threatened and rare species also can be used as indicators of the most unique Atlantic Forest communities (paleoenvironments)VIRGULA which need special attention. (AU)
