column4: [Inglês] Occurrence of xyloglucan containing protuberances in the storage cell walls of cotyledons of Hymenaea courbaril L.VIRGULA [Português] Ocorrência de protuberâncias contendo xiloglucano nas paredes celulares da reserva de Hymenaea courbaril L.

column5: [Inglês] Stream ecosystems may be strongly influenced in different ways by land use. The effects of land-cover patterns on Odonata community were studied in eight streams and seven lakes-dams of northeastern São Paulo State. The pattern analyzed was monoculture (sugar cane) vs. nature reserve in terms of Odonata species richness and similarity. Eighty-five Odonata species were sampled. The species richness was higher in the monoculture (33 species) than nature reserve (30 species) and 22 species were common to both areas. There was not verified relationship between land use and physical or chemical characteristics of the streams or lakes-dams water. These results suggest that some Odonata species are benefited and other affected by anthropogenic actionsVIRGULA although more studies are necessary to evaluate this hypothesis. column5: [Inglês] Most of the morphological and developmental characteristics of different parts of a plant may vary in function of the species architectureVIRGULA microenvironment and degree of ecological restriction where its has begun it growth. This study aimed to analyze the allometric relation between height and the largest horizontal crown axis andVIRGULA for a community of tree seedlings and saplings up to 1 m in height in the Reserva Estadual do Morro Grande (23o35S - 23o50SPONTOCOMMA 46o45W - 47o15W)VIRGULA situated in São Paulos Atlantic PlateauVIRGULA SE Brazil. We sampled 600 individuals in 34 1m2 plots distant 2.5 m from each other along six transectsVIRGULA 100 individuals per transect. For each individual we measured their height and largest crown axis. We adjusted different regression models (linearVIRGULA exponentialVIRGULA powerVIRGULA polynomial and logarithmic) to the data. The best fit was for the power model (r2 = 0.640VIRGULA p<0.001). The fact that juveniles from different species adjust to the same allometric model suggests that ecological factors could have an important restrictive role in the allometry of seedlings and saplings of tree species. (AU)VIRGULA [Português] Muitos caracteres morfológicos e de desenvolvimento de diferentes partes de uma planta variam dependendo da arquitetura da espécieVIRGULA do microambienteVIRGULA e do grau de restrição ecológica onde esta iniciou seu crescimento. Dentro deste contextoVIRGULA este estudo teve como objetivo analisar a relação alométrica entre o maior eixo de copa e a alturaVIRGULA para a comunidade de plântulas e indivíduos jovens de espécies arbóreas com até 1 m de altura na Reserva Estadual do Morro Grande (23o35S - 23o50SPONTOCOMMA 46o45W - 47o15W)VIRGULA situada no planalto atlântico de São Paulo. Foram feitas seis transecções onde a cada 2VIRGULA5 metro foi estabelecida uma parcela de 1x1mVIRGULA totalizando 34 parcelas. Todos os indivíduos encontrados dentro das parcelas tiveram a altura e o maior eixo horizontal da copa medidoVIRGULA sendo amostrados em cada transecção 100 indivíduosVIRGULA totalizando uma amostra de 600 indivíduos. Foram ajustados diferentes modelos de regressão aos dados (linearVIRGULA exponencialVIRGULA potencialVIRGULA polinomial e logarítmica) sendo que o potencial apresentou o melhor ajuste (r2 = 0VIRGULA640VIRGULA p<0VIRGULA001). O fato de jovens de diferentes espécies se ajustarem a um único modelo alométrico sugere que os fatores ecológicos podem ter um papel restritivo na alometria das plântulas e jovens de espécies arbóreas. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Bathyglycinde profunda (Hartman & Fauchald) (PolychaetaVIRGULA Goniadidae): new combination
column5: [Inglês] Goniadid polychaetes belonging to the genus Bathyglycinde FauchaldVIRGULA 1972 were collected during the REVIZEE Program/South Score/Benthos on the outer shelf and continental slope off the south-southeastern coast of Brazil. This genus is recorded for the first time from Brazilian waters. A new combination for the species Glycinde profunda Hartman & FauchaldVIRGULA 1971 is proposedVIRGULA and the species is illustrated. This species was originally assigned to the genus Glycinde MüllerVIRGULA 1858VIRGULA but the conspicuous proboscideal papillae and the simple capillary notochaetae without knob are typical of Bathyglycinde. Bathyglycinde profunda comb. nov. differs from other congeneric species mainly in having all chaetigers with single pre- and postchaetal lamellaeVIRGULA proboscideal papillae in Area I and 32-41 uniramous chaetigers. This is the first member of the genus found in less than abyssal depths. A key to the species of Bathyglycinde is provided. (AU)VIRGULA [Português] Poliquetas goniadídeos pertencentes a Bathyglycinde FauchaldVIRGULA 1972 foram coletados durante o programa REVIZEE/Score Sul/Bentos Avaliação do potencial sustentável dos recursos vivos na zona econômica exclusiva na plataforma externa e talude continental sul-sudeste do Brasil. Originalmente esta espécie estava em Glycinde MüllerVIRGULA 1858VIRGULA mas as papilas proboscideais e cerdas notopodiais capilares não geniculadas são características de Bathyglycinde. Bathyglycinde profunda (Hartman & FauchaldVIRGULA 1971) comb. nov. difere das outras espécies do gênero por ter uma única lamela pré- e uma pós-setal em todos os setígerosVIRGULA papilas proboscideais na área I e 32-34 setígeros unirremes. Uma chave de identificação para as espécies de Bathyglycinde é fornecida. Este é o primeiro registro de uma espécie do gênero em águas não abissais. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Microhabitat selection and co-occurrence of Pachistopelma rufonigrum Pocock (AraneaeVIRGULA Theraphosidae) and Nothroctenus fuxico sp. nov. (AraneaeVIRGULA Ctenidae) in tank bromeliads from Serra de ItabaianaVIRGULA SergipeVIRGULA Brazil
column5: [Português] Foram estudadas a seleção de microhabitat e co-ocorrência de Pachistopelma rufonigrum Pocock (Theraphosidae) e Nothroctenus fuxico sp. nov. (Ctenidae) em bromélias-tanque. A condição da temperatura dentro e fora das plantas foi medida para verificar se a temperatura da água acumulada dentro da bromélia afeta algum aspecto comportamental das aranhas que ali vivem. Medidas dos parâmetros foliares foram realizadas para avaliar se a estrutura das plantas chega a afetar a abundância ou a seleção de microhabitat dessas aranhas. AparentementeVIRGULA as diferenças na estrutura das duas espécies de bromélias estudadas não afetam nem a abundânciaVIRGULA nem a seleção de microhabitat de P. rufonigrum e N. fuxico sp. nov. A preferência e co-ocorrência de ambas as espécies de aranhas parece ser um evento ao acaso. AdicionalmenteVIRGULA apresenta-se notas sobre os limites de distribuição de P. rufonigrum e descreve-se N. fuxico sp. nov. do Estado de SergipeVIRGULA Brasil. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] Microhabitat selection and co-occurrence of Pachistopelma rufonigrum Pocock (Theraphosidae) and Nothroctenus fuxico sp. nov. (Ctenidae)VIRGULA in tank bromeliads were investigated. Thermal conditionsVIRGULA inside and outside the plantsVIRGULA were measured in order to verify if the temperature of the water that accumulates inside the plant affects the behavior of these species. Measurements of foliar parameters were taken in order to evaluate if and how plant structure affects spider abundance and microhabitat selection. ApparentlyVIRGULA differences in plant structure do not affect either spider abundance or microhabitat selection. No microhabitat preference was observed and co-ocurrence of both species was a random event. In additionVIRGULA notes on the distribution range of P. rufonigrum and the description of N. fuxico sp. nov. from State of SergipeVIRGULA Brazil are presented. (AU)

column4: [Português] Anatomia e ultraestrutura do pulvino primário de Pterodon pubescens Benth. (Fabaceae - Faboideae)VIRGULA [Inglês] Anatomy and ultrastructure the primary pulvinus of Pterodon pubescens Benth. (Fabaceae - Faboideae)
column5: [Português] A anatomia e ultraestrutura do pulvino primário de Pterodon pubescens foram estudadas para verificar se os movimentos lentos de suas folhas estão associados às características celulares do pulvino. Amostras de pulvinos provenientes de folhas com folíolos abertos e fechados foram preparadas segundo técnicas usuais em microscopia de luz e eletrônica. O pulvino é constituído por epiderme unisseriada recoberta por cutícula espessa e tricomas tectoresVIRGULA córtex com diversas camadas de células parenquimáticas (ou motoras)VIRGULA feixe vascular central rodeado por bainha de fibras septadas e medula reduzida. As características das células motoras variam de acordo com o grau de turgescência do pulvinoVIRGULA ocorrendo alterações no tamanho e forma das célulasVIRGULA na espessura das paredes celularesVIRGULA na freqüência e organização dos plasmodesmosVIRGULA no conteúdo e número de vacúolos e na densidade do citoplasma. Fibras septadas ao redor do floema estão sendo descritas pela primeira vez em pulvinos. A ampla ocorrência de plasmodesmosVIRGULA a ausência de barreiras apoplásticas e a escassez de lignificação (presente unicamente nos vasos do xilema) indicam uma continuidadeVIRGULA simplástica e apoplásticaVIRGULA desde a epiderme até o tecido vascular do pulvino. Em P. pubescensVIRGULA as características do pulvino primário são compatíveis com as de pulvinos que apresentam movimentos lentosPONTOCOMMA as características compartilhadas com pulvinos de movimentos rápidos são a presença de vacúolos com substâncias fenólicas nas células corticais e amiloplastos na endoderme. Os movimentos promovidos pelo pulvino primário de P. pubescens estão associados a mudanças nos compartimentos apoplástico (dobramentos das paredes celulares) e simplástico (reorganização vacuolar). (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] The anatomy and ultrastructure of Pterodon pubescens primary pulvinus were studied to verify if slow leaf movements are associated with pulvinus cells features. Pulvini samples deriving from leaf with open and closed leaflets were prepared following usual techniques using light and electron microscopy. The pulvinus has a unisseriated epidermis covered by a thick cuticle and many trichomesVIRGULA cortex with several layers of parenchyma cells (motor cells)VIRGULA a central vascular core surrounded by septate fibersVIRGULA and a reduced pith. Cortical cells features change with the turgescence degreeVIRGULA showing alteration in the cell size and shapeVIRGULA cell wall thicknessVIRGULA frequency and arrangement of plasmodesmataVIRGULA vacuole content and number and cytoplasm density. Septate fibers around the phloem were described for the first time in pulvini. The wide occurrence of plasmodesmataVIRGULA the apoplastic barriers absence and the lignification scarcity (only present in xylem vessels) indicate a continuityVIRGULA both simplastic and apoplasticVIRGULA from the epidermis to the vascular tissue of the pulvinus. In Pterodon pubescensVIRGULA primary pulvinus features are compatible with slow movement pulviniPONTOCOMMA the features shared to speedy movement pulvini are the presence of vacuoles with phenolic substances in the cortical cells and amiloplasts in the endodermal cells. Movements caused by P. pubescens primary pulvinus are associated with changes in both the apoplastic (wall infoldings) and symplastic (vacuolar reorganization). (AU)

column4: [Português] Ontogenia foliar de três espécies de Erythroxylum P. Browne (Erythroxylaceae) ocorrentes no CerradoVIRGULA [Inglês] Foliar ontogeny of three species of Erythroxylum P. Browne (Erythroxylaceae) from Cerrado
column5: [Português] Com o objetivo de descrever a ontogenia foliar e natureza das cicatrizesVIRGULA encontradas em lâminas adultas de ErythroxylumVIRGULA foram analisadas as folhas de Erythroxylum campestreVIRGULA E. nanum e E. tortuosumVIRGULA em diferentes estágios de desenvolvimento. Para as três espéciesVIRGULA verificou-se a ocorrência de um crescimento foliar marginal do tipo submarginal mediano. No início do desenvolvimento do órgãoVIRGULA a atividade do meristema adaxial é intensa e leva à formação de uma saliência nessa faceVIRGULA enquanto que a porção laminar se desenvolve de forma involutaVIRGULA devido à atividade do meristema marginal. Os estômatos se diferenciam junto com as camadas do mesofilo e a expansão final do órgão é dada por um crescimento intercalar. Durante a ontogenia não foi registrado o aparecimento de cicatrizes laminares queVIRGULA quando presentesVIRGULA se assemelham a injúrias superficiaisVIRGULA dispostas na face inferior e paralelamente à nervura principal. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] Leaves of Erythroxylum campestreVIRGULA E. nanumVIRGULA and E. tortuosum have been studied in different developmental stages in order to describe the leaf ontogeny and the structure of scars found in mature blades of Erythroxylum. The marginal growth of the leaves is of the median submarginal type. At early stagesVIRGULA intense activity in the adaxial meristem leads to the formation of a crest on this surfaceVIRGULA while the laminar portion has an involuted aspectVIRGULA due to the activity of the marginal meristem. The stomata develop at the same time as the mesophyll layers and the final expansion of the blade results from an intercalary growth. Blade scars were not observed during ontogeny. When present these scars appear to result from shallow injuries parallel to the midrib on the abaxial surface. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Ectoparasites of wild rodents from Parque Estadual da Cantareira (Pedra Grande Nuclei)VIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA BrazilVIRGULA [Português] Ectoparasitos de roedores silvestres do Parque Estadual da Cantareira (Núcleo Pedra Grande)VIRGULA São PauloVIRGULA Brasil
column5: [Português] Dezesseis espécies de ectoparasitos foram coletadas sobre 195 roedoresVIRGULA entre fevereiro de 2000 e janeiro de 2001VIRGULA no Parque Estadual da CantareiraVIRGULA que compreende os municípios de CaieirasVIRGULA Mairiporã e GuarulhosVIRGULA estado de São PauloVIRGULA Brasil. Cinqüenta e três por cento dos roedores capturados estavam infestadosVIRGULA e as maiores prevalências foram observadas para Gigantolaelaps gilmorei e G. oudemansi em Oryzomys russatusPONTOCOMMA G. wolffsohniVIRGULA Laelaps paulistanensis e M. parvispinosus em Oligoryzomys sp. Em relação as pulgasVIRGULA Polygenis (Neopolygenis) atopus foi a mais prevalenteVIRGULA infestando O. russatus. Os maiores índices de especificidade foram para Eubrachylaelaps rotundus/Akodon sp.VIRGULA G. gilmorei e G. oudemansi/ O. russatus e Laelaps navasi/Juliomys pictipes. A intensidade média de infestação está relacionada ao índice de especificidadeVIRGULA e somente foi significante para Brucepattersonius sp. e O. russatus (p< 0VIRGULA05). Um novo registro de localidade foi assinalado para L. navasiVIRGULA e as seguintes espéciesVIRGULA Craneopsylla minerva minerva e Polygenis (N.) pradoi foram encontradas pela primeira vez em Blarinomys brevicepsPONTOCOMMA tanto quanto A. fahrenholziVIRGULA E. rotundusVIRGULA G. wolffsohniVIRGULA M. parvispinosusVIRGULA C. minerva e P. atopus em Brucepattersonius sp.PONTOCOMMA e A. fahrenholziVIRGULA E. rotundusVIRGULA G. gilmoreiVIRGULA G. oudemansiVIRGULA Ixodes loricatusVIRGULA L. navasiVIRGULA L. paulistanensisVIRGULA M. parvispinosus e P. atopus em J. pictipes. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] Sixteen ectoparasite species were collected from 195 wild rodentsVIRGULA between February 2000 and January 2001VIRGULA in an Ecological Reserve area of the Parque Estadual da CantareiraVIRGULA in the municipalities of CaieirasVIRGULA Mariporã and GuarulhosVIRGULA State of São PauloVIRGULA Brazil. Fifty three percent of the captured rodents were found infestedVIRGULA with the highest prevalences observed for the mites Gigantolaelaps gilmorei and G. oudemansi on Oryzomys russatusPONTOCOMMA G. wolffsohniVIRGULA Lalelaps paulistanensis and Mysolaelaps parvispinosus on Oligoryzomys sp. In relation to the fleasVIRGULA Polygenis (Neopolygenis) atopus presented the highest prevalenceVIRGULA infesting Oryzomys russatus. column4: [Inglês] Application of preparative high-speed counter-current chromatography for the separation of flavonoids from the leaves of Byrsonima crassa Niedenzu (IK)
column5: [Inglês] The methanolic extract of the leaves of the medicinal plant Byrsonima crassa (Malpighiaceae) contain flavonoids with antioxidant activity. They were separated in a preparative scale using high-speed counter-current chromatography. The optimum solvent system used was composed of a mixture of ethyl acetate-n-propanol-water (140:8:80 (v/v/v)) and led to a successful separation between monoglucosilated flavonoids (quercetin-3-O-a--arabinosideVIRGULA quercetin-3-O-ß--galactoside) and the biflavonoid amentoflavone in only 3.5 h. The purities of quercetin-3-O-a--arabinoside (95 mg)VIRGULA quercetin-3-O-ß--galactoside (16 mg) and the biflavonoid amentoflavone (114 mg) were all isolated at purity over 95%. Identification was performed by 1H NMRVIRGULA 13C NMR and UV analyses.(AU)

column5: [Inglês] Annual patterns of breeding activityVIRGULA reproductive modesVIRGULA and habitat use are described for a frog community in a seasonal environmentVIRGULA in the southern PantanalVIRGULA Mato Grosso do SulVIRGULA Brazil. A total of 24 species from four familiesPONTOCOMMA Bufonidae (3 species)VIRGULA Hylidae (10 species)VIRGULA Leptodactylidae (9 species)VIRGULA and Microhylidae (2 species) were registered. Three reproductive activity patterns are recognized among these species: continuousVIRGULA explosiveVIRGULA and prolongedPONTOCOMMA 50% of the species were explosive breeders. Seasonal pattern of reproduction was verified for three analyzed years (1995-1997)PONTOCOMMA most species reproduced during the rainy season (Nov-Jan). The reproduction was aseasonal in 1998PONTOCOMMA unexpected rains in the dry season lead to an unusual breeding activity. Five reproductive modes were noted - 62.5% of the species have the generalized aquatic modeVIRGULA and 33.3% deposit eggs embedded in foam nests. Many species used the same sites for reproductionVIRGULA although temporal partitioning and calling site segregation was observed. The occurrence of many species that exhibit explosive breeding early in the rainy season is common in seasonal and open environments with variable and unpredictable rainfallVIRGULA as is the case in the Pantanal.(AU)

column4: [Inglês] Why biogeographical hypotheses need a well supported phylogenetic framework: a conceptual evaluation
column5: [Inglês] A growing number of biogeographical methods have attempted to describe formal means of reconstructing the biogeographical history of the organisms. Whatever the biogeographical methodVIRGULA howeverVIRGULA the source of systematic information has to be well worked out. Taxonomic noise is sometimes a true impediment to properly deal with the complexity of life in its three-dimensional aspectsVIRGULA the threefold parallelism represented by formVIRGULA space and time. This paper argues that historical systematics is a necessary basis for a historical biogeography. Organismal phylogenies or at least hypotheses of monophyly should be taken as the basis for the study of distribution patterns. Whenever a non-monophyletic taxon is misleadingly taken as monophyleticVIRGULA erroneous interpretations in evolutionary analyses necessarily follow... (AU)VIRGULA [Português] Um crescente número de métodos biogeográficos tem buscado descrever maneiras formais de reconstruir a história biogeográfica dos organismos. EntretantoVIRGULA para qualquer método biogeográfico empregadoVIRGULA a fonte de informação sistemática deve ser precisa. Ruído taxonômico é por vezes um verdadeiro obstáculo para se tratar apropriadamente da complexidade da vida no seu aspecto tridimensionalVIRGULA representado pelo triplo paralelismo formaVIRGULA espaço e tempo. Esse artigo defende que a sistemática é o fundamento necessário para a biogeografia histórica. Filogenias de organismos ou ao menos hipóteses de monofiletismo devem ser a base para o estudo de padrões de distribuição. Táxons não-monofiléticos tomados erroneamente como monofiléticos resultarão em interpretações incorretas nas análises evolutivas... (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Systematics must embrace comparative biology and evolutionVIRGULA not speed and automation
column5: [Inglês] Systematists have come under a barrage of criticism because of the alleged inadequacy of the traditional taxonomic paradigm to curb the biodiversity crisis and expeditiously make available the products of systematic research-usually species names-to the professional biological user community (including ecologistsVIRGULA physiologistsVIRGULA population geneticistsVIRGULA and conservationists). The accusations leveled on systematists range from being slow to incapable of furnishing these products at a rate considered (by users) appropriateVIRGULA especially given that the professional systematic community is portrayed as being in stark decline while operating in a quickly deteriorating natural world. Some of the critics have proposed solutions to this taxonomic impediment in the form of a triumvirate adjoining a unitary taxonomic cyberstructure + automated DNA barcoding + molecular phylogenyVIRGULA which we consider to be nothing but a threefold miopiaPONTOCOMMA one critic has even gone as far as to suggest that biologists who need systematists can circumvent this dependency by doing systematics themselves... (AU)

column5: [Inglês] Three species of darwinulid ostracodsVIRGULA belonging to the genus PenthesilenulaVIRGULA are reported from terrestrial and semi-terrestrial habitats in São Paulo State (Brazil). Penthesilenula reidae n. sp. is here described as new to science. It belongs to the africana-group in the genus and was found exclusively in bromeliad pouches. Penthesilenula aotearoa (in the incae-group) was previously known from New Zealand only and is here reported for the first time from South America. The third speciesVIRGULA Penthesilenula brasiliensisVIRGULA is here described from leaf litter in forestsVIRGULA constituting the first darwinulid taxon to be found in fully terrestrial habitats. The morphological diversity within P. brasiliensis s. l. is discussed and various lineages on different continents are retained within this species. The evolutionary significance of the high incidence of teratologies in the Darwinulidae is discussed. A tentative homology for the apical chaetotaxy of A2 between Darwinulidae and Cyprididae is offered. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Revisiting the taxonomic impediment
column5: [Inglês] We read with some frustration the recent Editorial and Letters concerning the "taxonomic impediment" (Q. D. Wheeler et al.VIRGULA "Taxonomy: Impediment or expedient?"VIRGULA EditorialVIRGULA 16 Jan. 2004VIRGULA p. 285PONTOCOMMA "Taxonomists and the CBDVIRGULA" R. Geeta et al.VIRGULA LettersVIRGULA 20 Aug. 2004VIRGULA p. 1105PONTOCOMMA "Museum collections and taxonomyVIRGULA" D. Causey et al.VIRGULA LettersVIRGULA 20 Aug. 2004VIRGULA p. 1106). Geeta et al.'s claim that "developing nations... produce far fewer taxonomists than developed countries" is not true in much of Latin AmericaVIRGULA where a large proportion of research biologists are systematists. For exampleVIRGULA Brazil has more systematic ichthyologistsVIRGULA entomologistsVIRGULA and botanists than most countriesVIRGULA due to a federal directive in the 1980s that trained new generations of specialists in cladistics. Undergraduate biology courses in Brazil emphasize not only zoology and botany but also cladistics and biogeographyVIRGULA more so than in American universitiesVIRGULA which consequently produce fewer new systematists. But with meager employment prospects in morphological systematics in U.S. institutions and in the developed world generallyVIRGULA how could this be otherwise? This bleak prognosis has also affected U.S. collections (1)VIRGULA representing a "broader trend away from organismal biology" (2)PONTOCOMMA the number of doctorates awarded yearly in botany and zoology is decreasing in the United States. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Purification and biochemical characterization of a thermostable extracellular glucoamylase produced by the thermotolerant fungus Paecilomyces variotii
column5: [Inglês] An extracellular glucoamylase produced by Paecilomyces variotii was purified using DEAE-cellulose ion exchange chromatography and Sephadex G-100 gel filtration. The purified protein migrated as a single band in 7% PAGE and 8% SDS-PAGE. The estimated molecular mass was 86.5 kDa (SDS-PAGE). Optima of temperature and pH were 55°C and 5.0VIRGULA respectively. In the absence of substrate the purified glucoamylase was stable for 1 h at 50 and 55°CVIRGULA with a t50 of 45 min at 60°C. The substrate contributed to protect the enzyme against thermal denaturation. The enzyme was mainly activated by manganese metal ions. The glucoamylase produced by P. variotii preferentially hydrolyzed amylopectinVIRGULA glycogen and starchVIRGULA and to a lesser extent malto-oligossacarides and amylose. SucroseVIRGULA p-nitrophenyl ALPHA-d-maltosideVIRGULA methyl-ALPHA-d-glucopyranosideVIRGULA pullulanVIRGULA ALPHA- and BETA-cyclodextrinVIRGULA and trehalose were not hydrolyzed. After 24 hVIRGULA the products of starch hydrolysisVIRGULA analyzed by thin layer chromatographyVIRGULA showed only glucose. (AU)

The species has nasal barbels on the posterior nares(shared with various Old-World catfish taxa)VIRGULA a wide separationbetween the anal and urogenital openings (shared with a largesubgroup of Bagridae) and a unique structure of the firstlateral-line ossicle (shared with species of Olyra). The speciesis similar to Olyra longicaudataVIRGULA although there are significantmorphometric and meristic differences. column4: [Inglês] Description and ecology of a new species of sun spider (Arachnida: Solifugae) from the Brazilian Cerrado
column5: [Inglês] A new species of solifuge from São Paulo StateVIRGULA south-eastern BrazilVIRGULA is describedVIRGULA together with its phenologyVIRGULA habitat useVIRGULA activity pattern and the effect of fire on the population. Mummucia coaraciandu n. sp. differs from other Mummuciidae in cheliceral dentition and pleurite coloration. Over a one-year periodVIRGULA 649 individuals of M. coaraciandu were captured in 72 pitfall traps distributed in three Cerrado physiognomies: borders of gallery forest (N~53)VIRGULA campo sujo (N~561) and campo cerrado (N~35). The species is diurnal and showed two peaks of surface activity during the year: the highest peak occurred in the cold-dry season (June to July) and the smaller peak in the middle of the warm-wet season (December to February). The number of individuals per trap was negatively correlated with the mean monthly temperatureVIRGULA but showed no correlation with the monthly precipitation. The sex ratio was male-biased (7:1) and the number of males trapped was positively correlated with the number of reproductive females. More individuals were trapped in burned areas when compared with unburned areas 1 month after the fire. This difference between the two areas was not observed 1 month before and 3-4 months after the passage of the fire (when the vegetation had recovered). Mummucia coaraciandu is the second solifuge described from the Brazilian Cerrado and its ecology is very similar to that of Mummucia mauryi from Caatinga vegetation. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Xenochironomus ceciliae (Diptera: Chironomidae)VIRGULA a new chironomid species inhabiting freshwater sponges in Brazil
column5: [Inglês] Chironomids living inside freshwater sponges are scarcely knownVIRGULA particularly in the Neotropical region where most of them are to be described. HereVIRGULA male and female adultsVIRGULA pupa and 4th instar larva of Xenochironomus ceciliae sp. n.VIRGULA living in freshwater sponges of the Paraná River (Brazil) are described. The larval labrum with its several densely setose or combed structures somewhat resembling the filtering structures of simuliid larvae and the predominance of fine detritus in the larval gut contentsVIRGULA may indicate that the larvae of Xenochironomus ceciliae sp. n. are collector-filterers and they might be favored by the aquifer systems of the sponges. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] HPLC method for the analysis of atrazine in freshwater bivalves
column5: [Inglês] A method for the analysis of atrazine in freshwater bivalves has been developed. The method involves a simple liquid C liquid extraction procedure followed by high©performance liquid chromatography analysis using a C 18 columnVIRGULA a methanol C water (60:40VIRGULA v/v) mobile phaseVIRGULA a flow©ate of 1 mL/minVIRGULA and UV detection at 230 nm. After optimization of the conditionsVIRGULA the method was validatedVIRGULA showing 81.7% atrazine recovery. Performance data for the method such as linearityVIRGULA precisionVIRGULA and quantitation limit are also reported. (AU)

column4: [Português] Variações bioquímicas durante o desenvolvimento da semente de Pinus taeda LVIRGULA [Inglês] Biochemical changes during seed development in Pinus taeda L
column5: [Inglês] Amino acidsVIRGULA polyaminesVIRGULA 3-indoleacetic acid (IAA)VIRGULA abscisic acid (ABA)VIRGULA buffer-soluble protein and starch contents and dry matter accumulation were analyzed in megagametophytes containing developing embryos during seed development in Pinus taeda. The highest total amino acids and polyamine contents occurred at the cotyledonary stageVIRGULA followed by a significant decrease in the mature seed. Free polyamines exhibited higher levels than conjugated onesVIRGULA with putrescine being the predominant type until the cotyledonary stageVIRGULA and spermidine at the mature seed stage. IAA content increased continually from the globular stage reaching the maximum at the cotyledonary stageVIRGULA followed by a decrease in the mature seed. The highest ABA level occurred at the globular stageVIRGULA followed by a continuous reduction until stabilization at the pre-cotyledonary stage. Buffer-soluble protein and starch contentsVIRGULA and dry matter increased progressively during developmentVIRGULA reaching their maximum values at the mature stage. column5: [Português] No presente trabalhoVIRGULA foi investigado o conteúdo de aminoácidos livresVIRGULA poliaminasVIRGULA ácido 3-indol acéticoVIRGULA ácido abscísicoVIRGULA proteínas solúveis em tampãoVIRGULA amido e acúmulo de matéria seca em megagametófitos contendo embriões em diferentes estágios durante o desenvolvimento de sementes em Pinus taeda. (AU)VIRGULA [Inglês] Somatic embryogenesis is the most important in vitro culture system for conifer propagation. HoweverVIRGULA Pinus taeda has been considered recalcitrant to somatic embryogenesis in commercial scale-up. The study of biochemical and physiological aspects of cell growth could lead to a better understanding of somatic embryogenesis in this species. In the present workVIRGULA we investigated the cell growth dynamicsVIRGULA intracellular levels of proteinsVIRGULA starch and polyamines in suspension cultures of Pinus taeda established in plant growth regulator-free medium (BM0) and in medium supplemented with 2 M 2VIRGULA4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acidVIRGULA 0.5 M 6-benzylaminopurine and 0.5 M Kinetin (BM2). Cell cultures growing in BM0 medium showed an increase in the sedimented cell volume from 3.77 to 17.73 ml after 24 days of culture. Those cultured in BM2 medium showed an increase in the sedimented cell volume from 4.23 to 25.17 ml after 20 days of culture. Intracellular proteins levels increased during the exponential growth phase and starch levels decreased until the exponential phaseVIRGULA followed by a synthesis up to the stationary phaseVIRGULA in both BM0 and BM2 media. Highest putrescine levels occurred in cultures growing in BM0 medium and this was associated with the low cellular growth. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Application of preparative high-speed counter-current chromatography for the separation of flavonoids from the leaves of Byrsonima crassa Niedenzu
column5: [Português] The methanolic extract of the leaves of the medicinal plant Byrsonima crassa (Malpighiaceae) contain flavonoids with antioxidant activity. They were separated in a preparative scale using high-speed counter-current chromatography. The optimum solvent system used was composed of a mixture of ethyl acetate-n-propanol-water (140:8:80 (v/v/v)) and led to a successful separation between monoglucosilated flavonoids (quercetin-3-O-a--arabinosideVIRGULA quercetin-3-O-ß--galactoside) and the biflavonoid amentoflavone in only 3.5 h. The purities of quercetin-3-O-a--arabinoside (95 mg)VIRGULA quercetin-3-O-ß--galactoside (16 mg) and the biflavonoid amentoflavone (114 mg) were all isolated at purity over 95%. Identification was performed by 1H NMRVIRGULA 13C NMR and UV analyses. (AU)

column4: [Inglês] Flavonoids and antiulcerogenic activity from Byrsonima crassa leaves extracts
column5: [Português] Byrsonima crassa Niedenzu (IK) (Malpighiaceae) is used in Brazilian folk medicine for the treatment of diseases related mainly to gastric ulcers. In this studyVIRGULA we evaluated the potential antiulcerogenic effect of three different extracts obtained from the leaves of Byrsonima crassa namely hydromethanolic (80% MeOH)VIRGULA methanolic (MeOH) and chloroformic extracts (CHCl3). The oral administration (250VIRGULA 500 and 1000 mg/kg) of all the extracts reduced the formation of lesions associated with HCl/ethanol administration in mice. The 80% MeOH extract significantly reduced the incidence of gastric lesions by 74VIRGULA 78 and 92% at doses of 250VIRGULA 500 and 1000 mg/kgVIRGULA respectively (P < 0.01). The MeOH extract reduced the ulceration by 93 and 99% only at the doses of 500 and 1000 mg/kg (P < 0.01). The lower gastroprotective action (69%) was observed when animals were treated with CHCl3 extract at the dose of 1000 mg/kg (P < 0.01). Phytochemical investigation of Byrsonima crassa afforded five known substances: quercetin-3-O-â-D-galactopyranosideVIRGULA quercetin-3-O-á-L-arabinopyranosideVIRGULA the biflavonoid amentoflavoneVIRGULA (+)-catechin and (&#8722PONTOCOMMA)-epicatechin. The presence of these phenolic compounds may probably explain the antiulcerogenic effect of the extracts of Byrsonima crassa leaves. (AU)
